Monster Beverage's (MNST) first-quarter earnings fell short of Wall Street forecasts on costs related to the termination of distribution agreements following its partnership with Coca-Cola.The energy drink maker's earnings grew 14% to 62 cents per share, below estimates for 68 cents. Net sales, excluding acceleration of deferred revenue, increased 9.5% to $587 million, missing views for $601.2 million.Shares were down 3.8% in extended trading after closing up 2% on the stock market today.Monster's international prospects are getting lift from its partnership with Coca-Cola (KO), which is acquiring a 16.7% stake in Monster and is its preferred distribution partner worldwide.Under the terms of the $2.15 billion transaction announced last year, Coke will transfer ownership of its energy-drink brands, including NOS and Full Throttle, to Monster. And Monster will transfer to Coke its nonenergy drinks business, such as Hansen's Natural Sodas and Peace Tea."To date we have transitioned approximately 84% of our targeted distribution rights in the United States to the Coca-Cola Company and its distribution network, which was accomplished with minimal disruption in the retail trade," CEO Rodney Sacks said Thursday in a statement. "We expect to transition an additional 5% of the targeted volume during this month."

Keurig Green Mountain (GMCR) late Thursday said its Keurig Kold cold-beverage maker won't fully roll out until the 2016 holiday season. That left investors feeling cold. Shareholders already have been burned by weak sales of the Keurig 2.0 brewer.Keurig Green Mountain will start selling the single-serve brewer for iced coffee, sodas, sports drinks, and iced tea online this fall. It will be available online and select retail stores this holiday. It won't reach all retail stores until the 2016 holiday season.BThe Kold device is supposed to have "one-button simplicity" — but executives said they will provide instructions on how to use the device.The Kold device was developed with Coca-Cola (KO). Coca-Cola has bought a significant stake in Keurig.There will be 16 brands of drinks to start, including Coke, Sprite, Dr. Pepper (DPS) and 6 Keurig options. Single-serve pods will cost 99 cents to $1.29.The Keurig Kold will start at $300, which left some analysts cold on Thursday's call.The Kold device is expected to take on SodaStream (SODA).Keurig shares fell 9% to 93.77 Friday on the stock market today, undercutting the 52-week low set last week on Keurig's disappointing earnings and outlook.Keurig launched its Keurig 2.0 brewer with high hopes last year. But shoppers balked at technology that prevented other coffee pods from working with the 2.0.Sales growth has stalled, with profits actually falling in the last two quarters. Keurig conceded in last week's post-earnings call that it made a mistake and said it would bring back refillable K-Cups.SodaStream shares, which have been in a long downtrend amid plunging sales, were little changed late Thursday.Follow Ed Carson on Twitter: @IBD_ECarson.

Today's IBD 50 list includes Ulta Beauty (ULTA) and four other consumer stocks poised for big gains. Meanwhile, the legendary investor cut stakes in Goldman Sachs Group (GS) and Wal-Mart Stores (WMT) to free capital for the $37.2 billion purchase of Precision Castparts (PCP). Dr Pepper Snapple (DPS) beat Wall Street estimates Thursday, thanks to strong sales of noncarbonated beverages and less exposure to currency headwinds than bigger rivals such as Coca-Cola (KO). The Plano, Texas-based company earned $1.05 a share, up 9.4% from a year earlier, beating by two cents the estimates of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Revenue rose 3.2% to $1.63…

Monster Beverage (MNST) is on track for its biggest gain in over two months as it climbs in heavy volume in the stock market today. The gain comes on the heels of an Evercore ISI report that said McDonald's (MCD) is testing the energy-drink maker's beverages at some of its locations and has seen "positive results."
According to the analyst, Monster could see as much as $1.5 billion in additional U.S. revenue with the new quick-serve restaurant distribution channel.
Shares jumped over 7% intraday to retake the 50-day moving average, which Monster hasn't traded above for eight weeks.
Just last week, the stock breached its 200-day line and closed below that level for the first time in over a year.
Monster is now trading about 11% below its early August peak as it works on the right side of a consolidation pattern.

In June, Monster and Coca-Cola (KO) sealed their deal to transfer all of the energy-drink maker's U.S. and Canada distribution to the soda giant, which now owns about a 17% stake in Monster. Coke and Monster also swapped ownership of several brands.
Coke and McDonald's have been in an alliance for decades, so the testing of Monster's beverages seems logical for the fast-food behemoth.

Everyone told Vicente Fox he was crazy to seek Mexico's presidency. The Institutional Revolutionary Party — Partido Revolucionario Institucional, or PRI — had been in power for 71 years.
It always won by stuffing ballot boxes, bribing officials, getting critics fired and murdering reformers.
As it turned out, he was crazy like a fox. The former Coca-Cola (KO) executive ran a grass-roots campaign that bypassed the censored media. On July 2, 2000, he shocked Mexico by beating the bullies.

"Over 100,000 of our supporters gathered at the Angel of Independence monument in Mexico City, and they were stomping so hard, foreign correspondents thought there was an earthquake," Fox told IBD. "One of my aides quipped, 'That's the sound of 100 million people who just got their freedom!'"
Popular President

Fox, now 72, left office in 2006 with a 70% approval rating. Some predecessors stole the silverware on the way out of the palace to live high in exile; he is building Mexico's first presidential library to be a center to promote honesty and transparency in public institutions.
Fox was the second of nine children when he was born in 1942, in San Francisco del Rincon in the central state of Guanajuato.
His father was Jose Fox, whose own father was an Ohioan of German descent. His mother, Mercedes, was a Basque from Spain.

The family owned a 1,000-acre ranch. By age 3, Vicente was up before dawn to milk cows. Soon he was hunting to provide more food. He spoke almost no English when, at 14, he went to Wisconsin for a year to learn and broaden his horizons.

In 1960, he enrolled in the business administration program at Universidad Iberoamericana in Mexico City and graduated four years later. But he was too antsy for a desk job. He joined Coca-Cola to drive a delivery truck to every corner of the country, convincing even the tiniest shops to stock the soda that was a laggard behind Pepsi.

He rose quickly, married Coke receptionist Lilian de la Concha in 1969 and was named president of Coca-Cola Mexico in 1974 (the same year he earned a diploma in management from Harvard after the firm gave him six months off).

Five years later, Coke's sales had increased 50%, and it was the No. 1 drink in the world's biggest per-capita soda market. Fox was a star, with an offer to head up the company's Latin American operation.
But that required a move to Miami. He decided instead to retire to the ranch in 1980.

Over the next eight years, he and Lilian realized they couldn't have their own children yet couldn't adopt because Mexican mothers rarely give up their babies. They found a home for unwed mothers in Costa Rica and eventually brought home four kids: Ana Christina, Paulina, Rodrigo and Vicente.
They had a healthy business manufacturing boots and exporting frozen vegetables to Texas.

Those ventures met a dead end, thanks to the government's mismanagement of the economy: defaulting on debt, devaluing the currency, endless red tape and bribery at every level. So in 1988, Fox ran for Congress with the center-right National Action Party (Partido Accion Nacional, or PAN), which was strong in that region.
Standing Up

The PRI reacted by pulling his business permits, having his bank loans called early and organizing strikes. "They did me a favor because with the main plant shut down, I could campaign full time," he said. "PAN's president, Manuel Clouthier, told me, 'Bullies are cowards, so if you hit back, they'll respect you.' I was angry enough that I began calling out the bad guys by name, and the people responded with righteous indignation after almost a century of repression."

Fox was one of 240 opposition candidates that the PRI had to concede won, despite its stuffing ballot boxes, giving the ruling party its narrowest majority ever in the 500-seat Congress. Congress had little power, but the rebels had studied Lech Walesa, Martin Luther King Jr. and Mahatma Gandhi and led constant street protests.

When Clouthier died suspiciously, Fox ran for governor of Guanajuato in 1991. Though he clearly won, the PRI insisted otherwise, until public protests grew so great that it agreed to let another PAN representative serve. Fox went back to the family business, which sprang back from the attempts to kill it. But he didn't quit politics. In 1995, election reforms that he helped push through led to his taking the governorship in a landslide.
Howdy, W
Now with a government title, he went up to Texas the next year to meet its governor, George W. Bush, who shared sympathies about illegal aliens flowing from Mexico and ways to increase trade.

Fox traveled the world to promote his state's products, and former Soviet boss Mikhail Gorbachev introduced him to Muhammad Yunus, who founded the Grameen Bank as a Bangladesh university student to deliver microloans to poor entrepreneurs.
Fox brought the idea home to create jobs. Yet in 1997, as he pondered running for president, he had two big problems:
Article 82 of the Constitution banned anyone whose parents and grandparents weren't born in Mexico. He organized a campaign that got the law changed.

PAN had only 28% of registered voters nationally. However, Fox had worked with local deputies for the PRI and the leftist Party of the Democratic Revolution (Partido de la Revolucion Democratica, or PRD) to get things done, so he reached beyond his base to create the Alliance for Change in 1999.
"I read books about the optimistic campaigns of Reagan, Clinton and Tony Blair, and studied their ads," said Fox.

Despite the PRI's spending hundreds of millions of dollars, its candidate won 36% of the vote in 2000; PRD's candidate won 17% and Fox 43%. His victory came on July 2, his 58th birthday. He became president in December, the first time in Mexican history that party power changed without violence.

Bush also won his country's top office that year. In February 2001, a month after his inaugural, he quit the tradition of U.S. presidents making the first state visit to Canada and went down to the Fox ranch. "Bush may be the single most focused individual I have ever met," Fox wrote in his 2007 memoir, "Revolution of Hope."

He and Lilian had divorced in 1990. In July 2001, Fox married his communications director, Marta Sahagun. Bush invited them to his first state dinner at the White House that September. And Fox became the first Mexican president to address a joint session of Congress.
Everything looked promising for improved relations, but days later, on Sept. 11, terrorists struck.
Cross-border traffic and tourism virtually stopped.

Mexico's presidents serve one six-year term. In his, Fox aggressively eased the police state, made it easier for companies to fire bad employees, trimmed debt, improved tax laws and created so many jobs that Mexican average per capita income rose 60% to the highest in Latin America.
Fox had set Mexico on an upward path. Fortune recently ranked the country as one of the seven best emerging markets for investors.
Fox has been on a whirlwind of activity based out of the Fox Center in San Francisco del Rincon.
Upcoming is a conference called Citek. The Sept. 30-Oct. 2 event will mix 1,500 executives to discuss the planned privatization of Mexico's energy industry. Bill O'Reilly is the headline speaker.
In Tune
Fox also is passionate about Rock Against Human Trafficking, which is using music to raise awareness about child slavery.
And he and Marta have foundations to deliver better nutrition and medical care to Mexico's children.

"President Fox has been the most important leader in Mexico's history for creating an environment to grow the economy and create great jobs," said Dave Phillipson of CEO Space of Southern California, a networking organization. "Now he's taking his crusade to inspire entrepreneurs to a global audience."Everyone told Vicente Fox he was crazy to seek Mexico's presidency. The Institutional Revolutionary Party — Partido Revolucionario Institucional, or PRI — had been in power for 71 years.It always won by stuffing ballot boxes, bribing officials, getting critics fired and murdering reformers.As it turned out, he was crazy like a fox. Keurig Green Mountain (GMCR) reported poor fiscal second-quarter results late Wednesday and cuts its full-year sales outlook.
Earnings fell 5% to $1.03 a share, missing views by 2 cents. Revenue increased 2% to $1.127 billion, below the consensus of $1.152 billion.
CEO Brian Kelley said the sales miss was "primarily due to the slower than expected transition to the Keurig 2.0 system."
He added that the company is taking actions to reduce brewer inventories and enhance 2.0 brewer packaging.
Keurig shares were down 11.5% in extended trading after it finished down 1.8% in regular trading on the stock market today.
Keurig forecast fiscal Q3 EPS of 75-80 cents, including an estimated 2 cents headwind from foreign currency exchange. That badly undershot consensus for $1.08.
The company also cut its 2015 sales outlook to flat to up by low-single digits from a prior view of growth in the mid-single to high-single digits.
Keurig will host a webcast for investors and analysts on May 14 to give an update on the Keurig Kold beverage maker it's been developing in partnership with Coca-Cola (KO).
In February Coke boosted its stake in Keurig to 16%, fueling speculation it may eventually buy the whole company.
Keurig has said it plans to launch Keurig Kold this fall, along with 30 flavors that can be used to make soft drinks, iced tea and other cold beverages.
Reports said that, unlike rival SodaStream's (SODA) home soft drink machines, Keurig Kold won't require a CO2 canister to make carbonated soft drinks.
SodaStream shares plunged more than 8% after reporting Q1 EPS jumped to 29 cents from 9 cents, beating views, while revenue fell 23% to $91.3 million, missing.

That badly undershot consensus for $1.08.The company also cut its 2015 sales outlook to flat to up by low-single digits from a prior view of growth in the mid-single to high-single digits.Keurig will host a webcast for investors and analysts on May 14 to give an update on the Keurig Kold beverage maker it's been developing in partnership with Coca-Cola (KO).In February Coke boosted its stake in Keurig to 16%, fueling speculation it may eventually buy the whole company.Keurig has said it plans to launch Keurig Kold this fall, along with 30 flavors that can be used to make soft drinks, iced tea and other cold beverages.Reports said that, unlike rival SodaStream's (SODA) home soft drink machines, Keurig Kold won't require a CO2 canister to make carbonated soft drinks.SodaStream shares plunged more than 8% after reporting Q1 EPS jumped to 29 cents from 9 cents, beating views, while revenue fell 23% to $91.3 million, missing.Follow James DeTar on Twitter: @IBD_JDeTar.

The year 1982 marked a turning point for S. Truett Cathy — and in the trajectory of the restaurant chain he founded, Chick-fil-A. Chick-fil-A had experienced nearly uninterrupted growth since its debut 15 years earlier.About 100 of Cathy's chicken sandwich restaurants dotted the country, mostly in the South.But that year, Chick-fil-A experienced its first (and only) decline in same-store sales.Fewer malls — where all of Cathy's restaurants were located then — were being built.And McDonald's and Wendy's were about to enter the quick-serve chicken market by offering chicken sandwiches and nuggets, which helped poultry prices soar."All of that focus on chicken would be good for us in the long run," Cathy explained in "Eat Mor Chikin, Inspire More People," his 2002 memoir, "but the immediate effect was a double punch that caused me many sleepless nights."Prudent InvestingCautious by nature, Cathy was also anxious about a corporate plan to double the number of Chick-fil-A's in two years and spend $10 million on a new corporate headquarters in Atlanta.Having grown up watching his mother struggle to run a boarding house in their home, Cathy hated the idea of carrying debt.So Cathy (1921-2014) invited his small executive committee on a two-day retreat.Instead of thinking up ways to cut costs, the execs reflected on why they were in the restaurant business to begin with.This discussion of first principles prompted Cathy and his team to articulate the following corporate mission statement:"To glorify God by being a faithful steward of all that is entrusted to us. To have a positive influence on all who come in contact with Chick-fil-A."That simple act worked. "Wonderful things began to happen," Cathy told Philanthropy magazine. "I felt confident in the future."The company grew by 29% in the next year and would go on to become one of the nation's largest family-owned companies. From then on, Cathy also began to focus more of his resources on charity, launching several endeavors that improved thousands of lives.Samuel Truett Cathy was born in Eatonton, Ga., and was an unlikely candidate to become a restaurant mogul. Growing up, he was a slow reader and learner."I didn't have much confidence in my ability," he wrote in "How Did You Do It, Truett?" another autobiography. He was a C student and never attended college.Cathy took on jobs — newspaper delivery boy, Coke (KO) stand operator — that instilled in him the importance of keeping the customer satisfied: "The key to succeeding with a paper route — and the restaurant business, I would later learn — is to take care of the customer."After high school and a stint in the Army, Cathy and his brother Ben borrowed $10,000 to open a restaurant in the Atlanta suburb of Hapeville in 1946.They called the restaurant Dwarf Grill because of its small size, later renaming it Dwarf House.Tragedy struck in 1949 when two of Cathy's brothers, including Ben, died when a plane they were flying in crashed. The year before, Truett had married Jeanette McNeil, with whom he had three children: Dan, Don ("Bubba") and Trudy.Jeanette was instrumental in getting Cathy to recommit to his Southern Baptist faith. "Her level of commitment showed me a new way to live," he wrote.Cathy built his business one satisfied customer at a time. But when he built a second restaurant, it promptly burned down.Cathy was philosophical about the loss. "When I had two restaurants, I had one too many," he later reflected. "So the Lord burned one down and gave me the chance to start Chick-fil-A."With only one restaurant to manage, Cathy had more time to develop what would become his signature chicken sandwich.He took his time. "I worked for years, adding this, taking away that," he wrote. "I was up to more than 20 seasonings and breading ingredients — twice as many as Col. Sanders had in his secret recipe."Southern StartCathy tested all of his variations on customers, gauging their reactions. It wasn't long before Cathy had trademarked the name Chick-fil-A and begun selling his chicken sandwiches to restaurants across the South. And in 1967, Cathy opened the first Chick-fil-A restaurant, in an Atlanta mall.Chick-fil-A was unique in two ways. It was the first fast-food restaurant to serve a skinless, boneless-breast chicken sandwich, and the first to operate in shopping malls. It was an immediate success.Over the succeeding decades, Chick-fil-A grew to more than 1,800 locations scattered across 40 states. Chick-fil-A opened its first freestanding restaurant in 1986 and its first drive-thru-only location in 1993.At the time of his death at age 93, Cathy's net worth was $1.9 billion, according to Bloomberg.The year before, the company took in more than $5 billion, making it the country's largest fast-food chicken restaurant by sales.In 2010, Chick-fil-A became the industry leader in average sales in its restaurants: $2.7 million per.Chick-fil-A's massive growth was helped by its "Eat Mor Chikin" ad campaign. It featured hapless dairy cows trying to persuade the public to eat chicken sandwiches instead of hamburgers by, in one example, painting "Eat mor chikin" on a billboard. The amusing campaign has remained a core part of Chick-fil-A's ads for two decades, winning numerous industry awards.Cathy succeeded by following four key principles: 1. The main reason companies fail is their desire to grow too fast too soon. Cathy exercised caution and patience. He spent 21 years owning just one restaurant, learning the trade and saving enough money to try new ventures. He never went into debt and never took his company public, which made him accountable only to God, himself and his customers. 2. As restaurant consultant and marketing expert Aaron Allen told IBD, Chick-fil-A "focuses on speed, accuracy, cleanliness. They're not showy. As other companies start to drift, it has remained focused on fundamentals."Chick-fil-A offers a basic chicken sandwich and a small menu that rarely changes. By doing so, it can focus on quality. Result: In 2014, Consumer Reports ranked Chick-fil-A's chicken sandwich No. 1. 3. The company's faith-based corporate culture is most clearly seen in its policy of closing on Sundays. Cathy said the policy is the result of his desire that employees save at least one day a week for God and family. 4. The "loyalty effect" is something Cathy instilled in employees and customers.Denise Lee Yohn, author of the book "What Great Brands Do," says that Chick-fil-A has engendered a deep devotion from customers by serving a high-quality product and through top customer service. Chick-fil-A "really does go the extra mile to serve its customers," she said. That includes everything from community-building promotions to college scholarships for staffers. Many call Chick-fil-A's employees among the industry's kindest. They often respond to customer requests with a hearty "my pleasure."Tasteful Loyalty"In the past 60 years, no matter the ups and downs, I have learned that the number one thing to do is to please the customer and they will come back," Cathy once said.As he became wealthy, Cathy donated more of his time and money to charities and started one of his own, called the WinShape Foundation, which provides scholarships and foster homes to needy children. Cathy himself was a foster parent for more than 30 years. He liked to say that some 150 children called him Grandpa."People ask me why I invest so much in the foster homes," he said. "The one thing I take more joy in than anything else in the world is seeing young people develop. They grow and make good decisions. They want to be winners despite the odds against them."That's an aspiration that Cathy helped thousands of people, including himself, realize.
Stock futures swept higher ahead of Friday's open, accelerating early gains after a mixed April payroll report.
Dow futures surged 194 points above fair market value. Nasdaq 100 futures powered up 48.6 points and S&P 500 futures showed a strong 20.7-point gain.

The stock market today gets rolling with the Nasdaq down 1.2% so far in what would be its second straight weekly slip. The S&P 500 is off not quite 1%, also in a second down week. The S&P 500 opens just above, the Nasdaq just below their 50-day moving averages. But the market's opening position is nothing new — investors have been seeing similar poses for months. Likelier to matter Friday is the Labor Department's April payrolls report, the latest event showing some potential to snap the market higher or lower and break the momentum deadlock that has contained trade since March. Remember, a weak payroll report is a positive for stocks, implying the Federal Reserve may be likely to hold off on any interest rate increases.

The April report showed nonfarm payrolls increasing by 223,000 in April, sharply above the department's original March estimate of 126,000 new jobs and just above analyst projections for 220,000. The March estimate was revised downward to a weak 85,000. The unemployment level held at 5.4%, disappointing some forecasts for a downtick to 5.3%. The closely watched average hourly earnings number edged up 0.1%, less than consensus expectations for a 0.2% gain. The average workweek held steady at 34.5 hours.

In stocks,Syngenta (SYT) surged 12% ahead of the open. The Switzerland-based pesticide maker and seed developer announced it had rejected a takeover offer by U.S. peer Monsanto (MON) that had reportedly valued the company around $45 billion. Syngenta shares have been in a deepening correction for 26 months, under pressure due partly to currency issues and partly from political issues regarding genetically modified crop strains. The stock shot up 16% May 1 and has been volatile following reports of a possible Monsanto deal.
Leaders broke in both directions in premarket trade.

Tableau Software (DATA) snapped up 8% after reporting late Thursday its first-quarter sales and earnings thrashed analyst consensus views. The data analytics leader's management also lifted Q2 and full-year revenue guidance above expectations. The stock ended Thursday not quite 2% below a flat-base buy point of 99.39.

Monster Beverage (MNST) dived more than 5% before the starting bell. The energy drink maker's first-quarter earnings and revenue growth stopped well short of consensus expectations. Earnings took a hit largely due to costs related to termination of distribution agreements as the company shifts its distribution rights to Coca-Cola (KO), which is acquiring a 16.7% stake in the company. Monster finished Thursday's session perched above its 50-day moving average and just below a 144 buy point in a flat base.

Overseas, China's markets closed out the week with strong gains: the Shanghai composite up 2.3% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng ahead 1.1%. In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 ticked up 0.5% to post a 0.8% decline for the week.
Europe's market punched higher after Britain's conservative party won a narrow majority in Parliament. London's FTSE 100 led the major indexes with a 1.9% gain.

The dollar was up across the board. Oil rose modestly after slipping off its short-term highs on Thursday. For the week, both the U.S. benchmark West Texas Intermediate and Europe's benchmark Brent crude are effectively unchanged. Making sure that the next generation doesn't squander the wealth you worked to acquire means sharing your smarts and values. Financial experts urge starting early.

"The earlier you can have an open discussion about succession and inheritance planning with both generations, the better the odds are that the planning will be effective," said Ian Weinberg, CEO of Family Wealth & Pension Management in Woodbury, N.Y. "Introducing the kids to the team of professionals now is also critical."

 Step up. As you zero in on kids, said Kevin Reardon, owner of Shakespeare Wealth Management in Pewaukee, Wis., "the child can have three containers for their money: 1. short-term spending (candy, soda, fun stuff); 2. long-term savings (for electronics, car, college); 3. charitable giving. If you want to teach the children about values, showing them how to give to charity is a great first step. The three buckets is a great way to teach basic budgeting."

 Give with purpose. "Start discussing financial topics early with grandchildren," said Nancy Anderson, a certified financial planner at Key Private Bank in Salt Lake City. "One way to open up that discussion is when you are giving them a check for their birthday, ask them to call you before you send it. Discuss what they might do with the money. You can use this opportunity to talk about saving and spending."

 Train teens. Reardon says that a job in high school is key: "It teaches responsibility and gives them an opportunity to practice what we've taught. When the child learns how to drive, have them pay for some or all of the gas or insurance."
Mitchell Kraus, a CFP at Capital Intelligence Associates in Santa Monica, Calif., added: "If you don't learn the value of a dollar, you won't be able to build on that wealth you (have)."

 Build independence. Be sure the kids have their own financial plan so they won't depend on inherited money, said Cindy Richey, president of Prosperity Planning in Kansas City, Mo.: "It starts with expecting your kids to earn their own way and save and invest on their own. We have nine clients (ages 16 to 25) who were referred to us by their parents and have invested their own money. We meet with them annually and reinforce good savings habits. Their parents have told them many of the same things, but hearing it from a professional advisor reinforces it."

 Teach investing. Reardon suggests buying children stock in something that they understand — such as Disney (DIS), Coke (KO), Apple (AAPL) or Sony (SNE). "The kids will look much differently at things in their life if they can equate it to business or investments," he told IBD.

 Plan college. Managing higher-education costs is good training for handling inheritance money. Reardon says that the college-application process should include a discussion of the cost-benefit analysis of each university or major.

"Having them pay for at least some of their tuition is important," he said. "Children will be more tuned in to money and begin to learn skills related to consumption. This is a great opportunity to teach them about opportunity cost."
 Pass on values. Identify family stories and life lessons, using them as the cornerstone for all planning, says Mark LaSpisa, president of Vermillion Financial Advisors in the Chicago area.
 Try 'em. Future heirs learn and sharpen skills by running part of the business.

"Depending on the age and skill set of the family member, they could be given a portion of the family budget to manage," LaSpisa said. "Perhaps place them in charge of a major purchase (or) project."Making sure that the next generation doesn't squander the wealth you worked to acquire means sharing your smarts and values. PepsiCo (PEP) topped third-quarter expectations and raised its 2015 earnings outlook even as it recorded a $1.4 billion charge related to a change in accounting for its Venezuela operations.Earnings dipped 0.7% to $1.35 a share, above estimates by 9 cents. Revenue fell over 5% to $16.33 billion, as foreign exchange woes weighed on results. Analysts had forecast $16.15 billion in sales.North America beverage volume rose 3% as revenue grew 5%. The category includes Pepsi, Gatorade, Naked Juice and other drinks.Volume for Frito-Lay North America — the snack segment that includes Cheetos and Sun Chips — edged up 0.5%, while sales grew 2%. Quaker Foods North America volume and sales rose 2%."Our year-to-date mid-single-digit organic revenue growth and double-digit core constant currency EPS growth reflect our focus on managing those things that are in our control in a challenging environment, namely innovation, brand building, marketplace execution, and productivity," said CEO Indra Nooyi in a statement."Productivity, in particular, continues to simultaneously fund investments in our business and contribute to margin enhancement, and we remain on track to deliver our five-year, $5 billion productivity savings target through 2019."PepsiCo raised its core constant currency per-share earnings growth target to 9%, up from prior guidance for 8% growth. Currency headwinds are expected to weigh on core EPS by 11%. The company said it is "on track" to produce $1 billion in productivity savings and $9 billion in cash returns to shareholders.Shares closed up 1.3% to 97.07 in the stock market today. Coca-Cola (KO) dipped 0.1%.Follow Elaine Low on Twitter @IBD_ELow.RELATED:Consumer ETFs Usher In Q3 Earnings Season.

The ProShares Dividend Aristocrats ETF (NOBL) holds S&P; 500 firms with the longest track records of year-over-year dividend growth. Coca-Cola (KO), McDonald's (MCD) and AT&T; (T), members of Friday's Dividend Leaders screen, are top-25 holdings. So is Consolidated Edison (ED) in the Utility Leaders Screen. Several other highly rated dividend names in IBD's database, all with Composite Ratings of 80…

Snack and beverage giant PepsiCo (PEP) served up an earnings surprise Tuesday, pushing the stock up more than 1%. Pepsi cleared resistance at about 95 and is approaching its Feb. 11 high. The stock is forming a cup-type base with a 100.71 entry. The stock is a member of the S&P; 500 Dividend Aristocrats index, which comprises 52 companies that…

A wild run-up in a stock you own is exciting, but what you ideally want to see while the stock is basing is just the opposite type of action. When a stock is consolidating after a pronounced advance in price, the calmer the action, the better.Instead of wide and loose price action on big spikes in volume, look for stocks with tight weekly closes in calm, quiet trade."On a weekly chart, tightness is defined as small price variations from high to low for the week, with several consecutive weeks' prices closing unchanged or remarkably near the previous week's close," IBD founder and Chairman William O'Neil wrote in "How to Make Money in Stocks.""If the base pattern has a wide spread between the week's high and low points every week, it's been constantly in the market's eye and frequently will not succeed when it breaks out," he wrote.Tight weekly closes signal accumulation by the big money: mutual funds, pensions, banks and other institutional investors.Let's say the market is selling off, but a leading stock on your watch list is trading tightly, with small price changes from week to week. That's a sign that some big money managers may be building a position in the stock but spreading purchases out over weeks or months, instead of causing a big price and volume spike by buying a stake at once.If large-fund managers are dumping shares, a stock will go down in heavy volume. Likewise, if they are snapping up shares, the stock will rise in brisk turnover.Tight trading is easier to spot in a flat base, due in part to the pattern's nature. The correction from a price high is contained within 15% from the base's peak to the trough. But it's a bullish trait that can occur in cup, cup-with-handle and double-bottom bases, too.Monster Beverage (MNST) saw some wild and loose overall price action in 2012 and into 2013, but trading began to tighten up in subsequent bases. The stock cleared a cup-with-handle base in December 2013, and rose 19% before consolidating again.The new pattern, which kicked off in February 2014, featured several areas of tight trading with a weekly change of less than 1%.Shares rocketed nearly 35% in the week ended Aug. 15, triggering the eight-week hold rule for winners that rally more than 20% in three weeks or less. That week, Coca-Cola (KO) said it would take a 16.7% ownership stake in Monster as part of a deal in which Coke would transfer its energy drink portfolio to Monster.The next week, shares fell 7.6% to start the left side of a new base. Weekly price action stayed in a fairly narrow range for the seven-week duration of the flat base, including a 1% or smaller price change for four straight weeks (1).Volume was light in the base, which is ideal. Monster cleared the 95.03 buy point Oct. 10, but heavy trade didn't kick in until the week ended Nov. 7, when the stock rallied 7% in above-average volume (2).The tight trading in calm volume helped set Monster up for a big run. Shares advanced as much as 64% from the entry to its early August peak of 155.83.

Talk about caffeine highs and lows. After negative publicity surrounding the health risks of consuming too much caffeine slowed growth in 2013, the energy-drink market resumed its run last year.Health risks apparently weren't shown to be strong enough to hold back core energy-drink consumers for too long."The fact is, a lot of core consumers of energy drinks — young males — don't tend to pay a lot of attention to health concerns," Amit Sharma, an analyst with BMO Capital Markets, told IBD.Industry watchers say the category is poised for healthy growth the next few years at least.That's good news for the two dominant players in the energy-drink market: Corona, Calif.-based Monster Beverage (MNST) and its chief rival, the Austrian company Red Bull.Sharma, for one, recently assured his clients that it was safe not only for most people to consume energy drinks, but also to invest in Monster Beverage.Energy-Drink Safety BuzzIn a client note, Sharma pointed to "mounting scientific evidence" that consuming energy drinks in moderate amounts is safe. Together with Monster Beverage's voluntary labeling and marketing changes, he said, the risk of adverse regulatory action is largely removed.Monster now displays its total caffeine on packaging and an advisory warning that its energy drinks are not recommended for children, caffeine-sensitive people and pregnant or nursing women. It also reduced marketing programs to consumers under 18.How does Monster view health risks related to its energy drinks? Company executives declined to comment on any aspect of the business. But the first comment from CEO Rodney Sacks in a Feb. 26 conference call following its fourth-quarter report said it all: "We reiterate that our products are safe."Monster's gross sales in the quarter grew 12.1% vs. the prior year to $696.3 million. Earnings shot up 63% to 72 cents per share, sending Monster's stock up 13% to 141.Earnings for the full year jumped 42% over 2013 to $2.77 per share vs. 5% year-over-year growth in 2013. Gross sales for the year grew 9.3% to $2.8 billion.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect 2015 earnings to rise 22% to $3.37."We think there is more upside to the stock," said Sharma, who has an outperform rating on it.The energy-drink market peaked in 2011 and 2012 on double-digit sales growth, according to the Mintel Group, a global market research agency. Mintel forecasts that energy-drink sales in the U.S. will grow around 40% from 2014 to 2019, or nearly 7% a year on average, as new users join the core cohort of 18- to 34-year-old males.Red Bull is the market leader in energy drinks worldwide. It's been selling energy drinks overseas longer and in more countries than Monster. But in the U.S., where Monster derives most of its sales, Monster and Red Bull are running neck and neck."Monster has been pulling up on Red Bull, and they are almost tied now," said John Sicher, editor and publisher of Beverage Digest.Monster Beverage was called Hansen Natural until the name got changed in 2012 to reflect the company's greater sales from Monster energy drinks than from natural soda and tea.Hansen launched its first energy drinks in 1997 and followed five years later with Monster Energy, which still comes in supersized, 16-ounce black cans featuring neon claws and Goth lettering on the outside and various vitamins and herbs on the inside — in addition to a blast of caffeine.Brand Grows RapidlyNearly 80% of Monster's sales are in the U.S., where Monster is growing faster than the overall energy-drink market.Red Bull is growing a little faster than Monster this year, however, due to the launch of new flavors, Sharma says. But he expects Monster's U.S. sales this year to grow in double digits.Monster is rolling out at least a couple of new products this year, such as recently launched Monster Energy Ultra Citron and Monster Rehab Peach Tea + Energy.But the biggest change will come from a deal with Coca-Cola (KO), set to close in the current quarter. Coke will acquire a 16.7% stake in Monster and become its preferred distribution partner worldwide.Under terms of the $2.15 billion transaction, Coke will transfer ownership of its energy-drink brands, including NOS and Full Throttle, to Monster. And Monster will transfer to Coke its nonenergy drinks business, such as Hansen's Natural Sodas and Peace Tea."Monster gets access to the powerful Coke bottling system," said Sicher. "Coke gets a significant equity stake in a very fast-growing beverage company, and its bottlers get more distribution of Monster."Coke's new role "will certainly accelerate the timeline for Monster's expansion into international markets," Sharma said.Going For The GlobeMonster's international sales have already been growing faster than domestic sales. Sacks said in the call that Japan is "becoming one of our largest international markets." He added that expansion in Germany, Great Britain, Greece, the Netherlands and Chile is also going well.One potential new market is China, Sharma says."You could argue that over time, Coca-Cola will help Monster go into that market," he said. "It's one of the biggest energy-drink markets, and Monster is not in that market today."In a recent research report, analyst Theo Brito of BTIG suggested that at least $1.2 billion in new revenue opportunities could be up for Monster under the Coke "brand swap" from expansion into new consumer niches.Such new niche segments could include "edgy millennial women," baby boomers and more affluent consumers overall, he noted. But still, young males "may always be the largest energy drink consumer."

The Obama administration sent a double message last month when it resumed military aid to Egypt. The most populous Arab nation will now receive F-16 jets, Harpoon anti-ship missiles and Abrams tank upgrade kits withheld following the military ouster of its elected president in July 2013. Starting in 2018, however, its army will no longer be allowed to buy weapons…

Stock futures battled out of early losses and into mixed terrain ahead of Wednesday's open, with earnings news driving much of the action.
The Nasdaq shed early losses and climbed 2.6 points above fair market value. Dow futures kept an 11.6-point loss, but were improving. S&P 500 futures slipped a fraction into negative territory.

The stock market today follows a mixed finish Tuesday, in which earnings and M&A action had a positive influence on the Nasdaq and slumping oil prices hauled the S&P 500 off its gains to a mild loss. Resistance and distribution remain major factors. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq have been consistently plotting higher lows, a technical plus. But the market's status remains "uptrend under pressure," so caution remains the keyword for investors.
Stocks
Big names moving on earnings news included McDonald's (MCD) (up 2%), Coca-Cola (KO) (up 2%) and Boeing (BA) (down 1%).
Chip-related plays were busy ahead of the open.

Netherlands-based ASML (ASML) rocketed 11% after announcing an agreement to deliver 15 EUV lithography systems to an unnamed U.S. customer. The stock is looking to regain key levels of support in a monthlong consolidation.

Broadcom (BRCM) spiked 6% after its Q1 sales and earnings, reported late Tuesday, easily cleared expectations. Second-quarter earnings guidance was in line with expectations. The premarket move implies an open at a new high, although premarket moves often evaporate prior to the open. The stock is in the fifth week of a flat consolidation — too deep for a pullback to test support, and too short for a flat base.

Cree (CREE) collapsed 5%. It reported mixed fiscal third-quarter results late Tuesday. Revenue beat, earnings missed and gross margins slipped. The stock has been rising since April 6, attempting to fashion a bottom to an eight-week consolidation.
Economic News

Housing markets receive the week's first real dose of economic news today, with the Federal Housing Finance Agency reporting its February Housing Price Index at 9 a.m. ET. The National Association of Realtors delivers its March exiting home sales numbers at 10 a.m. March existing-home sales numbers are due out Thursday.
Overseas

China's indomitable markets continued higher: the Shanghai Composite up 2.4% and Hong Kong Kong's Hang Seng index up 0.3%. In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 popped 1.1%. Europe's leading indexes were under pressure near midday, with Frankfurt's DAX down hardest, with a 1.1% loss.
Currencies/Commodities

The buck backed down vs. the euro and the yen. Commodities were mixed. Oil shed a fraction, but with U.S. benchmark West Texas Intermediate crude holding above $56 a barrel and Europe's Brent crude near $62. "Fed Keeps December Rate Hike In Play - Officials remove explicit mention of concern at overseas tumult, delivering warning to markets" - WSJ 10-29-15
The operative word in that headline is 'Play'....in this case Play is defined as 'engaging in activity for enjoyment or fun - to amuse oneself'
"Federal Reserve officials explicitly said they might raise short term interest rates in December pushing back against investors who have bet that the central bank wouldn’t move this year."

They continue to try and convince us that they are going to move in 2015....and December is their last opportunity.......but can they really?  US macro data continues to weaken,  The U6 Underemployment rates is still above 10%, inflation remains frustratingly low,  congress just approved a disastrous 'spending plan' kicking their responsibility into the NEXT CENTURY,  The ECB announces a new bigger & better QE type program to further stimulate that sagging economy, and China?  Well they cut short term lending rates last week in a last ditch effort to 'boost growth' while they continue to threaten another currency devaluation.....and Hilsenrath thinks that these moves signal 'STRENGTH'.........and pave the way for the FED to raise rates?   Now in a move to show us how serious they really are - the FED " struck from their policy statement a sentence introduced in September that pointed to market turbulence and global developments as potential restraints on U.S. economic activity. As those concerns recede, the Fed has fewer impediments standing in the way of a rate increase."

Now the funny thing is that the FED is clearly split....some say go, while other say no.......and yesterday's statement was supposed to remove any doubt at all about the coming increase.   Remember - the FED remains 'data dependent' so we will get two more months of 'data' before the FED meets again on Dec 16th/17th.....but remember - they may have wanted to send 'that wakeup call' but in the end - yesterday's statement DID NOT commit to a December move.....(they left the door slightly ajar so that they have an exit plan....)

And amuse themselves is exactly what they did.....Stocks rallied early on prior to 'the announcement'  - the DOW was up 131 pts at 2 pm.....then the news hits...the mkts stumbles as it dissects the headline...then the algo's hit......sending stocks into a minor tailspin sending the DOW  - down 287 pts - from hi to lo.....in a matter of 13 mins.....only to reverse and surge higher into the close as the 'smart algos' realized that the statement didn't really say anything new...there was NO definitive decision....there was nothing in there that sets the path for a move in December at all.....Yeah - there was a vague reference to a move - but does anyone really believe it to be true?  Not yesterday anyway...as they closed the mkt on its highs  at 2090 on the S&P and 17,779 on the DOW..... You gotta love when the FED speaks out of both ends, no?

It is interesting to think that all of a sudden the FED thinks that economy is ready to launch..... Remember!  The Fed hasn’t raised interest rates since 2006 - (they have only lowered them)  and here 9 yrs later  when we have zero interest rates (while some countries have negative rates)  - we also have manufacturing crashing, durable goods and retail sales plunging our national debt approaching $19 trillion, housing still struggling, healthcare costs soaring, wages stagnating,  entitlement programs exploding, Underemployment still in the double digits, weak commodity prices, struggling global economies, half the world in recession and the other half gasping for air and NOW she thinks it's the right time to launch?   Is it me?  Now all this says is that monetary policy alone cannot solve the world's problems....so I once again point the finger at leadership.....or lack of...but hey...that's a conversation for another time I guess.....
In the end - The FED made it clear that they won't raise rates until they are 'reasonably confident' that the data supports the move.....and that ain't happening in 60 days.....

Technically  - the mkt has enjoyed a surge off the August lows...making everyone 'feel better' but is it really better?   Have we moved too fast and now need to play catch up?  I think that answer is yes....and as the mkt gets used to the latest FED speak and analysts/strategists recalculate the possibilities - I suspect that we see the mkt back and fill..... Last night we ended at S&P 2090.....a good 30 pts above support.....earnings are coming to an end and so the focus will return to more broader global macro issues once again....For now - I think we are in the 2060/2100 range...and if the 'data' continues to disappoint then expect the mkt to find its legs and push higher (indicating NO rate increase) ....but if as Janet indicates - the 'data' becomes stronger -then yes....look for the mkt to back off as the reality of an 'increase' hits home....and the mkt re-prices.  Either way - I do not think we get a move in 2015...so I suspect that the mkt churns and attempts to return closer to the yearly highs (2150)  as we approach year end.

Now this morning - US futures are off 8 pts  as we await the first release of 3rd QTR GDP...and it does not have a 3 handle on it, and it does not have a 2 handle on it......we will be lucky if it has a 1 handle on it...as the Atlanta FED suggests it will be 0.9% (vs. the robust 3.9% in the 2nd qtr) and some of the biggest investment banks in the country are looking for 1.2% - 1.4% .  The 'official' (govt) expectation is for a reading of +1.6%.... and if it comes in stronger then I think someone will have 'a lot of 'splainin to do' ......
Look for earnings today from MasterCard (MA),Western Union  (WU), CME Group  (CME),Air Products  (APD), Good Year Tires  (GT), Coca Cola  (KO), Pitney Bowes  (PBI),  and Marathon Oil  (MRO).....

European mkts are in negative territory.....not big, but a bit softer....earnings are the focus.......DBK reports a loss of $6.5 bil  and said that they will CUT their workforce by some 26k jobs over the next 2 yrs - sending that stock lower.........Barclays also missed on their earnings....sending that stock down 4.5%... Frances Total Oil reports a 69% drop in revenue....(no surprise)  and they take the stock UP......Take good care. Kp

Greg Steltenpohl is a pioneer in the nonalcoholic beverage industry. And he has advice for the entrepreneur who thirsts to make it big. If you want to win in a product category, study hard and truly grasp what your competitors do.Then go out and create something unique. Or make the product a different way.That advice from the head of Califia Farms may be easy to swallow, yet it's hard to do.How does one get started on the right path and do both things well?The CEO revs up his team by inspiring it to imagine, think, design and execute steps into the future."At Califia we're trying to build innovation and kind of asking the question about the question after the question," Steltenpohl told IBD. "We're trying to build that kind of culture of inquiry into everything that we do. And when you apply that type of cultural attribute to fundamental business aspects like manufacturing, it emerges as a core strategy."Sweet TriumphsSteltenpohl knows about success in the tough field of beverages.He turned the U.S. fruit and vegetable juice market on its head after co-founding the Odwalla brand in 1980. That firm focused on minimally processed juice. He sold it to Coca-Cola (KO) in 2001 for $181 million, worth $242 million today.Steltenpohl is doing it again, this time via 5-year-old Pasadena, Calif.-based Califia Farms, which he co-founded with Sun Pacific.Califia has become a giant in almond milk, one of the fastest-growing niches in the food and beverage industry. How does Califia take Steltenpohl's advice to heart?When he started the company in 2010 and began production in 2011, he re-entered the citrus juice market. In his eyes, since citrus is the No. 1 beverage-flavoring agent in the world, Califia could not become a serious player without having at least one product in that category.So his team pondered this point: What could grow to become as popular as orange juice?They decided to develop a market in specialty flavors such as mandarin orange and clementine.Four years later, according to Steltenpohl, Califia is the country's largest producer of tangerine juice.Califia created California Lemonade with its different taste. "The Meyer lemon has 10% to 15% less acid (than other lemon types). It has a much rounder flavor, and so you can lower the sugar content (and) increase the drinkability and the (beneficial) effects on people's stomachs," Steltenpohl said.Soon he moved into almond milk. Before making a single quart, his team thought hard about how to approach the market.Here's To Improvement"We weren't the first to market. Our thought process was, 'How can you make it better? How can you leapfrog where the pack is and really make something that provides a benefit and is not simply another brand?'" Steltenpohl said.His solution was to reinvent the manufacturing process. Large almond milk makers cook up the nuts with heat and oil, then mix the resulting butter with water.Such a process creates oxidized byproducts, affecting taste.In contrast, Steltenpohl uses a method that he equates to recipes that date back to the Middle Ages.Rather than heat the almonds, Califia artisans blanch the skin off, make what Steltenpohl calls soaked milk flour, and then apply filtering steps. "This allows us to place more almonds per ounce than most of our competitors and come up with an ultracreamy, velvety mouth feel without traditional food science techniques and lots of gums and binders," he said.Califia continues to innovate with products that range from almond-milk-based horchata to Double Espresso Pure Cold Brew Coffee With Almondmilk to agua fresca drinks with flavors such as watermelon, strawberry, mango, basil, ginger and chili lime.As of July, Califia products are in 27,000 retail outlets, including Kroger (KR), Safeway, Wal-Mart (WMT), Whole Foods (WFM), Gelson's Markets, Fresh & Easy and Stater Bros.Steltenpohl forecasts annual sales to hit $100 million in 2016."Greg is a once-in-a-lifetime leader with whom to work," said Kaitlin Walter, a Califia marketing officer who joined the firm after a stint at Coke. "Greg takes everyone's point of view seriously, weighing the various opinions from his team carefully before making executive decisions. He encourages all Califia employees to think creatively and out of the box, both by example and through encouragement."Big MoneyFurther growth looks likely. On Sept. 15, Califia announced a $50 million investment by Stripes Group, a New York equity firm focused on consumers and tech.While almond milk industry sales are growing at a 40% annual clip, according to a report in May by market researcher Packaged Facts, Califia's Almondmilk brand enjoys 177% yearly growth.Dan Marriott, managing partner at Stripes, calls Steltenpohl a "true product visionary" and adds, "Greg is assembling an amazing team and has cultivated a culture of rapid innovation focused on delivering premium, healthful products."Steltenpohl, 60, has lived near oranges his entire life. During childhood, his family moved from Homestead, Fla., to Southern California's Highland area, once a hotbed of orange growth."My father always picked houses away from people and near orange groves, so I was raised near the smell of orange blossoms," he said. "This made a deep imprint on me. So when I was just out of college and broke, making fresh squeezed orange juice just made sense."That college was Stanford, where he says he was the first to design and complete an undergraduate degree in environmental studies.After college, he joined two partners to start Odwalla as a simple business, selling fresh-squeezed orange juice out of a van in Santa Cruz, Calif. The idea was to offer something of premium quality.Sales grew, and Odwalla expanded outside of California by 1994.Two years later, an outbreak of E. coli bacteria contaminated a batch of apple juice shipments. Odwalla juice used blemished fruit, killing a child and sickening 66.It was not only tragic but also a public relations disaster. Sales dropped 90%, according to a Harvard Business School case study published in 1997. In 1998, Odwalla agreed to pay $1.5 million and admit guilt to charges of selling contaminated juice.Steltenpohl learned that to prevent such a calamity from recurring, a leader must have operating principles in place for factory workers to report any problems directly to top management.Steltenpohl is married with three sons, all of whom work in the beverage industry. He carries such passion for his products that he hasn't let a liver transplant several years ago slow his effort to meet with buyers at big trade shows such as Expo West in Anaheim, Calif.Winning WayIt's clear to Steltenpohl that corporate culture is vital."One of the biggest things I learned is that you can use your culture as a significant competitive advantage and as a kind of business systems strategy," he said, adding: "All of a sudden, you're bringing in all sorts of creative opportunities. You're bringing in a higher degree of quality control. And you're bringing kind of an excitement, you're infusing culture with a closeness to the product. I feel all of those pay off in the long run. I learned that at Odwalla, and I've been applying it in spades here at Califia."

Sophia Loren, Michelangelo, Benvenuto Cellini, Leonardo da Vinci, Guglielmo Marconi, Fibonacci (Leonardo Bonacci), Federico Fellini, Luciano Pavarotti - There is just a handful of famous Italians that have contributed immensely to Italian and world history ......and today - one of the most famous (and sexually charged) Italians comes to the NYSE......Today - we welcome Ferrari - ticker symbol RACE to the NYSE family of companies.

Ferrari - is an Italian luxury sports car manufacturer - founded by Enzo Ferrari in 1929....originally to build race cars...in 1947 - Ferrari moved into the production of 'street legal' luxury cars. In 1969 FIAT acquired 50% of the company and in 1988 took control of 40% more taking their total stake to 90%.
In 2014 Fiat Chrysler announced that it would sell 10% of the company to the public and today is the day.....expect the 'street' to be awash in testosterone as the excitement builds....

Broad Street - now known as 'experience square' has a dozen Ferrari's on display - 'only to look at - no touching allowed' ...which will only serve to drive the men into a frenzy..... The IPO was priced last night at $52/share - at the high end of the range - and was 'way oversubscribed' .....so instead of raising the IPO price to cool demand - they decided to remain within the range to create the 'desire' in the aftermarket......You can feel the excitement building, the tingle in your spine, the rapid breathing, the toe curling excitement and the rush of blood as the heart beats faster and faster exploding with fury as the opening bell rings.....( What a great way to start the day - I 'm exhausted already...)

Stocks chopped yesterday - as healthcare stocks got whacked over more political wrangling and investors/traders grew concerned about IBM (IBM) earnings and mounting concerns over Marissa Meyers options at Yahoo (YHOO) .......... The choppy trading on Wall Street suggests that traders are uncertain about the near-term direction of equities following the recent volatility and continuing disappointments in earnings reports and forward guidance.
IBM shares dropped 5.75% (or $8.50) after the company reported lower quarterly revenue for the 14th straight quarter - they also lowered guidance for the fiscal year.

So - investors and traders reacted to how far off the mark IBM's stock price was from fundamentals. The stronger dollar in this case - did hurt. The stock has been in a downtrend since July as investors began to re-price the company based on $ concerns..........breaking every support level it had only to find support at the $140 level in late August....churning and building a new base...............It was only in the last month that investors/traders thought that maybe the market had adjusted for it and punished it enough causing some to go on a bargain hunting spree. Well - that didn't work out too well...yesterday's news sent the stock right back down to those lows.....the question now is: Will it find support in here at $140/share?

YHOO - also disappointed - and warned about what the future holds - putting Mayer's turnaround plan in jeopardy.....causing her to announce a new plan - a resetting of sorts after two top executive 'flew the coop'.....saying that the changes are 'the result of careful planning' - one should ask - who's planning was it?

More broadly - 70% of companies so far have beat on the bottom line while only 40% of companies have beat on the top revenue line...this is becoming more of a problem, causing a disconnect between fundamentals and stock prices.....despite all of the rhetoric from Washington that the economy is doing just fine......

When the recession of 2008 hit and continued to hammer earnings, stock prices eventually fell hard. Are we gearing up for another fall? Technically, we are still struggling, bulls and bears are locked in a battle.....All of the major indexes are still in a downtrend....their 50 dma's are trending below their 200 dma's and all have found resistance as they have recently approached this longer-term technical indicator. So we remain locked in a tight range.

Next up - Oil and energy stocks.....what will they say about the current state of the economy? My sense is that stocks will stay in a sideways channel (1985/2050) as long as oil prices remain in the $43 to $50 range. If oil breaks $43 then look for stocks to come under renewed pressure breaking below 1985...and if for some reason - oil pierces $50 (unlikely in the short term) then we will see renewed excitement for stocks....taking us to the longer-term resistance at 2060. Now overnight oil fell 2% and is now trading at $45.75/barrel.....which will only cause some to remain laser-focused on today's EIA report. (Energy Information Admin).

Look for reports from BA, KO, ABT, BHI, BIOGEN, NT, GM, EMC, STJ and ITW today - as well as one FED Governor - Jerome Powell who will be speaking at 1:30 pm. - Will he give us a clue about what rates will do in October? My money says - no rate hike..... .
Take good care.
Kp

The comments noted herein should not be construed as an offer to sell or the solicitation of an offer to buy or sell any financial product, or an official statement or endorsement of O'Neil Securities, Incorporated or its affiliates.Sophia Loren, Michelangelo, Benvenuto Cellini, Leonardo da Vinci, Guglielmo Marconi, Fibonacci (Leonardo Bonacci), Federico Fellini, Luciano Pavarotti - There is just a handful of famous Italians that have contributed immensely to Italian and world history ......and today - one of the most famous (and sexually charged) Italians comes to the NYSE......Today - we welcome Ferrari - ticker symbol RACE to the NYSE family of companies.Ferrari - is an Italian luxury sports car manufacturer - founded by Enzo Ferrari in 1929....originally to build race cars...in 1947 - Ferrari moved into the production of 'street legal' luxury cars. In 1969 FIAT acquired 50% of the company and in 1988 took control of 40% more taking their total stake to 90%.In 2014 Fiat Chrysler announced that it would sell 10% of the company to the public and today is the day.....expect the 'street' to be awash in testosterone as the excitement builds....Broad Street - now known as 'experience square' has a dozen Ferrari's on display - 'only to look at - no touching allowed' ...which will only serve to drive the men into a frenzy..... The IPO was priced last night at $52/share - at the high end of the range - and was 'way oversubscribed' .....so instead of raising the IPO price to cool demand - they decided to remain within the range to create the 'desire' in the aftermarket......You can feel the excitement building, the tingle in your spine, the rapid breathing, the toe curling excitement and the rush of blood as the heart beats faster and faster exploding with fury as the opening bell rings.....( What a great way to start the day - I 'm exhausted already...)Stocks chopped yesterday - as healthcare stocks got whacked over more political wrangling and investors/traders grew concerned about IBM (IBM) earnings and mounting concerns over Marissa Meyers options at Yahoo (YHOO) .......... The choppy trading on Wall Street suggests that traders are uncertain about the near-term direction of equities following the recent volatility and continuing disappointments in earnings reports and forward guidance.IBM shares dropped 5.75% (or $8.50) after the company reported lower quarterly revenue for the 14th straight quarter - they also lowered guidance for the fiscal year.So - investors and traders reacted to how far off the mark IBM's stock price was from fundamentals. The stronger dollar in this case - did hurt. The stock has been in a downtrend since July as investors began to re-price the company based on $ concerns..........breaking every support level it had only to find support at the $140 level in late August....churning and building a new base...............It was only in the last month that investors/traders thought that maybe the market had adjusted for it and punished it enough causing some to go on a bargain hunting spree. Well - that didn't work out too well...yesterday's news sent the stock right back down to those lows.....the question now is: Will it find support in here at $140/share?YHOO - also disappointed - and warned about what the future holds - putting Mayer's turnaround plan in jeopardy.....causing her to announce a new plan - a resetting of sorts after two top executive 'flew the coop'.....saying that the changes are 'the result of careful planning' - one should ask - who's planning was it?More broadly - 70% of companies so far have beat on the bottom line while only 40% of companies have beat on the top revenue line...this is becoming more of a problem, causing a disconnect between fundamentals and stock prices.....despite all of the rhetoric from Washington that the economy is doing just fine......When the recession of 2008 hit and continued to hammer earnings, stock prices eventually fell hard. Are we gearing up for another fall? Technically, we are still struggling, bulls and bears are locked in a battle.....All of the major indexes are still in a downtrend....their 50 dma's are trending below their 200 dma's and all have found resistance as they have recently approached this longer-term technical indicator. So we remain locked in a tight range.Next up - Oil and energy stocks.....what will they say about the current state of the economy? My sense is that stocks will stay in a sideways channel (1985/2050) as long as oil prices remain in the $43 to $50 range. If oil breaks $43 then look for stocks to come under renewed pressure breaking below 1985...and if for some reason - oil pierces $50 (unlikely in the short term) then we will see renewed excitement for stocks....taking us to the longer-term resistance at 2060. Now overnight oil fell 2% and is now trading at $45.75/barrel.....which will only cause some to remain laser-focused on today's EIA report. (Energy Information Admin).Look for reports from BA, KO, ABT, BHI, BIOGEN, NT, GM, EMC, STJ and ITW today - as well as one FED Governor - Jerome Powell who will be speaking at 1:30 pm. - Will he give us a clue about what rates will do in October? My money says - no rate hike..... .Take good care.KpFollow Kenny on Twitter at @kennypolcari, or on his website at Kennypolcari.comKenny Polcari is Vice President and director of NYSE Floor Operations on behalf of O'Neil Securities, Inc., a sister company of Investor's Business Daily. Ok...so what happened last night? All that hype about the China macro data kept everyone on edge over the weekend...what would they report? Would it be a disaster? What would that say about the health of the Chinese economy and then by default the global economy? In the end - it was NOT a blockbuster, in fact it was rather boring really....

At 10:00 pm est - China released a bunch of data - and it was mixed.....no disasters but no upside surprises either.........3rd Qtr GDP came in above expectations at 6.9% (exp was for 6.8%), Industrial Production did rise 5.7%, but that was below the exp of 6%. Fixed Asset Investments (FAI) - a key reading - came in at 10.3% - below the expectation of 10.8% and Retail Sales - that beat at 10.9% vs. the exp of 10.8%... So what does it all mean? Well - to start with - the data implies that the world is not ending and that the Chinese economy appears to be stabilizing - which in the end is a positive.
Angus Nicholson - Market Analyst at IG sums it up like this:

"It's hard to be overly optimistic about the headline number, especially given the range of other data released today. Nonetheless, markets have clearly been buoyed by the better than expected headline number, and it shows that China's economy has not deteriorated as much as some had thought"
James Laurenceson - Deputy Director of the Australia-China Relations Institute added that:

"The data show a rebalancing away from growth driven by investment and secondary sector production towards consumption and the services sector. It's time we accept that Chinese growth isn't solely at the mercy of industrial production and fixed asset investment"

So maybe, just maybe this is the 'new normal' for China. Maybe the world will see a China growing at a 6 handle and that's ok. Analysts are already looking out to the 4th qtr and suspect that by year end China will achieve annual growth of 6.8% -7% on continued fiscal and monetary support.

Global markets are not panicking with on these reports. In fact - there appears to be a little bit of 'risk on' as the investors/traders are relieved that the data was NOT as bad as analysts had prepared us for. Asian markets essentially ended flat. Japan - the worst performer - ended the day -0.88%, Hong Kong + 0.04%, China + 0.14% and ASX +0.03%.
European markets are also higher - discounting the China data and refocusing on earnings. FTSE flat, CAC 40 +0.32%, DAX + 0.86%, EUROSTOXX + 0.53%, SPAIN flat, and ITALY + 0.61%.

France's Danone Group up 2.5% beat estimates, Germany's Deutsche Bank +3.1%, announces a big management shakeup and restructuring plan - heads to roll and that is helping to send other financials higher. German retailer Metro - announces a rise in sales and is talking all bullish about the coming Christmas season sending this stock up by 3.7%. Air France- KLM announces job CUTS in 2016 and investors love it - sending that stock higher.... and not to be left in the dark - Italian carmaker Ferrari is getting ready to price its IPO tomorrow and will start trading on the NYSE on Thursday.

This morning US futures are off 1 pt.....Now prior to the China report - US futures were pointing lower on the expectation that we were gonna get hit hard....and when that did not happen - Futures moved to the plus side and are now flat. I suspect that the market will test resistance at 2040 and then back off trying to find support in the 2025 range - if not, then definitely the 1980 range.

As much as there is plenty of US macro data this week - the focus will now return to US corp earnings. This week and next week will see hundreds of reports for investors to chew on. Earnings to include: HAS, MS, HAL, GPC, IBM, ZION, AXP, BA, KO, MCD, MSFT, and PG to name just a few.
NOTE: Fed's Lacker is due to speak today at 12 pm.

Up til now - earnings have been, well, not so good. Not horrible, but not great. 70% are beating the estimates while only 48% of those are beating on top line revenue growth. Despite the economic weakness and a bunch of downgrades - stocks have not done so badly.....with the DOW, S&P and Nasdaq all closing close to 2 month highs.... All of these indexes have now pierced their down trending 50 dma's and are now challenging their intermediate term resistance - or 100 dma's. Now here we may hit some trouble - but I think that is just a matter of time....unless earnings completely implode - then I suspect that we will test resistance one or two more times before 'breaking out' and challenging the longer term resistance levels defined by their 200 dma's. And as is usual - as we move thru the 4th qtr - FOMO (fear of missing out) will help to lift stocks going into year end.

Now on the other hand - small caps are lagging...... The most recent lows for small caps came early October and it was much lower than the August 24th sell-off lows. The most recent highs were just two weeks ago and those highs were lower than the highs set in mid-September. - suggesting that a bearish downtrend (lower lows and lower highs) remains intact from a small cap perspective. And why would this be so?

Well - it is earnings season, and it is more common for the large cap/mid cap companies to be able to borrow money to buy back shares which will serve to 'doll up" their earnings per share. (Small cap companies are not nearly as active buying back stock to create the illusion of better earnings and so you have the disconnect.) Or it could be that small caps are more risky and at a time of global nervousness - investors may want the security of large cap, liquid, dividend paying names....It's just a thought.....

The fact that small caps continue to lag might suggest that the selling pressure is not over yet....but until we get thru earnings season the divergence will continue. Then it will be Thanksgiving, and the debt debacle in DC, and then the FED December decision.... so there is plenty ahead to keep investors on their toes the question is: Does the market have enough strength to support another "Santa Clause" rally into the end of the year?
Take good care
Kp

"Words of War" - A special evening in support of comprehensive mental healthcare for Iraq and Afghanistan Veterans will take place tonight - Monday, October 19th, 2015 - Freedom Tower - NYC.

The Headstrong Project - a veterans charitable organization begun by a returning Iraqi War Veteran - A US Marine - that not only saw but understood the impact that this war was going to have on a nation of Americans, will hold their 3rd Annual Fundraiser to help 'heal the hidden wounds of war'. In partnership with Weill Cornell Medical College - One of this nation's leading mental health care centers - The Headstrong Project has developed the first of its kind, comprehensive treatment program for veterans in need.

I am proud to be on the host committee and I am proud to participate as the evening's Live Auctioneer as we raise money to support the very men and women who answered the call. I am looking to break the record and raise $1 mil this evening and I could use your help. Please visit
Getheadstrong.org/words-of-war/
Getheadstrong.org/donate-support/
as we honor the men and women who fight valiantly for our freedom.

Earnings season is winding down, but there are still top stocks due to report, including drug giant Actavis (ACT), one of several drug stocks reporting earnings that day, including Intrexon (XON), Impax Laboratories (IPXL) and Juno Therapeutics (JUNO). Actavis is on the IBD 50 list of the very best stocks. Three other IBD 50 stocks — Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN), Monster…
Stocks bolted higher in quiet trade Friday after a mixed April jobs report pointed to no near-term rate hike from the Federal Reserve.

The Dow Jones industrial average jumped out to a 1.4% gain. The Nasdaq and the S&P 500 swung up 1.2% each. Volume was mixed, a shade higher on the Nasdaq and down 8% on the NYSE, compared to action at the same time Thursday.

The stock market today got what it wanted — a generally weak April payrolls report. Payrolls expanded slightly more than expected for the month, to 223,000 vs. consensus estimates for 220,000. That was a positive. But private employers added fewer new jobs than expected, and the Labor Department sharply revised its March estimate downward to 85,000 new hires from an initial 123,000. Even more important, from a market standpoint, was the average hourly earnings number: up 0.1%. That compared to a 0.3% increase in March and economist projections for a 0.2% gain. The number has become a crucial metric for the Federal Reserve in deciding whether and when to raise target interest rates.
A week wage number suggests no rate increase. And no rate increase from the Fed means more cheap money for longer. So investors piled back into stocks Friday after two days of jittery nerves.
A full 30% of the Nasdaq 100 stocks posted gains of 2% or more. NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) and Tractor Supply (TSCO) led, up 3% each. Also up 3% were Home Depot (HD) and Boeing (BA), topping the Dow.

WhiteWave Foods (WWAV) popped almost 8% at the open on generally positive first-quarter results. Earnings per share cleared consensus forecasts by two cents, while revenue growth of 10% stopped just shy of expectations. Management's Q2 and full-year sales and earnings guidance was at or above consensus. The heavy-volume, gap-up gain left shares at a new high.

Cruise fleet operators were hopping, with Royal Caribbean (RCL) torquing up 4% and Norwegian Cruise Line (NCLH) climbing 3%. The Miami-based Royal announced late Thursday its capital spending outlook for the next five years, and that it had ordered a fourth "quantum" class ship for delivery in 2019. Norwegian shares jumped for a second day, now up 10% for the week after reporting a strong first quarter on Thursday.
Despite all the jubilation, there were losers.

Monster Beverage (MNST) dropped 10% after its transition in distribution rights linked to its deal with Coca-Cola (KO) took a bigger bite than expected from first-quarter earnings. The loss sent shares well below their 10-week moving average in powerful trade.

Medivation (MDVN) crumbled almost 5% after its Q1 earnings didn't rise far enough and a 48% surge in revenue missed consensus targets. Collaboration revenue from sales of its prostate cancer treatment Xtandi rose 81% in the U.S. and 177% overseas. The stock had been struggling below its 10-week moving average for two weeks, and is now 17% below its late-March high.Stocks bolted higher in quiet trade Friday after a mixed April jobs report pointed to no near-term rate hike from the Federal Reserve.The Dow Jones industrial average jumped out to a 1.4% gain.
