Refiners are finding a place among the market leadership in the current stock market. Oil refiners Tesoro (TSO) and Phillips 66 (PSX) nailed the No. 18 and No. 44 slots in Monday's IBD 50. Both stocks, though, are extended from buy points, which makes them too risky to buy. An extended stock can trigger the 8% sell rule with normal action.
However, the Stock Spotlight screen offers another refining stock — big cap Valero Energy (VLO) — and it is just under a 71.60 buy point.
Valero has built three first-stage bases since mid-2014. Breakouts from the first two led to gains of 8% and 10%, which is why the base count remains early stage.
The current base began forming in August. While the pattern shows neither net distribution nor net accumulation, the up-down volume ratio is a bullish 1.8.
Refiners are doing well because lower crude oil prices improve margins for the gasoline that refiners produce.

In the first nine months of 2015, for example, gasoline profit margins increased sharply. Valero estimates that the jump in gasoline margins per barrel boosted Valero's refining margin about $1.8 billion.
Margins for other Valero refined products — such as petroleum coke, sulfur and propane — also ballooned. Over nine months, the boost helped these other products' margins to the tune of $1.3 billion.
Revenue on a year-earlier basis, though, plunged 37%, 28% and 34% in the past three quarters, largely because of the decrease in refined product prices.
The cost of sales, however, decreased even more, which is how Valero reaped earnings increases of 21%, 118% and 39% in recent quarters.
The Street expects full-year earnings to increase 30% this year but slide 20% in 2016. An earnings decrease in 2016 is also seen for other refiners, such as Tesoro and Phillips 66.

Valero recently hiked its quarterly dividend from 40 cents to 50 cents a share.Refiners are finding a place among the market leadership in the current stock market. In a day of broad losses in the Weekly Review screen, one stock stood out with a bullish price move. Coca-Cola Bottling Consolidated (COKE) broke out of a base, clearing the 174.20 buy point of an odd-shaped double-bottom base. Volume was 50% above average. The base was late-stage, which made it riskier than the earlier patterns from which the stock broke out.

The nation's largest independent Coke bottler agreed to purchase plants in Virginia, Maryland, Indiana and Ohio in a deal that expands the bottler's distribution territory. Coca-Cola Bottling said that it is still working with Coca-Cola (KO) for the rest of a territorial expansion, first agreed on in May, that includes distribution territories in Ohio, Indiana, Illinois and Kentucky.

The deal is part of the sale of nine plants to Coca-Cola Bottling, Swire Coca-Cola USA and Coca-Cola Bottling Co. United, Bloomberg reported. The soft drink giant is selling the facilities to cut costs and streamline operations.
Quite a few other Weekly Review stocks are getting close to possible buy points. Some of the better bases are in regional banks.

Heritage Commerce (HTBK) is almost touching the 11.79 buy point of a cup-shaped base. Opus Bank (OPB), BNC Bancorp (BNCN) and HomeTrust Bancshares (HTBI) are forming the right side of well-shaped bases.
Most regional banks are thinly traded, which can diminish their institutional sponsorship.
The banking industry groups are not leading the market, but stocks have been rising on hopes that higher interest rates will result in better margins.
Some of the stocks forming bases remain below the 10-week moving average. Watch for shares to rise above those levels as an indication of their basing progress.

Although investors can find high-rated stocks near buy points, they need to remember that market risk is higher than normal.In a day of broad losses in the Weekly Review screen, one stock stood out with a bullish price move. Coca-Cola Bottling Consolidated (COKE) broke out of a base, clearing the 174.20 buy point of an odd-shaped double-bottom base. Volume was 50% above average. The base was late-stage, which made it riskier than the earlier patterns from which the stock broke out.The nation's largest independent Coke bottler agreed to purchase plants in Virginia, Maryland, Indiana and Ohio in a deal that expands the bottler's distribution territory. Coca-Cola Bottling said that it is still working with Coca-Cola (KO) for the rest of a territorial expansion, first agreed on in May, that includes distribution territories in Ohio, Indiana, Illinois and Kentucky.The deal is part of the sale of nine plants to Coca-Cola Bottling, Swire Coca-Cola USA and Coca-Cola Bottling Co. United, Bloomberg reported. The soft drink giant is selling the facilities to cut costs and streamline operations.Quite a few other Weekly Review stocks are getting close to possible buy points. Some of the better bases are in regional banks.Heritage Commerce (HTBK) is almost touching the 11.79 buy point of a cup-shaped base. Monster Beverage (MNST) flexed its muscles with double-digit sales gains across retail channels last month as more consumers opted to quench their thirst with its energy drinks.Monster's dollar sales were up a solid 11.2% from a year earlier during the four-week period ending Sept. 5, according to a report on beverage sales by Wells Fargo Securities analyst Bonnie Herzog, citing Nielsen's "all channel" data — including grocery, drug, mass, and convenience stores.Monster's unit sales were up 12.6% from a year earlier during the period and its average unit pricing was down 1.3%.Monster's lineup of energy drinks now include Coca-Cola (KO) energy brands as a part of a partnership deal with the soft drink giant that closed in June. Under the pact, Coke transferred ownership of its energy drink business to Monster and in return, Monster transferred its non-energy drink business to Coke. Coke has also become Monster's preferred global distribution partner.Coke now owns about 16.7% stake in Monster.The energy drink category overall remained strong during the month with dollar sales up 11.1% vs. a year earlier, Herzog noted in her report.Rockstar led the pack with a hefty 29.5% gain in dollar sales for the month.Energy drink hot shot Red Bull saw a 9.4% increase in dollar sales for the four-week period.But total carbonated soft drink dollar sales (excluding energy drinks) in all channels fizzled with a 1.0% decline for the month, noted Herzog.Coke's dollar sales overall were up 2.2% vs. a year earlier for the four-week period amid "solid growth" from juices, water, and teas, which "partially offset declines" in carbonated soft drinks, Herzog noted.Pepsico (PEP) saw dollar sales rise 0.9% during the month, according to the report. "Soft" results in carbonated soft drinks were "offset" by "slight growth" in snacks and by "solid" growth in water, sports drinks, and shelf-stable juices, Herzog noted.Pepsi recently expanded an alliance with home-based Sodastream (SODA). That comes as Keurig Green Mountain (GMCR) and Coca-Cola are developing Keurig Kold device for soft drinks. Coke also owns a significant stake in Keurig Green Mountain.Dollar sales for Dr Pepper Snapple Group (DPS) were up 2.2% during the four-week period, driven by "modest growth" in carbonated soft drinks and "strong" results in juices and teas, Herzog noted.Monster is part of IBD's Beverage-Non-Alcoholic industry group, where it ranks No. 2 with a Composite Rating of 95 out of a possible 99. Coca-Cola Bottling (COKE) ranks No. 1 with a Composite Rating of 99.Monster's stock closed up 1.1% to 133.93 Wednesday in the stock market today. Coca-Cola Co. closed up 1.7% to 39.15, Pepsi closed up 1.1% to 93.07 and Dr Pepper closed up 0.6% to 77.26 . Keurig Green Mountain (GMCR) closed up 3.5% to 60.15 and SodaStream (SODA) closed up 3.7% to 15.59.Correction: The original article misidentified Rockstar's owner. Rockstar is an independent energy drinks firm.

Led by consumer electronics giant Apple (AAPL), technology companies continue to have the most valuable brands in the world, though athletic gear maker Nike (NKE) and industrial giant General Electric (GE) also earned top spots.

Apple's brand is valued at $170.28 billion, up 43% from a year ago, Interbrand said. Technology companies accounted for six of the top 10 and a third of the $1.71 trillion value of all brands on the market tracker's latest top 100 list, released Sunday.
Apple was No. 1 for the third year in a row, followed by Alphabet's (GOOGL) Google, valued at $120.31 billion (up 12%), and Coca-Cola (KO) with $78.42 billion (down 4%).
Microsoft (MSFT) was No. 4 with $67.67 billion (up 11%), and IBM (IBM) was No. 5 with $65.1 billon (down 10%).
Apple shares closed up 0.4% in Monday trading on the stock market today. Alphabet rose 2.2%. Coca-Cola gained 1.5%, Microsoft 2.3% and IBM 3%.

Rounding out the top 10 were Toyota (TM) valued at $49.05 billion (up 16%), Samsung at $45.3 billion (unchanged), General Electric at $42.28 billion (down 7%), McDonald's (MCD) at $39.81 billion (down 6%), and Amazon.com (AMZN) at $37.95 billion (up 29%).
Among other notable names, entertainment and media conglomerate Disney (DIS) was No. 13 with $36.5 billion, and Nike was No. 17 with $23.1 billion.
Five brands that saw the steepest increases in value were Facebook (FB) (up 54%), Apple, Amazon, Paris-based luxury goods company Hermes (up 22%), and Nissan Motor (NSANY) which rose 22% to No. 41.

Interbrand, a division of Omnicom Group (OMC), identifies the 100 most valuable global brands by analyzing the ways that a brand benefits an organization — from delivering on customer expectations to driving economic value.

China's faltering economy and markets sent stocks worldwide spiraling Monday to their worst drops in years. Analysts expect U.S. equities and the economy to weather the storm, but China itself must navigate a delicate economic balancing act.

The Shanghai Composite dived 8.5% to a fresh bear-market low, bleeding into U.S. and European trading. After big losses last week, the Dow fell over 1,000 points intraday and the Nasdaq 8.8%. The major averages closed down nearly 4%.

"This is a made-in-China problem that's been transmitted around the world," said David Rosenberg, chief economist for Gluskin Sheff. "China packs a very powerful punch through its impact on trade and the plunge in commodities."

"The good news is that if there is a central bank on the planet that has the capacity to ease the old-fashioned way, either through interest rates or bank reserve ratios, the People's Bank of China has that latitude more than anyone else," he said.

China's economy and markets have recently made that "powerful punch" feel more like a jab-and-cross. Equities have plunged 40% since June, and PBOC efforts to control the rout have been small-scale, scattershot and ineffective, leading many analysts to question the Communist government's competence.

Every fresh report seems to confirm that China's economy is braking much harder than the government wants. A flash manufacturing reading for August released last week was a deeply contractionary 47.1 — the lowest since 2009. July exports slid 8.3% vs. a year earlier, much worse than expected. The central bank devalued the yuan two weeks ago, setting off a cascade across other currencies, especially in emerging markets.

For years, China powered commodity demand. But with its raw materials appetite waning, the Bloomberg Commodity Index on Monday reached its lowest level since 1999. U.S. crude hit a fresh 6-year low, falling 5.5% to $38.24 a barrel. That's hit commodity-driven nations hard, sending Brazil and Russia into recession.
Great Fall Of China

The "great fall of China" comes at a precarious moment for global markets. Investors are on edge over a possible Federal Reserve rate hike in September. The eurozone has averted a break up, but growth remains lackluster.
And investors are realizing that if there's another global financial crisis like 1998 or 2008, most central banks this time are essentially out of ammunition.
But Rosenberg and other analysts aren't concerned.

"Comparisons between the present and the Asian crisis of 1997-1998 seem a stretch because, among other things, the relative FX reserves positions of China and the rest of Asia are very different," Cornerstone Macro economists wrote in a Monday note.
Most analysts expect the Chinese authorities to step up with decisive action. The lack of weekend signals from Beijing drove Monday's rout, Rosenberg noted.
Reform Vs. Bailout

China's government is caught between competing priorities: liberalizing markets and propping them up. Most experts believe the recent devaluation was a bid to link the yuan more closely to markets, not a beggar-thy-neighbor effort to boost exports.

China also is struggling to manage an economic transition to smaller private firms and the service sector. New stimulus could boost inefficient state-owned enterprises and spur more regional government vanity projects.
Yet for U.S. investors there are many reasons to stay bullish.
The 10-year Treasury yield fell to 2% as investors fled to safety, but its growth component is firm.
"The Treasury market has upgraded significantly the U.S. growth outlook since China devalued," Cornerstone Macro economists wrote, a trend that's continued since the spring.
Rosenberg notes that multiple housing gauges are at their highest levels since before the financial crisis, and Home Depot (HD) just upped its guidance again.

In the U.S., at least,"It's increasingly a market that's going to be driven by earnings, not by multiple expansions courtesy of the central banks," he said.China's faltering economy and markets sent stocks worldwide spiraling Monday to their worst drops in years. Stocks dropped out of the starting gate Tuesday, as investors processed news of a downed jet, a global travel alert and a sharp drop in consumer confidence.
The Nasdaq dropped to a 0.6% loss. The S&P 500 hung 0.5% below the line, and the Dow Jones industrial average slipped 0.4%
Volume rose sharply, up 43% on the Nasdaq and 17% higher on the NYSE, compared with very weak levels early Monday.

The stock market today reflected, among other things, uncertainty tied to the downing of a Russian jet near the Turkish-Syrian border and the release of an alert to American travelers by the U.S. State Department.

Details were not yet clear on the downing of the Russian fighter. Turkish sources said a Turkish F-16 shot down the Russian aircraft after warnings it was violating Turkey's airspace. Russian officials reportedly denied the account, saying the warplane had not violated protocol, was flying at 6,000 meters and was shot down from the ground.

The State Department's travel alert advised Americans to be wary while traveling. "The likelihood of terror attacks will continue," the alert said, "as members of ISIL/Da'esh return from Syria and Iraq." The alert cautioned travelers to "be aware of immediate surroundings and avoid large crowds or crowded places."
The result sent airlines and travel-booking stocks to some of the mornings worst losses. Oil prices surged, lifting oil-related groups to 8 of the 10 best gains among industry groups in early trade.
The conflict and warnings overpowered an as-expected revision to Q3 GDP growth from the Commerce Department, lifting the economy's performance to a 2.1% gain vs. an initial estimate of 1.5% growth.

Case-Shiller's 20-City Home Price Index for September was also mildly positive, showing a 5.5% year-over-year gain — above consensus views for a 5.3% increase. Prices advanced 0.6% vs. August, better than projections for a 0.3% improvement.

Consumers' outlook fell hard in November, with the Conference Board reporting its Consumer Confidence Index pulled back to 90.4, far below October's 97.6 tally and an optimistic consensus view for an upshift to 99.6.

At the top of the S&P 500, Campbell Soup (CPB) ladled up a 5% advance at the start of trade. The Camden, N.J.-based soup, sauce and broth maker reported a strong fiscal-first-quarter earnings beat and revenue in line with consensus expectations. Management projected lower sales but EPS above consensus expectations.

Chipmaker Analog Devices (ADI) popped 4%, boosted by a 49% surge in fiscal Q3 EPS, vs. consensus views for a 20% gain. Revenue also topped forecasts, and first-quarter sales and earnings guidance was in line with expectations.

At the low end of the S&P 500, weaker-than-forecast quarterly reports sent X-ray and veterinary supplies firm Patterson (PDCO) and retail chain Signet Jewelers (SIG) each down 5%. The loss left Signet, an IBD 50 stock, just above its 200-day moving average and down 13% from an Oct. 13 high. GameStop (GME) dropped 3% as Oppenheimer added its name to the list of brokerages downgrading the video game retailer after reporting a Q3 sales and earnings miss on Monday.

About 80% of the IBD 50 list traded lower in early action, but Dycom (DY) and Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) chalked out the high end, up nearly 2% each. The gain put Dycom out of buy range, nearly 9% past a flat base buy point of 80.95.
Skyworks continues to feel its way along the underside of its 50-day moving average, bound up in a five-month consolidation.

Among leaders on IBD's Your Weekly Review list, Maxlinear (MXL) surged 5%, taking out a new high. The Carlsbad, Cal.-based chipmaker is 33% past a 13.06 buy point after an early October breakout.Stocks dropped out of the starting gate Tuesday, as investors processed news of a downed jet, a global travel alert and a sharp drop in consumer confidence.The Nasdaq dropped to a 0.6% loss. Stocks bounced out of the three-day holiday weekend, reversing early losses into thin gains on rising oil prices and mixed economic data.
The Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq added 0.1% each. The S&P 500 ticked up 0.2% as a cross-section of industries edged higher.

Early action in the stock market today showed an already stressed uptrend under additional pressure. But volume was soft, and the Nasdaq managed to hold just above its 50-day moving average. The S&P 500 rose for a third test of resistance at that line.

Crude oil prices were a key influence on Monday's early trade. Oil prices added to early gains, with the U.S. benchmark West Texas Intermediate crude up nearly 3% to above $50 per barrel. Europe's Brent crude rose more than 3% to near $57. Currencies were also a factor, with the euro pushing back above 1.10 to the dollar.
While Friday's weak March payrolls report dragged on stocks, Monday's economic news was mixed.
Researcher Markit reported its March service purchasing managers' index rose to 59.2, up from 57.1 in February and above forecasts for 58.4.
The Institute for Supply Management's March service index slipped to 56.5. That was down from 56.9 in February and a shade less than forecasts for 56.7.

In stocks, the Dow was about evenly split, up vs. down, at the open. Its biggest losers were JPMorgan (JPM) and Johnson & Johnson (JNJ), down 1% apiece. McDonald's (MCD) and Coca-Cola (KO) led the index, up a bit less than 0.5% each.

Barbie maker Mattel (MAT) spiked 6% in early action. B. Riley & Co. upgraded the stock to buy from neutral and boosted the price target to 27.50 from 26. It based its upgrade on new Chief Executive Chris Sinclair and his clear turnaround strategy. Mattel shares remain deep in a 14-month consolidation.

Tesla Motors (TSLA) whirred up 5% after announcing on Friday that deliveries of its luxury battery-powered cars rose 55% in the first quarter, above analyst expectations. The gain positioned the stock for a test of resistance at its 10-week moving average, but still deep in a six-month consolidation.
Most of the IBD 50 list slipped at the starting bell. The worst losses went to Alaska Air Group (ALK) and M/A-Com Technology (MTSI), which dropped 2% each.

On the upside, Cambrex (CBM) sneaked ahead 2% to a new high, adding to last week's 16% gain. Riley & Co. upgraded the stock to buy from neutral and boosted the price target to 27.50 from 26. It based its upgrade on new Chief Executive Chris Sinclair and his clear turnaround strategy. Mattel shares remain deep in a 14-month consolidation.Tesla Motors (TSLA) whirred up 5% after announcing on Friday that deliveries of its luxury battery-powered cars rose 55% in the first quarter, above analyst expectations. The gain positioned the stock for a test of resistance at its 10-week moving average, but still deep in a six-month consolidation.Most of the IBD 50 list slipped at the starting bell. The worst losses went to Alaska Air Group (ALK) and M/A-Com Technology (MTSI), which dropped 2% each.On the upside, Cambrex (CBM) sneaked ahead 2% to a new high, adding to last week's 16% gain. IPG Photonics (IPGP) rose 1%, still looking for enough loft to rebound from its 10-week moving average.

Ball (BLL) confirmed its offer to buy U.K.-based can maker Rexam in a merger that will create the world's largest metal and plastic packaging maker for beverages, food, aerospace and other industries. The proposed $6.8 billion cash and stock purchase, valued at $8.4 billion including assumption of net debt, will likely face regulatory scrutiny. Broomfield, Colo.-based Ball said the deal…
SodaStream (SODA) shares sank to a new low Wednesday as the company said U.S. demand for its home-carbonation systems fell during the holiday quarter.

Revenue tumbled 24.7% in the fourth quarter to $126.5 million, falling short of analysts' expectations for $127.1 million. Earnings shot up to 35 cents a share from 3 cents a year ago, topping estimates for 18 cents.
In addition to weak U.S. demand, the company attributed the sales drop to an unfavorable foreign-currency exchange rate and the elimination of promotional activity that had occurred during Q4 2013.

Shares were down nearly 7% on the stock market today. The stock is down 61% since late April and has been under pressure since Keurig Green Mountain (GMCR) said early last year that it is developing a cold-beverage machine with Coca-Cola (KO).

SodaStream said it recorded $15.6 million in pre-tax charges in Q4 related to its restructuring and growth plan, which included transitioning to a new plant in southern Israel and transforming product lines.
The company is trying to reposition itself as a wellness tool rather than a soda replacement, as health-conscious consumers edge away from soft drinks.

"We are confident that repositioning the brand around health and wellness and launching a completely new portfolio of water-enhanced flavors fits perfectly with the changing nature of consumer demands and will re-accelerate participation in our home carbonation system," said CEO Daniel Birnbaum in a statement.

Shares of Monster Beverage (MNST) may seem dull, but a stock chart analysis shows some bullish characteristics. The stock has been in a narrow price range for a few weeks. It has declined as much as 7% from its peak on Feb. 27, which means that it could form a flat base in short order. Even if it doesn't, the…
Keurig Green Mountain (GMCR) is repurchasing about half of Italian coffee maker Luigi Lavazza's stake for approximately $624 million.
Lavazza owned a 6.6% stake in the at-home beverage maker as of Feb. 4, down from 7.8% in late January.
Keurig said Monday it is buying back about 5.2 million shares from Lavazza at 119.18, which represents a 3% discount from the stock's closing price on Friday.
Keurig said the deal eliminates Lavazza's pre-emptive rights on future issuances of the company's common stock.

Keurig shares gained 1.1% to 124.24 on the stock market today. The stock's 50-day line is close to falling below its 200-day line, which is a signal that its current movement is lagging its long-term performance. Keurig has a low IBD Composite Rating of 41, meaning its shares outperform just 41% of all stocks in the market as measured by fundamental and technical factors.
Earlier this month, Coca-Cola (KO) raised its stake in Keurig to 16%.
The Wholesale-Food group is ranked No. 138 out of the 197 industry groups IBD tracks, led by United Natural Foods (UNFI) and Core Mark Holdings (CORE) .

Last week in this space, several Big Cap 20 stocks showing healthy earnings and sales increases were discussed. This week's column asks the question: Which Big Cap 20 names are making the most out of their sales growth? In other words, how much profit are they generating from each dollar of sales? Profit margin tells you that. And how well…

When his father's business failed, Caleb Bradham had to drop out of medical school and go back home to North Carolina. But he didn't dwell on the setback. Instead, he found a teaching job at a school in New Bern, N.C., saved up money and in 1892 bought a corner drugstore that he called Bradham's Pharmacy. The rest is history.…

With interest rates at record lows in the past several years, ETFs that invest in dividend-paying stocks have been a popular income alternative for some investors. But will they remain advantageous now that the Federal Reserve is seriously considering hiking rates?It depends on the specific investment objectives of each fund, according to Michael Rawson, research analyst at Morningstar Inc."When you look at stocks with a high dividend payout, they typically underperform when the economy is doing well," he says. "Those companies usually invest less in future growth (utilities, REITs, consumer staples), therefore they don't participate as much when the economy is growing very rapidly."Vanguard High Dividend Yield Index ETF (VYM) has over $10 billion in assets and a 12-month yield (net of fees) of 2.72%. However, it is tilted toward value stocks, notes Rawson, so it is not the most favorable to be in when the economy is growing.So what should an investor look at when considering a dividend ETF?Value Stock Tilt?Rawson says it's important to consider whether an ETF "is tilting toward higher-yielding dividend-paying stocks, which tend to be value stocks, or does it tilt toward stocks which might grow their dividend in the future?"Companies that are able to increase their dividends consistently are usually companies with very strong brand names or very strong market positions," he notes. An example is Apple (AAPL), which yields 1.5%, though its dividend hasn't been steady.Dividend growth is one of the reasons he likes $21 billion Vanguard Dividend Appreciation ETF (VIG). It looks for companies that have raised their dividends for 10 straight years. It has a lower yield at 1.91%, but focuses on quality stocks, thus having a slightly bigger exposure to growth companies.In addition, it has a razor-thin expense ratio of 0.10%. It has returned an average annual 14.15% in the past three years vs. the S&P 500's 16.57% advance. Top holdings are Wal-Mart Stores (WMT), PepsiCo (PEP), Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) and Coca-Cola (KO)."If the Fed were likely to raise rates, I think Vanguard High Dividend Yield might get hurt more than Vanguard Dividend Appreciation," Rawson said.Another element to consider is the fund's tilt toward size: whether it's in large-cap or small-cap stocks.IShares Select Dividend (DVY) is one of the highest-yielding ETFs with a 3.03% yield. But the $15 billion fund is tilted toward midcap deep-value stocks, which can make it more volatile. In addition, its 0.39% expense ratio makes it one of the more expensive dividend ETFs, notes Morningstar analyst Abby Woodham in her report.When the Fed raises rates, investors might consider shifting out of stocks and more toward bonds, said Rawson. The reasons people usually hold bonds is for income, diversification and stability. The reason why dividend ETFs are not always a good substitute for bond ETFs is that they don't have the stability of bonds, he said.Investors also need to be mindful of expenses. If those are high, they tend to eat into the yield of the ETF.Cheapest ETF AvailableSchwab U.S. Dividend Equity ETF (SCHD) is the cheapest among all dividend ETFs, with an expense ratio of just 0.07%. With nearly $3 billion in assets, it has a pretty attractive yield of 2.58%, while still maintaining the focus on quality stocks.It looks at companies that have paid dividends in the past 10 years and selects those that do well on fundamental metrics such cash flow/debt, return on equity, dividend yield and dividend growth. It's returned an average annual 15.93% in the past three years. Top holdings are Pfizer (PFE), Verizon Communications (VZ), Chevron (CVX) and Exxon Mobil (XOM).International funds tend to provide higher yields, but investors need to be able to stomach higher volatility due to currency fluctuations. The dollar's recent strength has hit the returns of nonhedged ETFs such as the WisdomTree Emerging Markets Equity Income Fund (DEM) and iShares International Select Dividend (IDV).

Wall Street was sweet on PepsiCo (PEP) Wednesday after the snack and soda company topped fourth-quarter expectations and announced a share buyback program for up to $12 billion of common stock.Its annualized dividend also will grow 7.3% to $2.81 a share, and the company expects 7% earnings growth for the year — above analyst estimates for 2.6% growth to $4.75 a share."As we look ahead to 2015, we expect to again deliver results consistent with our long-term financial objectives, despite the anticipated challenging and volatile global macro environment," CEO Indra Nooyi said in the company's earnings release. "Further, returning cash to shareholders remains a top priority, and we plan to return approximately $8.5 to $9 billion to shareholders through both higher dividends and share repurchases."Shares were up 1.9% on the stock market today, climbing further above their 50-day line after retaking it Tuesday.In Q4, earnings excluding items grew 6.7% to $1.12 a share, above views by 4 cents. Including restructuring and impairment charges, the remeasurement of monetary assets at Venezuelan entities, a pension lump sum settlement charge, and mark-to-market net losses on commodity hedges, PepsiCo earned $1.3 billion, or 87 cents a share.Revenue was negatively impacted by foreign exchange translation, including "significant currency volatility" in Russia and Venezuela, and dipped 0.8% to $19.95 billion. But that still beat consensus estimates for $19.66 billion.Cheetos and SunChips maker Frito-Lay North America grew net revenue by 3%, while Quaker Foods North America revenue fell 2%.Asia, Middle East and Africa segment revenue rose 4%, but the stronger dollar bogged down the Latin America Foods segment, with net revenue dipping 0.5% despite an 11% rise in organic revenue driven by growth in Venezuela, Argentina and Brazil. Net revenue in Europe fell 10% in spite of a 6% rise in organic revenue, also hit by foreign exchange translations.PepsiCo Americas Beverages revenue edged up 1% as the soda maker said it claimed more market share.Mondelez International (MDLZ) also reported Wednesday, beating Q4 earnings views by 4 cents with an 11.9% bump to 47 cents a share. But the Oreos and Ritz crackers maker missed sales estimates slightly with a 6.9% year-over-year decline to $8.83 billion. The company said it expects adjusted per-share earnings to "increase at a double-digit rate."Beverage giant Coca-Cola (KO) beat Q4 views Tuesday with earnings of 44 cents a share on revenue of $10.9 billion. Coke, too, said it expects to be dogged by a volatile macro environment.Dr. Pepper Snapple (DPS) reports on Thursday.Follow Elaine Low on Twitter: @IBD_ELow.
Stocks added to gains and were near session highs midday Tuesday.
The Nasdaq led with a 0.8% advance. The S&P and Dow Jones industrial average each added 0.5%. Volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq was tracking close to Monday's levels.
Stocks bounced back from a two-day slide as the major indexes grappled for support at their 50-day lines.
Small caps lagged in the stock market today, with the Russell 2000 edging up 0.1%.

Coca-Cola (KO) paced the Dow with a 3% gain in big trade after reporting fourth-quarter earnings. Earnings and sales fell less than expected, and the company reaffirmed 2015 guidance for slightly positive revenue growth.

IBD 50 member Spirit Airlines (SAVE) added 2% in heavy volume after reporting a 43% jump in Q4 earnings, topping expectations. Revenue for the discount airliner increased 13%, but just missed forecasts. The stock is working on a new base, with an 80.97 early buy point.

Baidu (BIDU) added 2% in above-average volume. The stock is rebounding from the lows of a potential new base ahead of its fourth-quarter earnings Wednesday after the close.Stocks added to gains and were near session highs midday Tuesday.The Nasdaq led with a 0.8% advance. The S&P and Dow Jones industrial average each added 0.5%. Volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq was tracking close to Monday's levels.Stocks bounced back from a two-day slide as the major indexes grappled for support at their 50-day lines.Small caps lagged in the stock market today, with the Russell 2000 edging up 0.1%.Coca-Cola (KO) paced the Dow with a 3% gain in big trade after reporting fourth-quarter earnings. Earnings and sales fell less than expected, and the company reaffirmed 2015 guidance for slightly positive revenue growth.IBD 50 member Spirit Airlines (SAVE) added 2% in heavy volume after reporting a 43% jump in Q4 earnings, topping expectations. Revenue for the discount airliner increased 13%, but just missed forecasts. The stock is working on a new base, with an 80.97 early buy point.Baidu (BIDU) added 2% in above-average volume. The stock is rebounding from the lows of a potential new base ahead of its fourth-quarter earnings Wednesday after the close.

Warren Buffett-led Berkshire Hathaway (BRKB) late Friday reported a 8% increase in first-quarter revenue to $52.4 billion, led by a 19% surge in insurance business revenue to $42.64 billion.But railroad, utilities and energy revenue slid 11% to $8.85 billion amid a slump in the railroad industry due to fewer shipments of coal, oil and other commodities. Finance and financial products revenue grew 14% to $1.39 billion.Net earnings rose 8.1% to $5.66 billion.Berkshire, which is a major shareholder in American Express (AXP), Wells Fargo (WFC), Coca-Cola (KO), IBM (IBM) and Kraft Heinz (KHC), said investments in equity securities dropped 4.8% to $106.4 billion in Q1 from $111.8 billion in Q4.Berkshire Class B shares were down less than 0.2% in after-hours trading after closing up 0.5% at 144.62 on the stock market today. Its stock hit an intraday low of 123.55 on Feb. 3 and bounced up about 17% since then, trading above both its 10-week and 200-day averages.

Monster Beverage (MNST)  shares jumped Friday after the beverage maker reported first-quarter results above Wall Street views and announced a buyback program.The energy drink maker earned 80 cents a share during the quarter, six cents above forecasts. Revenue rose 16% to $680.18 million, above views for $656.8 million.Case sales rose 25.6% to 72.6 million. Gross sales rose 9.5% to $777.5 million. Gross sales to customers outside the U.S. rose 31% to $184.4 million and overall gross profit widened to 62.2% from 58.9%.Monster also announced a $2 billion share repurchase program via a modified "Dutch auction" tender offer.Monster shares soared 12.8% to close at 144.22 in the stock market today, jumping over its 50-day and 200-day lines."The continued strength of the U.S. dollar, distributor transitions and uncertainties in portions of our international non-Coca-Cola (KO) distribution network also impacted our results," said CEO Rodney Sacks, in the earnings report.Monster completed the acquisition of its principal flavor supplier, American Fruits and Flavors, on April 1. The move "secures our ownership of the unique intellectual property of many of our key flavors," according to Sacks, who added that the company's distribution deal with Coca-Cola bottlers abroad is progressing well. Monster Energy drinks will be on shelves in New Zealand and Australia in May through a partnership with Coca-Cola Amatil."In the United States, the Coca-Cola bottlers have expanded the number of outlets in which Monster Energy drinks are available, and we are seeing improvements in our levels of distribution," Sacks said.Coca-Cola, which distributes Monster's drinks, took a 17% stake last year. Coca-Cola and Monster swapped drinks, with Coke giving Monster its energy drinks and Monster handing over its non-energy offerings.Coca-Cola shares rose 0.4%.

Adobe Systems (ADBE) on Tuesday announced an agreement to acquire audience-engagement firm Livefyre to bolster its Adobe Marketing Cloud services.Terms of the deal were not disclosed. Livefyre is a privately held company based in San Francisco.San Jose, Calif.-based Adobe plans to integrate Livefyre into its Adobe Experience Manager, allowing customers to collect, curate and publish user-generated content from major social networks into their own marketing channels.“With this acquisition, our customers will be able to unify the best social media content with branded experiences created in Adobe Creative Cloud and community-driven content in Adobe Behance and Adobe Stock,” Aseem Chandra, vice president of Adobe Experience Manager and Adobe Target, said in a statement.Bringing together branded and curated social content from Twitter (TWTR), Facebook (FB), Instagram and other social networks will provide an opportunity for marketers to further drive customer engagement and conversion, Adobe said in a press release.Livefyre customers include Time Warner's (TWX) CNN, the Coca-Cola Co. (KO), Cox Media Group, Hallmark, Intel (INTC), Kimberly-Clark (KMB), Major League Baseball, News Corp. (NWSA), the PGA Tour, Univision and Warner Music Group.Adobe is a top-rated stock on IBD's Leaderboard chart. The media software company is trading just below its all-time high of 98, reached on March 18. It would hit a buy point out of a flat base at 98.10.Adobe stock fell 1.3% to 93.66 on the stock market today but rose more than 1% after hours.RELATED:Adobe Teams With Box To Improve Digital Document Workflow.

Mondelez International (MDLZ) beat first-quarter estimates amid cost cuts and rising volumes, joining names like Procter & Gamble (PG), Coca-Cola (KO) and big banks that have relied on cuts to improve profit.Excluding items, the maker of Oreo cookies, Ritz crackers and Cadbury chocolates earned 48 cents a share in Q1, up 17% from a year earlier and nine cents better than estimates of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Including items, Mondelez earned $554 million, or 35 cents a share, compared to Q1 2015's $324 million, or 19 cents a share.Revenue fell 17% to $6.5 billion, beating estimates of $6.4 billion. It was the 10th straight quarter of revenue declines for the company.Volumes rose in North America, Europe and the Asia Pacific region but fell in Latin America and the region of Eastern Europe, the Middle East and Africa. Mondelez reaffirmed its full-year guidance.Slowing emerging markets, the strong dollar and consumers shifting their tastes away from sugary food have impacted the company. Activist investors Pershing Square Capital Management and Trian Fund Management also have been pressuring Mondelez to improve its performance.In response, the company has introduced healthier new products, cut costs and sold its coffee businesses. Its gross margin rose to 39.3% from 37.9%, while its operating margin rose to 11.2% from 10.4%.Mondelez says that it expects the dollar to be less of a drag and predicts that it will reduce net revenue growth by around three percentage points, in contrast to its previous estimate of six percentage points.Shares closed up 3.25% on the stock market today, pushing above their 200-day line, which crossed above the 50-day line in February.Other S&P 500 companies have relied on cost cutting in order to improve their bottom lines amid weak global demand and a strong dollar. A stronger dollar makes U.S. goods more expensive in overseas markets.Procter & Gamble said that its Q1 profit rose 28% to $2.75 billion. It has cut thousands of jobs, reduced its marketing budget and sold more than $20 billion of its units, including its Duracell battery business.Coca-Cola has aggressively moved to cut costs by $3 billion over several years, including $600 million in costs in 2016.Big banks such as JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Bank of America (BAC) have moved to cut costs, including eliminating scores of jobs, partly in response to a tough revenue environment and partly due to increasing regulatory costs.Meanwhile, Mondelez Chief Commercial Officer Mark Clouse has joined Pinnacle Foods (PF) and will become its chief executive officer.

Berkshire Hathaway (BRKB) Chairman and CEO Warren Buffett will give his insight into the company and markets at Saturday's eagerly awaited annual shareholders meeting in Omaha, Neb.Buffett made Berkshire Hathaway's largest-ever purchase in January and reshuffled the company's portfolio.On Jan. 29, Berkshire announced it had completed the $37.2 billion (including debt) purchase of Precision Castparts, its biggest buyout ever.Berkshire's net worth rose by $15.4 billion in 2015 as the company bought more shares of favorites IBM (IBM) and Wells Fargo (WFC).Berkshire expects about 40,000 shareholders from around the world to attend the event. But you don't have to visit Omaha in person: For the first time ever, the so-called "Woodstock for Capitalists" will be streamed live, on Yahoo Finance. Buffett will offer his comments in what a press statement described as a "no holds barred" Q&A with him and Vice Chairman Charlie Munger.Buffett, 85, has said in the past that he and the board have agreed on a successor, but he hasn't disclosed who that is. Munger is 92.S&P Capital IQ analyst Cathy Seifert said in a recent report that Berkshire's growth strategy is continuing to pay off."Our buy opinion reflects our view that Berkshire's ability to grow its revenue base (both organically and through acquisitions) and maintain margins, despite a mixed economic outlook, will enable the shares to retain their premium valuation" vs. its peers and the broader market. S&P Capital IQ has a 152 price target on Berkshire's Class B stock.For the full year 2015, net earnings grew 21.2% to $24.08 billion, and revenue grew 8% to $210.8 billion, up from $194.7 billion in 2014. Net earnings for the Dec. 31-ended quarter climbed 31.8% to $5.478 billion. Earnings per share minus one-time items for Class B shares rose to $2.22 in the fourth quarter, well above analyst estimates of $1.75.The consensus of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters is for EPS to rise 3% to $1.78 for the current quarter, up from $1.72 in Q1 2015. Berkshire's BNSF Railroad continues to be a drag on earnings amid an oversupplied energy market and plunging coal shipments. BNSF's total railcar units for the week ended April 16 fell by 21% vs. the same quarter a year earlier to about 81,000 units.Berkshire Class B stock hasn't formed a viable base recently. It dropped to an intraday low of 123.55 on Feb. 3 and has bounced nicely since then. It's risen about 18%, climbing above its 10-week average and 200-day line along the way. Berkshire's B shares closed up less than 0.1% at 146.18 in the stock market today.Berkshire Hathaway boasts a solid 81 IBD Composite Rating, meaning it's outperformed 81% of all stocks on key metrics such as sales and profit growth in recent quarters.Image provided by Shutterstock.

Stocks were trading modestly higher going into the noon hour Wednesday.The Nasdaq gained 0.4%, while the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.2% each in the stock market today.Volume was tracking slightly higher on the NYSE and lower on the Nasdaq, compared to the same time Tuesday.Oil prices opened lower on news that Kuwaiti oil workers ended their strike. It recovered on news that U.S. crude inventories rose less than expected.Two Dow components tugged the index in opposite directions.Coca-Cola (KO) gapped down, plunging through its 50-day moving average as it lost 5% after reporting declining earnings for the fourth straight quarter. Excluding items, it reported EPS of 45 cents, a penny above estimates and 6% below a year earlier. Revenue fell 4% to $10.28 billion. The company said foreign exchange shaved 12 percentage points off EPS.Another Dow component, UnitedHealth Group (UNH), surged 2% to an all-time high after reporting better-than-expected earnings. It also said it would drop out of all but a handful of ObamaCare exchanges.Among IBD 50 stocks, winners held a narrow edge over the day's losers. MaxLinear (MXL) was the big gainer, with a 7% advance, after it revised earnings guidance upward. On Monday, the stock lost 10%.Shares of Weibo (WB), sometimes described as the Chinese Twitter (TWTR), rose 4% in big volume. It's now gained 21% in three weeks since breaking out of a cup-with-handle base April 6.Image provided by Shutterstock.

Despite sinking fourth-quarter earnings and sales figures, Coca-Cola (KO) says it plans to be back to delivering a long-term target of high single-digit comparable currency neutral earnings growth from 2016.
But the global beverage giant also noted during a post-earnings conference call that it expects the macro environment to become slightly more volatile than in years past.
Shares of the soda maker rose 3.3% to 42.59 in the stock market today as the maker of Sprite and Coke nevertheless floated above Wall Street expectations.
Revenue fell 1.5% to $10.9 billion, slightly above views, while earnings excluding items fell 4.3% to 44 cents a share, topping by 2 cents.

Calling 2015 a "transition year," CEO Muhtar Kent said the company is making progress with its strategic initiatives that aim to save $3 billion by 2019. Announced in October, the program includes plans to streamline the company's operating model and restructure its North American bottling business.

Total unit case volume edged up 1%. Global sparkling beverage volume rose 1%, while global still beverage volume rose 2% in Q4, led by ready-to-drink tea, sports drinks and packaged water, but was offset by a dip in juice and juice drinks.

While fizzy drinks have recently gotten negative attention from the health conscious, sales of noncarbonated drinks Gold Peak tea, Fuze Tea and I Lohas mineral water each reached the billion-dollar mark.

Comparable currency neutral net revenues in North America rose 5% during the quarter. Eurasia and Africa revenue rose 5%, and Europe sales rose 2% during the quarter. In Asia-Pacific, they dipped 1%, but jumped 14% in Latin America on positive pricing and a favorable product mix in Brazil and the company's South Latin units.

Coca-Cola reaffirmed its 2015 outlook for a "slight positive on net revenue growth," with foreign currency exchange rates negatively impacting results. However, the company said during the call that it sees Venezuela pricing provisions negatively impacting Q1 net revenue.
Dr Pepper Snapple (DPS) reports on Thursday. Shares fell 0.1% to 77.81.
Frito-Lay and Pepsi maker PepsiCo (PEP) discloses earnings results Wednesday. Shares rose 0.7% to 96.62.

Coca-Cola (KO) and other beverage makers have been expanding their offerings to reach more customers as tastes shift away from soda, but Wall Street doesn't see earnings expanding as quarterly reports come out this week.
When Coke announces fourth-quarter results on Tuesday, analysts polled by Thomson Reuters see earnings falling 8.7% to 42 cents per share and sales slipping 2.5% to $10.76 billion.
The company has reported flat or declining sales in the past seven quarters.

But its fortunes could turn around soon. Analysts at Morgan Stanley upgraded Coke to "overweight" last month, citing an expected rebound in topline growth from market-share improvement, a return to high-single digit long-term EPS gains helped by cost cuts, and higher margins from its "refranchising" effort.

In October, Coke unveiled plans to refranchise, or sell to franchisees, two-thirds of its North American bottling by the end of 2017 and a major chunk of the rest by 2020, as it decreases its footprint in the lower-margin bottling business.

Meanwhile, Coke is looking outside the traditional bottled beverage market and has partnered with Keurig Green Mountain (GMCR) on its cold-machine venture. It also took a 16% stake in the maker of coffee brewers.

Sales for non-carbonated drinks are improving too. Coke recently announced that Gold Peak tea, Fuze tea and I Lohas mineral water each had sales of over $1 billion last year. The company now has 20 beverage brands that top that annual revenue level.

Rival Dr Pepper Snapple (DPS) also has been looking to products other than sodas for growth. In Q3, the company beat earnings expectations, fueled by strong sales of flavored mineral water and Clamato.

In the past year, it also started test marketing Snapple Straight Up Tea in response to consumers' request for a less-sweet drink and a proprietary sugar-Stevia blend to be used in some of its products.
Dr Pepper has a deal with Keurig as well to bring beverages to the cold machine, which is set to debut this fall.
When Dr Pepper reports Thursday, analysts expect to see a 9.3% drop in earnings to 88 cents per share, but sales are seen rising 1% to $1.48 billion.
On Feb. 5, the beverage maker raised its dividend 17.1% to 48 cent and approved an additional $1 billion share offering.
Pepsico (PEP) is expected to announce earnings Wednesday, but it gets most of its revenue from snacks like Lay's and Doritos.
Wall Street expects EPS to edge up 3% to $1.08 with revenue seen dipping 2.2% to $19.66 billion.
The Beverages-Non-Alcoholic group is ranked No. 38 out of the 197 industry groups IBD covers, up from 160 about 6 months ago.

Follow Gillian Rich on Twitter: @IBD_GRich.Coca-Cola (KO) and other beverage makers have been expanding their offerings to reach more customers as tastes shift away from soda, but Wall Street doesn't see earnings expanding as quarterly reports come out this week.When Coke announces fourth-quarter results on Tuesday, analysts polled by Thomson Reuters see earnings falling 8.7% to 42 cents per share and sales slipping 2.5% to $10.76 billion.The company has reported flat or declining sales in the past seven quarters.But its fortunes could turn around soon. Stock futures on Tuesday advanced toward the open for a second straight day, but showed a bit more strength than in Monday's premarket session.

Dow futures were ahead 91.1 points, well above Monday's premarket levels, and rising. Nasdaq 100 futures climbed 23.6 points above fair market value. S&P 500 futures showed a healthy 10.2-point gain. Small caps also looked in good shape, with Russell 2000 futures up 4.8 points.

The stock market today rolls into December with automakers releasing November sales numbers throughout the session. Fiat Chrysler (FCAU) reported a 3% gain in sales to its best level for November in 15 years. Jeep sales drove the results, rising 20%, vs. a 12% decline for Chrysler products, an 8% slip for Dodge and a 3% fall for Fiat autos.
Auto researcher Edmunds forecasts a total of 1.33 million light vehicles sold during the month, up 2.5% from a year ago. If accurate, it would make this the best November for automakers since 2001.
At 10 a.m., the Institute for Supply Management releases its November ISM Index and the Commerce Department reports October construction spending.

Retailers with a strong online presence may get a bump from data released by Adobe Systems (ADBE) showing shoppers spent a total of $2.98 billion during "Cyber Monday" — the Monday following the Black Friday launch of the holiday shopping season, which is designated as a day of technology and online shopping specials. The amount was a record and up 14% from last year's Cyber Monday sales, Adobe said. Adobe also estimated that Thanksgiving through Cyber Monday receipts would top $11 billion, up 15% year-over-year and also a record.
About a third of the Dow's issues were positive in premarket action, the rest were flat. The best gain came from Home Depot (HD), which added 1%.
Adobe Systems rose 2% to lead the Nasdaq 100. Baidu (BIDU) posted the Nasdaq 100's largest decline, down nearly 2%.

Automated network control specialist Infoblox (BLOX) rocketed 17% higher before the open. The Santa Clara, Calif.-based company reported late Monday fiscal first-quarter earnings, revenue and Q2 guidance above expectations, and management announced a $100 million share buyback initiative.

Mattress Firm Holding (MFRM) bounced 5% higher after announcing late Monday it would buy HMK Mattress Holding, owner of the Sleepy's retail chain, in a $780 million deal. The company said it expects about $40 million a year in cost savings. Mattress Firm also announced its fiscal Q3 sales rose 51%, and said it expected a 10% EPS gain — in line with consensus views.

China-based Qihoo 360 Technologies (QIHU) added 3% after the Wall Street Journal reported an investor group was prepared to offer $9 billion to take the Internet security and content provider off the U.S. market. The $77-per-American Depositary Receipt deal could be completed in the coming weeks, the report said. Plans then call for relisting the company on one of China's domestic exchanges.

Qihoo is the most recent in a wave of privatizations among China-based companies trading in the U.S. Another China-based issue, Ikang Healthcare (KANG), announced Monday it was being taken private by a group of investors at $22 per ADR.

Among leaders, stocks on the IBD 50 list were quiet ahead of the open. Most of the group remained flat. Among the few gains and losses, all held to less than 1%. The same was true for stocks on IBD's Your Weekly Review list.
Overseas, markets across Asia gained as PMI gauges tracking China's manufacturing and services sectors showed further divergence during the month. European markets were narrowly mixed near midday.
