It's easy to develop opinions quickly about the stock market, but opinion doesn't often jibe with reality.

Interest rates, for example, often fuel bullish or bearish sentiment. When interest rates rise, it can curb consumer and business spending and have an adverse effect on the stock market. Conversely, when interest rates are falling, consumers and businesses often increase spending, which fuels the economy and stock market gains.
A constant barrage of negative headlines often can cause investors to opine bearishly on the stock market, but the market often does what's least expected when headlines are the most dire.

In March 2003, negative headline flow was rampant when the U.S. invaded Iraq. But stocks put in a bottom that month. The Nasdaq followed through with conviction on March 17, confirming a new uptrend, and a new bull market was born.

The same thing happened in Sept. 1, 2010, when the Nasdaq confirmed a new uptrend. At the time, economic headlines weren't all that rosy as the U.S. economy was trying to climb out of a recession while the IBD/TIPP Economic Optimism Index was at a 22-year low.
Investors can be opinionated about individual stocks too.

While it's generally a good idea to short stocks with bad qualities like deteriorating fundamentals and shrinking mutual fund ownership, some form opinions about a stock and do the opposite by shorting stocks with positive traits.
The shorts have been wrong about Keurig Green Mountain (GMCR) for some time now.

In mid-January 2014, short interest totaled 37.5 million shares, according to Nasdaq.com. Based on its average daily trading volume at the time of 3.5 million shares, that gave it a high days-to-cover ratio of just over 9. But on Feb. 6, shares gapped up 26% after Coca-Cola (KO) acquired a 10% stake in Keurig for $1.25 billion.

In May, Coke increased its stake to 16%. In August, shares gapped up again after Keurig inked a deal with Kraft (KRFT) to make Kraft-branded coffee pods. By that time, short interest had fallen to 9.9 million shares, but its days-to-cover ratio was still elevated at around 5.5.

Meanwhile, a high price-to-earnings ratio might cause some to say, "This stock can't go any higher, it's already too expensive." Or they might say: "This stock can't go any lower. All the bad news is already priced in."

Just before the Nasdaq's follow-through day in September 2010, Netflix (NFLX) cleared a double-bottom base in mid-August. Volume was robust, a good sign. At the time of the breakout, its price-to-earnings ratio was 50. And yet the stock more than doubled over the next 11 months or so.

Some investors like to talk negatively about a stock just because it has a premium valuation. Netflix had one at the breakout, but it was warranted due to explosive growth. Consider: In the first three quarters of 2011, quarterly earnings growth averaged 70% while sales growth averaged 48%. Full-year profit in 2011 rose 41% from 2010. Sales increased 48%.

Keurig Green Mountain (GMCR) is sending most of its U.S. coffee-buying operations from Vermont to Lausanne, Switzerland, this spring, according to Reuters.

The maker of Keurig brewers and single-serve K-Cup coffee pods isn't the first U.S. coffee giant to go overseas to the commodity market hub. Kraft (KRFT) spin-off Mondelez International (MDLZ) also has buying operations in Switzerland, and Starbucks (SBUX) has been there for over 10 years. More than 60% of the world's coffee beans are traded in commodity markets in the country.
This fall, Keurig started Keurig Trading GmbH, a new corporate entity in Switzerland.
The country has favorable tax laws and light regulation, making it home to big commodity merchants, like Glencore and Trafigura. In 2012, commodity traders made the country over $13 billion.
Keurig wouldn't say if its move is due to the more favorable tax environment, but its Canadian procurement operations won't be affected.

Keurig has been gaining popularity as consumers crave individualized drinks with a wide variety of flavor options. Coca-Cola (KO) is bullish on the company and bought a stake to develop a cold beverage system
Keurig fell below its 50-day line on Nov. 21, a day after reporting the first single-digit percentage EPS growth since 2012, and has since struggled to retake that level of support.

Stocks turned small losses into modest gains Monday afternoon.

Thanks to solar, online travel and software stocks, the Nasdaq led with a 0.3% gain. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 rose 0.2% each. Earlier, the Nasdaq and the S&P 500 were off by about 0.2% and 0.1%, respectively. But volume continued to run lower in the stock market today compared to the same time Friday.

In leading stocks, Horizon Pharma (HZNP) jumped 5% after the company raised guidance, citing expected robust Q2 results. The drugmaker now expects full-year sales of $660 million to $680 million, up from a prior view of $590 million to $610 million. Views are currently for $611.6 million. The stock is now nearly 21% past a 31.25 buy point from a flat base cleared in late May. In most cases, profits should be taken once they amount to 20% to 25%.

Medidata Solutions (MDSO) added 3%, putting it on pace for an eighth straight gain. The stock cleared a 59.07 buy point from a flat base ahead of its Q2 earnings Tuesday morning. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters see profit rising 18% to 20 cents a share. Medidata had been trading sideways since its first-quarter results in April.

Facebook (FB) tacked on 2% to a new high. It's now more than 13% past an 86.17 buy point from a flat base initially cleared June 23. The social network giant will report Q2 earnings July 29. The company is expected to earn 47 cents a share, up 12% from a year ago. But that would mark a slowdown from recent quarters. Profit grew 20% to 121% in the past four quarters.

On the downside, Taser International (TASR) turned a near 3% gain into a 2% loss. It had almost climbed back to a 35.10 buy point at Monday's high. The company announced earlier in the day that its subsidiary, Taser International BV, bought Britain's Tactical Safety Responses Limited for an undisclosed sum.

Heritage Insurance Holdings (HRTG) was off its session low, but still off nearly 8% after suffering an analyst downgrade to market perform from outperform. The most anticipated feature of Microsoft's (MSFT) Windows 10, set for release on Wednesday, isn't some new application. It's the return of the traditional Start screen, which Microsoft ditched in August 2012, with Windows 8.
For that reason, Windows 10 is a lot like Coca-Cola Classic.
Let me explain.

When the Coca-Cola (KO) announced in April 1985 that New Coke would replace the original formula of its flagship soft drink, consumers protested. Some even hoarded cases of the original flavor beverage.
New Coke is now seen as a cautionary tale about tampering with a well-established and successful brand.

In October 2012, Microsoft introduced Windows 8, a new version of its popular PC operating system with a radically redesigned user interface. Win 8 was designed with touchscreens in mind, even though few people had or wanted a touchscreen PC. The operating system was clunky to use with a keyboard and mouse.
Like New Coke, Windows 8 forced changes on the public that the company thought people would prefer. And like the dud soft drink, consumers rejected Windows 8.

Even now after almost three years on the market, Windows 8 has only mustered 16% market share, based on PCs on the Internet, according to Net Applications. By comparison, Windows 7 still has 61% of the market and 14-year-old Windows XP has 12%.

Just like Coke drinkers stockpiled the original formula beverage, many PC owners stuck with their Windows XP and 7 machines and refused to move to the new OS. And PC makers amassed Windows 7 licenses that they could install on new PCs if customers so desired.
When Coca-Cola Co. brought back the original formula three months after the debut of New Coke, it tried to put a positive spin on the move by rebranding the old drink "Coca-Cola Classic."

Classic was a hit and helped revitalize sales for the company. It was popular because it brought back what everyone loved about the original. (Or possibly consumers didn't like the advertising pitchman for New Coke: Bill Cosby.)
When Microsoft named its next-generation operating system Windows 10, it skipped over Windows 9 in its naming scheme. This was seen as a way to distance it from the memory of Windows 8.
While Windows 10 has a lot of new features — the Cortana personal assistant, Edge browser and Windows Hello — the most sought-after feature is the return of the traditional Start button and menu.
Microsoft is marketing Windows 10 as "familiar, yet better than ever."
"Windows 10 brings back the Start menu people know and love while enabling them to easily find their files, pinned applications and favorites," the company said in a June 1 press release.

Windows 10 will be available as a free upgrade to Windows 7 and 8 users on Wednesday. Microsoft is launching the product in 190 countries and is planning launch events and "fan celebrations" in major markets like the U.S.

Obviously, Microsoft is hoping for a sales boost related to Windows Classic, er, Windows 10.The most anticipated feature of Microsoft's (MSFT) Windows 10, set for release on Wednesday, isn't some new application. A top Federal Reserve policymaker signaled he's less interested in raising rates next month, while durable goods orders and business investment picked up, at least in July.Fed's Dudley: September rate hike 'less compelling'New York Federal Reserve President William Dudley said Wednesday that he's less interested in a Fed "liftoff" next month, citing "international and financial market developments.""From my perspective, at this moment, the decision to begin the normalization process at the September FOMC meeting seems less compelling to me than it was a few weeks ago," he said.Dudley said he "really" hopes to see higher rates this year.Durable goods jump in JulyOrders were up 2% in July, trouncing expectations of a 0.4% decline, while a 3.4% gain in June was revised up to 4.1%. New orders remain 20% lower vs. a year ago, though that's largely due to summer air show orders skewing the data. Excluding the volatile transportation sector, orders rose 0.6% in July, also stronger than forecast. Core capital goods orders rose 2.2%, the second straight increase. Such positive data shows domestic strength amid global market woes. But will it last? Energy firms may have decided to step up capital spending as oil prices stabilized, but with crude plunging below $40 a barrel, oil and gas firms may make further cuts.Offshore drilling giant Transocean (RIG) halted its dividend late Tuesday. But Schlumberger (SLB) said Wednesday it would buy fellow oil services firm Cameron International (CAM) for $13 billion deal. Mortgage applications ticked up during the Aug. 21 week, with the Mortgage Bankers Assn.'s index up 0.2%. Applications to purchase rose 2%, but refinances dipped 1% even as average rates declined 3 bps. A housing market index from Freddie Mac rose 1.33% in June. At 80.3, its Multi-Indicator Market Index is up 5.41% vs. a year ago and points to a market in the outer stable range, according to Freddie. Some 28 states are in what Freddie considers stable range.Sales strong in U.K.CBI's "High Street" survey showed volumes rose to 24 from 21 in Aug., defying expectations of a dip to 18. Sales rose 0.6%, CBI said. It forecasts a rise in volumes to 35 in Sept. U.K. mortgage approvals rose to their highest level in 17 months in July, the British Bankers' Assn. said. The 46,033 approvals were up 11% vs. a year ago. Refinancing approvals rose to the highest in 4 years as homeowners anticipate a Bank of England rate rise. Eurozone inflation might never reach the central bank's target, said ECB Chief Economist Peter Praet. "Price pressures will remain subdued," he said, as commodities plunge and the euro strengthens.COMING UP THURSDAY

In the spirit of the Pepsi Challenge, we'll take a look at Coca-Cola (KO) and PepsiCo's (PEP) earnings, fundamentals and stock price action. Atlanta-based Coca-Cola on Wednesday topped views with a 2% slip in Q2 comparable earnings to 63 cents on a 3% revenue dip to $12.16 billion. Noncarbonated beverage sales outperformed sparkling beverage sales.

Coke, which took a near 17% stake in Monster Beverage (MNST) in August, has a three-year earnings growth rate of 2%. Its Earnings Stability Factor is 1 on a scale from 0 (most stable) to 99 (most volatile).

The beverage giant is also a consistent dividend payer. It raised its quarterly payout by 8% to 33 cents a share, or $1.32 for the full year, which works out to a 3.2% annualized yield vs. the S&P 500's average 1.93% payout.
This is the 53rd consecutive year in which Coke has raised its annual dividend. Coke is an S&P 500 Dividend Aristocrat — a firm that has increased dividends for 25 years in a row.
The stock is working on a flat base with a potential buy point at 43.93. It's trading just above its 10-week moving average and down slightly for the year. It's 7% below the entry.
Rival PepsiCo is crafting a flat base with a possible entry at 100.86. The stock is closer to the buy point, at 4% below. It's trading above its 10-week line and is up nearly 3% this year.

The Purchase, N.Y.-based company has a three-year earnings growth rate of 4% and an Earnings Stability Factor of 2. Earlier this month, its Q2 results beat views despite foreign exchange headwinds. Organic revenue rose 5.1% during the quarter as global snacks rose 8% and beverages 2%.

PepsiCo raised its full-year earnings growth outlook to 8% from 7%. It's added craft sodas to its lineup to help offset flagging sales of traditional sodas. It too is a Dividend Aristocrat, having raised its annual payout for a 43rd straight year. Coca-Cola (KO) bubbled past Wall Street views Wednesday as the beverage giant hiked drink prices. Demand for Diet Coke continued to decline.

Comparable earnings dipped a little less than 2% to 63 cents, 3 cents over consensus estimates. Coke reported EPS of 71 cents, helped by gains related to the closing of its purchase of a nearly 17% stake in Monster Beverage (MNST).
Revenue edged down 3.1% to $12.16 billion, slightly above forecasts for $12.06 billion.
Total unit case volume rose 2%, said the company. Global sparkling beverage volume rose 1% on 6% growth in Coca-Cola Zero as well as gains in Sprite and Fanta.
But Diet Coke volume fell 7%, extending declines from a 6% decrease in the previous quarter.

Global still (noncarbonated) beverage volume grew 5% as ready-to-drink tea rose 7% and packaged water rose 8%. Juice and juice drinks fell 1% as prices were hiked to compensate for higher input costs and "continued industry softness in certain markets."

By region, North American reported that its net revenue grew 3%. Eurasia and Africa revenue fell 10%, while Europe revenue declined 9%. Latin America revenue declined 13%. Asia Pacific revenue fell 7%.
Shares rose 0.2% to 41.25 in the stock market today.
Coke says that it is targeting full-year net share buybacks of $2 billion to $2.5 billion. It sees foreign exchange rates weighing on reported results in 2015.
Beverage and snack rival PepsiCo (PEP) topped earnings forecasts last week in the face of currency headwinds. Dr Pepper Snapple Group (DPS) reports Thursday.

Monster Beverage (MNST) broke out of a base in the stock market today. The energy drink maker had fallen as much as 14% from its April 27 high after reporting disappointing Q1 results. But now the stock is trying to stage a comeback. Shares gained 1% on Tuesday, clearing a 139.75 buy point from a cup-with-handle base. But volume was…
Stock futures veered unevenly lower on a heavy slate of earnings reports ahead of Wednesday's open.
Dow futures were down 30.3 points below fair market value, but had pared early losses. Nasdaq 100 futures were down 62.4 points and sliding. S&P 500 futures were also ticking lower, down 7.2 points.

This week's economic calendar finally kicks into gear at 9 a.m. ET, with the Federal Housing Finance Agency's May Housing Price Index. June existing-home sales numbers from the National Association of Realtors are due out at 10 a.m., with weekly crude oil inventories from the Energy Information Administration to follow at 10:30.

Big names were moving ahead of the open in the stock market today, with Boeing (BA) (up 1%), Microsoft (MSFT) (down 4%), Coca-Cola (KO) (up 1%) and Whirlpool (WHR) (up 2%) responding to their quarterly reports.

Apple (AAPL) grabbed the early headlines. The stock slid more than 6% in premarket trade, despite its late-Tuesday report of a better-than-forecast 44% earnings gain, a 33% surge in sales and expanded profit margins in its fiscal third quarter.

Fourth-quarter revenue guidance didn't quite measure up, however, and the company separately didn't break out sales of the new Apple Watch. Apple shares ended Tuesday just above their 50-day moving average in a shallow, two-month consolidation.
Apple suppliers were also taking an early beating, with Cirrus Logic (CRUS) and Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) down more than 5%.

Vasco Data Security (VDSI) collapsed 9% after the company admitted in a regulatory filing released Tuesday that some of its products may have been sold into Iran via its European subsidiary and a third-party distributor.

The sale potentially violated federal rules prohibiting transactions with "proliferators of weapons of mass destruction and their supporters." Vasco shares had pulled back sharply from a late June high to test support at their 40-week moving average.
Illumina (ILMN) dimmed 9%, falling hard after reporting late Tuesday its Q2 earnings topped; revenue missed analyst consensus expectations for the first time in six years.

The maker of large-scale genetic screening equipment also raised its Q3 earnings guidance in line with projections. The stock finished Tuesday just below Monday's high and 6% above a 223.18 buy point from a three-weeks-tight pattern.

Blackhawk Network (HAWK) climbed 4%. The distributor of prepaid gift cards reported late Tuesday its sales and earnings cleared analyst estimates. The IBD 50 and Leaderboard stock ended Tuesday at the top of its buying range, 4.8% above a 40.67 buy point in a cup base.

Overseas, Europe's markets were under pressure near midday. A vote in Greece was expected to pass further fiscal measures required by its recent bailout agreement with eurozone creditors, but could show declining support for Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras. London's FTSE 100 showed the deepest loss among benchmark indexes, down 1%.
In China, Hong Kong's Hang Seng index fell 1%, while the Shanghai Composite added 0.2%. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 in Japan fell 1.2% as the yen rose against the dollar.

The dollar rose up vs. the euro. Apple (AAPL) didn't make Goldman Sach's list of stocks that are most exposed to China's slowdown, but many beaten-up semiconductor stocks did make the list amid a rising toll on industrial companies. While as much as 60% of Apple's revenue and 80% of its fiscal Q3 operating income growth came from China amid strong iPhone sales, Goldman Sachs economist David Kostin identified other stocks with the highest overall revenue exposure to China, in a research report published on Monday.

Apple's iPhone sales in China might have topped the U.S. in fiscal Q3, but the companies with the most revenue exposure include Skyworks Solutions (SWKS), Qualcomm (QCOM), Broadcom (BRCM), Micron Technology (MU) and Avago Technologies (AVGO). Some of those stocks have sold off on Apple's weaker-than-expected iPhone sales in its fiscal Q3 ended June 27.
Skyworks and Avago had been among the best-performing stocks in 2014 and early 2015, but they've fallen in the past couple of months.

"Information technology stocks are the most exposed to China, with 10% of revenues generated in the region," said Kostin in the report. "Sales to China account for less than 2% of revenues from the industrials and consumer sectors."
Industrial companies, however, have been harder hit by weak China economic data than consumer sectors, he wrote.
Many companies have lowered guidance amid China's stock market turmoil, though the impact on its overall economy is still being debated by economists.

"S&P 500 firms explicitly attribute just 2% of their revenues to China and 8% to the broader Asia-Pacific region," Kostin said. "Analysts have slashed EPS estimates of U.S. firms with high sales exposure to China by 15% year-to-date vs. 8% for the overall S&P 500."

Bank of America/Merrill Lynch also weighed in on Monday, noting that "China-exposed" stocks have seen a lower proportion of June-quarter earnings beats and have given weaker guidance. BofA says the companies impacted experienced slowing demand — from "autos to TVs to iPhones to machinery."
Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and Yum Brands (YUM) are among the companies with revenue exposure, says Goldman Sachs.

"Industrial companies in both the U.S. and Europe witnessed a negative Q2 earnings impact from a slowdown in China," said Kostin. "Company managements of firms such as 3M (MMM), Caterpillar (CAT), and United Technologies (UTX) addressed the weakness during earnings conference calls.

"In contrast, consumer-facing firms did not echo the negative sentiment toward China expressed by many industrials. Companies such as General Motors (GM), Under Armour (UA), Coca Cola (KO) and Pepsi (PEP) benefitted from the Chinese consumer."Apple (AAPL) didn't make Goldman Sach's list of stocks that are most exposed to China's slowdown, but many beaten-up semiconductor stocks did make the list amid a rising toll on industrial companies. Before them all stood Ty Cobb. "He really was America's first superstar," Charles Leerhsen, author of the new book "Ty Cobb: A Terrible Beauty," told IBD. "Take into account mass entertainment was just…
Stocks were firmly in negative territory in late-afternoon trading Friday, but there wasn't much conviction behind the selling.
The Nasdaq lost 0.8% while the S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average gave up 0.6%. Volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq was tracking well below Thursday's levels.
Security software and biotech stocks lagged for the second straight session in the stock market today.
Exxon Mobil (XOM) and Chevron (CVX) lagged in the Dow as oil fell again. At the New York Mercantile Exchange, WTI crude oil lost just over 1% to $44.14 a barrel — down 6.3% for the week.
In economic news, the U.S. economy added 215,000 jobs in July, but wages were weak and the labor force participation rate hit a multi-decade low.
One day after a lukewarm debut, buyers came into Planet Fitness (PLNT). Shares jumped 12% to 17.98 after pricing Wednesday night at 16.
Meanwhile, a trio of early big movers faded badly.

An early 5% gain for Monster Beverage (MNST) eased to 2% after its Q2 results missed analyst targets but showed the drink maker's distribution deal with Coca-Cola (KO) was on track. Monster is in a buy range from a 139.75 buy point, but new buys are risky in light of the stock's recent volatility.

Arista Networks (ANET) also looked good early but was up a bit more than 1% in late trade after retracing a big chunk of a 7% early gain. The provider of cloud networking gear and software reported an across-the-board beat in its second-quarter results. Arista is still working on a base with an 88.66 buy point, but price action has been erratic, making the base flawed.

And enterprise software name Fleetmatics (FLTX) reversed early gains despite solid earnings late Thursday. Quarterly profit jumped 83% from a year ago to 33 cents a share. Sales rose 24% to $68.6 million. Stocks slumped out of the starting gate Friday as earnings reports roiled early action and an OK July payrolls report dragged mildly on stocks.
All three major indexes were down 0.2%. Volume edged up 1% on the Nasdaq and was 17% lower on the NYSE, compared to trade at the same time Thursday.

The stock market today showed a modest negative reaction to data showing U.S. nonfarm employers added 215,000 new jobs in July, down from June's performance but slightly above expectations. The unemployment rate and labor force participation rates remained unchanged, which was generally positive. The news does little to alter the likelihood of the Federal Reserve possibly raising its target interest rate in September.
Stocks were busy in early action, with Nvidia (NVDA) surging 9% to the top of the Nasdaq 100 and the S&P 500. Viacom (VIAB) rebounded 5%, but remained deep in the hole after Thursday's 14% dive.
Losses on the S&P 500 were mild, with Hershey (HSY) stepping off the deepest decline, down 3% after its Q2 earnings beat, but flat revenue stopped shy of expectations.
About half of the IBD 50 list moved higher at the start of trade.

Monster Beverage (MNST) jumped 4% after its Q2 resultsmissed analyst targets but showed the drink maker's distribution deal with Coca-Cola (KO) was on track. The gain put shares 8% above a 139.75 buy point and 3% below Monday's high.

Arista Networks (ANET) grabbed a 4% gain. The provider of cloud networking gear and software reported an across-the-board beat in its second-quarter results. Friday's gain lifted shares to less than 3% below an 88.66 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.

On the downside, Horizon Pharma (HZNP) dived 6% after an 86% EPS gain and a 161% surge in revenue cleared consensus expectations, but it left its full-year revenue guidance unchanged and just below consensus projections. Investors have slurped up shares of beverage stocks in recent weeks, pushing them up into the upper echelon of IBD's industry group rankings. The 17-stock soft drinks industry group has risen 25% this year, while the S&P 500 remains little changed. The group has risen steadily over the past six weeks, from No. 82 to No. 17 out of 197…

Best Mutual Funds 2015: Second Quarter Performance UpdateManagers of leading mutual funds the past three months have been taking profits and eased their buying of top-rated stocks. With top mutual funds adjusting their portfolios, the summer months kicked off with a lot of market volatility, thanks to Greece's persistent debt woes.The Nasdaq dropped 1.64% in June, while the S&P 500 fell 2.1%. The Dow was off 2.2%. IBD's Market Pulse turned to "under pressure" on June 26.Some medical giants, including Abiomed (ABMD), Illumina (ILMN) and HCA Holdings (HCA) also have been favored by top-performing funds in the latest reporting periods.IBD found eight top-notch mutual funds adding Abiomed, investing an estimated $2.8 million in their latest reporting periods.The Danvers, Mass.-based firm makes medical devices designed to assist or replace the pumping function of the heart.Abiomed's flagship product is heart pump Impella 2.5, which received FDA approval for elective and urgent high-risk percutaneous coronary intervention procedures.Abiomed is planning to expand operations at its Danvers headquarters, adding employees and manufacturing capacity.After hitting a 52-week high of 77 in early May, the stock has been etching a second-stage base, sitting just 15% off its high. Earnings growth has ramped up 173% and 211% the past two quarters.Several tech issues have continued to draw interest from top funds in recent months, including Palo Alto Networks (PANW), Avago Technologies (AVGO), CyberArk Software (CYBR), Fleetmatics (FLTX), Tyler Technologies (TYL) and NXP Semiconductors (NXPI).Monster Beverage (MNST) continued to pique investors' interests, as 22 best-performing funds invested an estimated $300 million in the latest reporting periods.The energy drink maker and Coca-Cola (KO) completed their previously announced strategic partnership. Coca-Cola now owns a 16.7% stake in Monster.Sell SideTop funds have been selling big telecom-cable stocks, such as Comcast (CMCSA) and Time Warner (TWC), in their latest reporting periods. Investors also are unloading retailers, including drug stores CVS Health (CVS) and Wallgreens Boot Alliance (WBA). Restaurants Yum Brands (YUM) and Starbucks (SBUX) were axed by top funds.

JPMorgan Large Cap Growth Fund is building a head of steam. The $15.8 billion fund has topped its Morningstar large-cap growth rivals and the S&P 500 for two straight quarters and three of the past four.
And over the 12 months ended going into Tuesday, the fund is up 17.74% vs. 11.55% for large-cap growth mutual funds tracked by Morningstar Inc. that are its direct rivals and 8.91% for the S&P 500.
That outperformance reflects a portfolio whose average IBD Composite Rating is a very strong 74. Thirty-three of the fund's 67 stocks have a Composite Rating of 80 or better.
Composite Rating summarizes Earnings Per Share Growth, Relative Price Strength and other CAN SLIM ratings. A rating can be 1 to 99, with 99 the best.
The fund's gains for investors have been driven by names like Monster Beverage (MNST), which is up 29% so far this year.
Trading around 140, the stock is forming a cup-with-handle base with a 139.75 buy point.

The fund added Monster, which has a 99 Composite Rating, in the first quarter. The beverage maker should benefit from its partnership with Coca Cola (KO) and from gains in market share by energy drinks.
Regeneron Pharmaceutical (REGN) has been another driver. The eye-disease drugmaker is up 31% this year. It is forming a flat base with a 544.10 buy point.
Earnings per share grew 5%, 25% and 27% in the past three quarters.
Its eye drug Eylea is the key growth driver for Regeneron.
Zacks Equity Research says Eylea sales could get a boost from use to treat diabetic retinopathy and two forms of macular edema.
Awaiting The Green Light
And Sanofi (SNY) and Regeneron hope to get approval this month from U.S. regulators for their cholesterol-lowering drug Praluent.
Starbucks (SBUX), with a Composite Rating of 98, has been a third driver. Shares are up 36% this year.
The fund boosted its stake to 2.7 million shares by March 31, up from 104,000 as of Dec. 31.
On Tuesday the coffee-shop chain said it would partner with Taste Holdings, a Johannesburg-listed company, to open full-format stores in South Africa. Taste will own and run the java joints.

Starbucks' return on equity was 29.1%, 34.8% and 41.7% in the past three years. Monday and Tuesday the stock hit new highs. Shares are extended from their January breakout and have rebounded from their 10-week line.
Illumina (ILMN) is up 24% this year. Early Tuesday, it retook a 223.18 buy point from a three-weeks-tight pattern.
The gene-sequencing leader has a 97 Composite Rating and is on IBD's Leaderboard.
Like Illumina, Facebook (FB) is on the Leaderboard and is in the IBD 50. Shares are up 15% this year.
Facebook remained near new highs Tuesday afternoon. The stock was about 5% above its 86.17 buy point, or still in a buy range.
According to media reports Friday, the company is looking to add music videos to its news feeds.
Valeant Pharmaceuticals International (VRX) is up 80% so far this year. Earnings per share for the specialty drug and medical device company grew 130%, 342% and 486% the past three quarters.

The Toronto-listed company has a history of accretive acquisitions, such as its takeover of branded drugmaker Salix Pharmaceuticals.JPMorgan Large Cap Growth Fund is building a head of steam. A raft of warnings from U.S. multinationals about their Chinese operations may indicate China's transition away from investment-focused growth is on track — but not going as smoothly as official data suggest.

In the past week, Caterpillar (CAT) cited reduced construction work in China for its subpar second-quarter results. United Technologies (UTX) blamed soft demand for elevators in part for cutting its full-year outlook, as China's once-hot real estate market cools off. Dow Chemical (DOW) warned of falling demand.

Apple (AAPL), however, more than doubled its China sales. But the overall downbeat tone from other companies this earnings season contrasts with China's Q2 GDP report that showed 7% growth, higher than expected and suspiciously in line with Beijing's target.
The recent comments from big U.S. firms also point to what may lie ahead as China rebalances its massive economy.

"In China, the idea was domestic consumption will pick up the slack," said Sung Won Sohn, an economist and professor at California State University, Channel Islands. "That really hasn't happened yet."
Car Dealers Boost Incentives

The troubles are extending beyond smokestack-type companies. Microsoft (MSFT) reported enduring a challenging macroeconomic climate in China, and virtualization software developer VMware (VMW) reported sluggish China business.

Some companies selling big-ticket consumer goods have been disappointed as well. Household appliance giant Whirlpool (WHR) said it had strong growth but noted "a lower demand environment in China than we had originally thought it was going to be."

General Motors (GM) said moderation and price competition in China's auto sector have been worse than anticipated, and the carmaker now sees the industry growing in the "low single-digit range" this year, down from a prior view of 6%-8% growth.
Analysts at Sanford Bernstein have estimated that capacity utilization in China's auto industry has declined, and car dealerships are offering more generous incentives.
But GM remained bullish on China long-term and expressed optimism that it can weather the near-term challenges with new models, improved product mix and aggressive cost cuts.
Some other U.S. consumer-facing companies, especially those that enjoy extra brand cachet, have been bright spots in an otherwise gloomy picture.
China's iPhone Bonanza

Apple reported that fiscal Q3 revenue shot up 112% to $13.2 billion in its greater Chinese market, which includes Taiwan. The Cupertino, Calif.-based tech giant said it plans to open 40 stores in China within the next 12 months.

Starbucks (SBUX) reported that same-store sales in the China/Asia Pacific region jumped 11% in fiscal Q3 and maintained plans to open 850 stores there this fiscal year vs. 600 in the Americas and 200 in the Europe-Middle East-Africa region.

And Nike (NKE), which reported its latest results last month, counts China as its fastest growing region. In its fiscal year that ended in May, the athletic gear giant's greater China sales leapt 18%. Meanwhile, consumer staples like Coca-Cola (KO) have seen sales volumes in China start to improve after slowing in 2014.

One wild card could be China's roller-coaster stock market, which soared earlier this year only to see its worst decline since the 2008 financial crisis. While stock ownership is still relatively narrow in China, GM pointed to the "potential recovery from the current reaction to the volatilities in the stock market" as something it will monitor.
Although China's shift is seen as necessary for more sustainable growth, the process of change can be awkward and painful.

"In the long run, it's good for everybody," said Angel Ubide, a senior fellow at the Peterson Institute for International Economics. "In the near term, there are going to be winners and losers."A raft of warnings from U.S. multinationals about their Chinese operations may indicate China's transition away from investment-focused growth is on track — but not going as smoothly as official data suggest.In the past week, Caterpillar (CAT) cited reduced construction work in China for its subpar second-quarter results. Monster Beverage's (MNST) stock surged Tuesday after Citigroup added the energy-drink maker to its U.S. Focus List and said the company was its top U.S. beverage stock, citing international growth potential as well as earnings and sales acceleration in the years to come.Citi kept its buy rating on the stock with a 155 price target. Over the next five years, analysts there see Monster turning in "outsized" earnings and sales growth."We are adding MNST to our U.S. Focus List as we believe there is considerable upside to the stock from current levels," Citi analyst Wendy Nicholson said in a note, according to Benzinga.Shares rallied 3.7% to 131.64 in the stock market today. Monster's stock gapped down May 8 after reporting disappointing Q1 results a day earlier, beginning a stint below its 50-day moving average that persisted through Tuesday.Nicholson said that decline was due to research indicating that Monster's market share had "come under a bit of pressure," Benzinga reported.Looking ahead, Citi sees Monster's stock price rising due to a variety of factors.Among them: the possibility that Coca-Cola (KO) will raise its stake in the company, new products, opportunities to get into new markets such as China, new distribution deals in nations like Brazil and indications "that U.S. distribution transition has stabilized," according to StreetInsider.Coca-Cola on Friday completed a $2.15 billion purchase of a 16.7% stake in Monster. Under the terms of that agreement, Coke handed over its energy-product business to Monster in exchange for Monster's nonenergy drinks.

The S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average each added 1.2%. The IBD 50 sprinted 1.8%, leading the indexes for a second straight session. Volume in the…
Stocks fought to hold thin gains in early trade Tuesday as the market battled concerns over the eurozone's standoff with Greece .
The Dow Jones industrial added 0.1%. The S&P 500 was flat and the Nasdaq showed fractional losses.
Volume was off to a soft start, dipping 10% on the NYSE and 1% on the Nasdaq compared with trade at the same time Monday.

The stock market today received mixed news from the homebuilding sector, with the Commerce Department reporting that new housing starts stalled in May, but building permits jumped more than expected. That coincided with news from the National Association of Homebuilders on Monday that builder confidence had unexpectedly surged in June.
Leading stocks showed some verve in Tuesday's early going.

Monster Beverage (MNST) popped nearly 4% at the open. Coca-Cola (KO) on Monday closed its $2.15 billion purchase of a 16.7% stake in the company. A statement from Coke said that, as part of the deal, it would transfer its worldwide energy business to Monster, including brands such as NOS, Full Throttle and Burn. Coke would take over Monster's nonenergy business, including Hansen's Natural Sodas and Juice products and Peace Tea. Monster fell out of a flat-base pattern and has been working since May to regain its 10-week moving average.

Coty (COTY) grabbed headlines, spiking 16% on news that it would buy the beauty and hair product businesses of Procter & Gamble (PG) in what is being reported as a $12 billion deal. Brands included in the deal were said to include Max Factor, Clairol and Cover Girl. The heavy-volume gain lifted shares 17% past a 25.86 flat base buy point.

Vasco Data Security (VDSI) jumped 4% out of the starting gate. Tigress Financial initiated coverage on the Oakbrook Terrace, Ill.-based security software developer with a buy rating. The report said Vasco's products were simple to implement and use and that demand for network security was increasing. The gain put Vasco shares 18% above a 28.27 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.

Methode Electronics (MEI) tumbled 8%, carving below its 50-day moving average and undercutting a 47.51 flat-base buy point by almost 8%. Robert W. Baird downgraded the stock to neutral from outperform, citing a weakening outlook, particularly in Methode's automotive business, for the next 12 months.

Workday's (WDAY) mixed earnings report late Tuesday could be the result of several factors ranging from seasonality issues and lower average deal sizes to increased competition from business software giant Oracle (ORCL), analysts say.

Workday, the No. 1 provider of human capital management software, reported a per-share loss and revenue that beat analyst estimates, but its Q1 billings and Q2 revenue outlook were less than what Wall Street wanted to see.
Workday stock was down 10% in morning trading in the stock market today, near 83. At least two investment banks lowered their price targets for Workday stock.

Workday's ability to sign new customers including Coca-Cola (KO) was offset by seasonality issues in Q1, Jesse Hulsing, an analyst for Cowen and Co., said in a research report Wednesday. Hulsing cut his price target to 101 from 111 but maintained an outperform rating.
"Management noted that the company's model is becoming more back-half loaded, a trend that will likely compound moving forward due to the company's renewal cycles," Hulsing wrote.

Workday is aggressively pushing its financial management software, which could temporarily be lowering its average selling prices, William Blair analyst Justin Furby wrote in a research report Wednesday. He maintained an outperform rating on Workday stock.

"Average deal sizes in the quarter appeared to have come down meaningfully year-over year, despite three large enterprise wins in the quarter (Hitachi, Dell and Coca-Cola), which suggests either increased discounting, lower attach rates, or a higher mix of middle-market activity relative to a year ago," he wrote. "We believe that over time, financial deal sizes will increase and ultimately be larger than core human resource as the company continues to push upmarket — management alluded to a growing pipeline of Fortune 250 financials customers — but this could be more of a gradual progression than a step function in the near term."

Workday also could also be seeing stiffer competition from Oracle as that company steps up its move to the cloud, J. Derrick Wood, an analyst for Susquehanna Financial Group, said in a report Wednesday. Wood lowered his price target on Workday stock to 89 from 97. He has a neutral rating on the company.

"We think Oracle is having an increasing presence in the market with greater maturity of its cloud HCM efforts, and with (Workday CEO Aneel Bhusri) mentioning that 'Oracle has their act together better than SAP (SAP) does,' we think it is possible competitive dynamics with Oracle are evolving," Wood wrote. "Indeed, our research reveals that Oracle now has about 350 live cloud HCM customers, up from greater than 100 a year ago, giving it a much larger referenceable customer base to help with sales engagements."Workday's (WDAY) mixed earnings report late Tuesday could be the result of several factors ranging from seasonality issues and lower average deal sizes to increased competition from business software giant Oracle (ORCL), analysts say.Workday, the No. 1 provider of human capital management software, reported a per-share loss and revenue that beat analyst estimates, but its Q1 billings and Q2 revenue outlook were less than what Wall Street wanted to see.Workday stock was down 10% in morning trading in the stock market today, near 83. Keurig Green Mountain (GMCR) and big backer Coca-Cola (KO) are working to dethrone incumbent cold drink machine maker SodaStream (SODA) with their Keurig Kold, but a new appliance from Whirlpool (WHR) and Anheuser-Busch InBev (BUD) is also making waves.The B.blend, which is the result of a four-year collaboration between the appliance maker and beer company, is an all-in-one machine that can make hot coffee as well as cold juice and soda. The device went on sale Tuesday in Sao Paulo, Brazil, for about $1,150.The B.blend is based on technology that comes from a licensing deal with Bevyz, which Keurig fully acquired at the end of last year, several months after the August announcement from Whirlpool about the launch of the platform.Depending on demand, Whirlpool and Anheuser-Busch plan to expand sales to the entire South American country and beyond.Whirlpool and Anheuser-Busch shares were down a fraction in afternoon trading in the stock market today.Keurig Kold, which can make iced coffee, soda, sports drinks and iced tea, will start selling online this fall and in select stores this holiday, but it won't reach all retail stores until the 2016 holiday season.It's priced starting at $300, which left some analysts cold on last week's post-earnings conference call.The Keurig 2.0 carafe-and-pod duo is $200, but sales have been weak, in part due to backlash over the latest brewer's unlicensed pod lockout technology.Argus Research analyst John Staszak on Wednesday downgraded the at-home beverage machine maker to hold from buy, and says Keurig is seen facing pressure from price cuts on its K-cup pods that it manufactures for Starbucks (SBUX) and Kraft Foods (KRFT).Costs associated with the new Kold machine, as well as 2.0 markdowns, are expected to weigh on near-term earnings, Staszak says.Keurig shares rose fractionally Wednesday afternoon. The stock is trading a steep 43% off of its all-time high of 158.87 reached last November. Just this month, shares have dropped 23%.And in addition to competition from the high-end, early-adopter machine from Whirlpool and Anheuser-Busch, Keurig also faces pressure from SodaStream, whose machines range in price from $80 to $180.But SodaStream sales have been plunging. Shares are in an extended downtrend and are 73% below their August 2011 all-time high of 79.72.Follow Alissa Williams on Twitter: @IBD_AWilliams.

That would be a slowdown from its previous…
At first glance, flagging soft drink sales might be a reason to shun Dow component Coca-Cola. But recent strategic initiatives show that the firm isn't ready to quit yet.

Carbonated beverages still account for the lion's share of sales volume at Coca-Cola (KO), but with soda consumption waning in North America, Coke has branched out into juices, bottled water, Powerade and energy drinks.

Shares gapped up nearly 2% on Aug. 15 after Coke announced plans to acquire a 17% stake in Monster Beverage (MNST) for about $2 billion. Monster has a big share of the U.S. energy drink market. It's also been increasing its share overseas. Sales in 2013 totaled $2.25 billion, up 9% from 2012. As part of the deal, Monster will transfer its non-energy brands, including Hansen's Natural and Peace Tea, to Coke.

In February, Coke acquired a 10% stake in Keurig Green Mountain (GMCR) for $1.25 billion. A few months later, it increased its stake to 16%. The Keurig Cold system is expected to launch next year and will offer at-home carbonation of soft drinks without a CO2 cartridge.
Last week, Keurig added two varieties of Coke's Honest Tea K-Cups for its hot brewing machines.

When Coke reported second-quarter earnings in July, profit rose 2% from a year ago, but sales fell 1% to $12.57 billion, its sixth straight quarter of declining sales growth. Beverage volumes rose 3% worldwide while soda volumes rose 2%. In the first quarter, soda volumes fell for the first time since 1999. In North America, soda volumes were flat.
Annual earnings growth is expected to be flat this year at $2.08 a share, with growth ramping up in 2015, rising 7% to $2.22.

Coke has a dividend growth rate of 8%. It pays a quarterly dividend of 30.5 cents, giving it an annual yield of 2.9%.At first glance, flagging soft drink sales might be a reason to shun Dow component Coca-Cola. The Keurig Cold system is expected to launch next year and will offer at-home carbonation of soft drinks without a CO2 cartridge.Last week, Keurig added two varieties of Coke's Honest Tea K-Cups for its hot brewing machines.When Coke reported second-quarter earnings in July, profit rose 2% from a year ago, but sales fell 1% to $12.57 billion, its sixth straight quarter of declining sales growth. Beverage volumes rose 3% worldwide while soda volumes rose 2%. In the first quarter, soda volumes fell for the first time since 1999. In North America, soda volumes were flat.Annual earnings growth is expected to be flat this year at $2.08 a share, with growth ramping up in 2015, rising 7% to $2.22.Coke has a dividend growth rate of 8%. It pays a quarterly dividend of 30.5 cents, giving it an annual yield of 2.9%.

Nahin Monsoor just can't seem to have enough Nike basketball shoes.The 12-year-old New York City native already owns four pairs of Nike (NKE) basketball shoes and was eying several more at the Foot Locker (FL) store on Manhattan's Upper East Side on the last Sunday in October.Monsoor says he only wears Nike basketball shoes."The style is really good and they're comfortable," said Monsoor, who has worn Nike basketball sneakers since he was seven.Monsoor isn't alone. Basketball shoes continue to be big winners in the hotly competitive athletic footwear game, with IBD 50 stock Nike scoring big points among consumers with its namesake and Jordan brands as well as collections from basketball stars LeBron James, Kevin Durant and Kobe Bryant, say followers.The apparel and footwear powerhouse has stayed on top of its game by continually rolling out more shoes named after star basketball athletes. Its latest was the LeBron 12 'HRT of a Lion' basketball shoe launched at retail on Oct. 30 after being delayed due to what Nike said was a "small cosmetic issue." The debut coincided with the Cleveland Cavaliers forward playing in his first NBA regular-season game for the team in four years that evening.Playing The FieldNike has been gaining traction on several fronts. Ongoing innovation in areas such as its Flyknit technology, now expanded beyond use in running shoes to several other categories such as football and basketball shoes, has helped vault Nike's business to new heights.It has also seen a big jump in its business in Western Europe and in China; and Nike is also riding the crest of the athleticwear wave that's taken workout clothes and sneakers out of the gym and onto Main Street as "the" fashion trend.Nike scored a slam dunk in its most recent fiscal 2015 first quarter. Earnings soared 27% to $1.09 a share, ahead of views by 21 cents. Revenue rose 15% to $7.98 billion, beating analyst forecasts for $7.83 billion. It was Nike's biggest quarterly revenue gain since the second quarter of fiscal 2012. Nike has logged double-digit revenue gains the past three quarters.Revenue climbed 25% in Western Europe, 12% in North America and 20% in greater China.Strong performance came from Nike's direct-to-consumer business, which includes its owned in-line and factory stores, as well as online sales through its website. Revenue increased 22%, driven by 11% same-store sales growth and significantly higher Nike.com revenue."In this current macro environment and given the size of the company, for Nike to be able to grow this quarter's revenue 15% with the expectation of 20% EPS growth for the full year, this early in the fiscal year, is nothing short of an outstanding performance, we think," wrote Nomura analyst Bob Drbul in a note following the results.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect full-year earnings to climb 21% to $3.60 a share, roughly double the 10% gain it saw the prior year. They see a 15% gain in fiscal 2016 and a 14% rise in 2017.Nike Stock JumpsNike shares hit an all-time high on Friday. They have surged 17% since the company reported first-quarter results on Sept. 25, and more than 30% from a February low."The reason Nike's stock is doing so well is their products are some of the only ones selling with strength globally," Brian Sozzi, CEO of Belus Capital Advisors, told IBD. "So they are not having to cut prices for their products."Adds Susquehanna Financial Group analyst Christopher Svezia: "They've executed pretty well. To some investors who need to look at big consumer discretionary names, Nike is doing well in the face of fiscal and global economic challenges vs. its consumer discretionary peers like McDonald's (MCD) and Coke (KO)."Basketball's Bank ShotThe basketball shoe category was among Nike's fastest growers and strongest performers in the quarter, with double-digit sales gains in North America."Nike has always dominated the basketball business," said John Horan, publisher of Sporting Goods Intelligence, a weekly newsletter. "Clearly we're in a big basketball up-cycle (as) fashion. Nike has been through these up-cycles in basketball before and never has been able to sustain the up-cycle the way it has this one."In this up-cycle, he adds, Nike's product development is much "broader and deeper" than it was before in terms of materials, colors and technology used in designing the shoes, and they're keeping the products new and fresh.He cites the point that Nike has continued to broaden the offerings in its Air Jordan franchise, which the company has "kept bigger than ever, and it's been years since Michael Jordan played his last game."Among the technologies he refers to is Flyknit, a special yarn and computer-controlled weaving method that lets footwear be "engineered to provide a more precise fit for the specific needs of the foot," according to RunningShoesGuru.com.Nike's popular Flyknit athletic shoes are known for comfortable woven uppers that still provide support and come in bright colors and patterns.A Friend In The TrendNike is also benefiting from how athleticwear has become a go-to wardrobe for women and men to sport in most any casual setting. Power brand Under Armour (UA) is also cashing in on this trend."Nike owns this business in theory," said analyst Svezia. "It's the $30 billion gorilla in the market. They have significant market share and scale and have their weight behind them in terms of growing this business. They should do better than anyone else."Drbul is upbeat about Nike's recent performance and prospects."Overall, we think Nike has separated itself from the competition at the greatest level in the history of the company," he said. "They are the creative machine and the innovation they have is second to none. They're hitting on all cylinders with growth in footwear, in apparel and in equipment. There's really very little weakness in its business."In a report, Drbul said he was "encouraged" by Nike's "robust" direct-to-consumer performance in the first quarter, which was driven by a 70% increase in e-commerce and comp growth of 15%.He also noted that the company's efforts to "reset the Chinese market are also clearly paying off."He expects the Greater China region to grow at a low-mid teens rate for the full year.Sozzi expects Nike to be the "winner" in holiday season sales along with Under Armour and the new Apple (AAPL) iPhone 6 and Apple iPhone 6 Plus smartphones.Nike competes with sports apparel outfits such as Under Armour and yoga-inspired clothing company Lululemon (LULU). It's part of IBD's Apparel-Shoes & Retail Manufacturing group, which also includes highly-rated Skechers USA (SKX).
Led by Apple (AAPL) and Microsoft (MSFT), the Nasdaq climbed Wednesday, with upside volume perking up for a second straight day. The S&P 500 was trading at a new high, approaching 2000.
The Nasdaq rose 0.5%, the S&P 500 gained 0.3% and the Dow Jones industrial average was down less than 0.1%.

Both of the tech giants posted earnings after the close Tuesday that cheered investors. Apple rose more than 3% as it neared its all-time high of 100.72. It had corrected 45% during 2013. The company beat earnings estimates but was light on revenue as iPhone and iPad sales flagged and fans panted over the pending release of new products in the fall.
Microsoft rose 1%. Its EPS fell and was below estimates, but revenue surged. The company said commercial cloud sales doubled, but the purchase of Nokia (NOK) assets cut into profit.
In the stock market today, the Dow was shackled by Boeing (BA), down 2%, and McDonald's (MCD), Coca-Cola (KO) and Intel (INTC), each 1% lower. Boeing beat on earnings but missed on revenue.

Among IBD 50 stocks, 37 were up and 13 were down. The star of the day was Biogen (BIIB), which beat Q2 earnings expectations, fueled by sales of its multiple sclerosis treatments. The stock broke out of a cup-with-handle base.
That lifted biotech stocks, which last week the Federal Reserve said had valuations that were "stretched."

PepsiCo (PEP) is going digital. The soft-drink maker is rolling out a high-tech soda fountain that will allow customers to come up with a thousand combinations of drinks to slake their thirst.
"Have you ever dreamed of a raspberry lemon Mountain Dew?" asked the May 15 press release announcing Pepsi Spire, its new beverage dispenser.

CEO Indra Nooyi said Pepsi had heard from restaurant operators that previous fountains were too slow, expensive and required too much worker training. So Spire, which resembles a big iPhone with a touchscreen, seeks to fix that.

The portfolio of three versions of Spire was shown off last week at the National Restaurant Association Show in Chicago. The move indicates that Pepsi might be trying to play digital leapfrog with rival Coca-Cola (KO), which in 2009 launched Coke Freestyle.
PepsiCo sells not only soft drinks but also Frito-Lay snacks, Gatorade, Quaker Oats and Tropicana fruit juice.

Pepsi stock is very near an all-time high. In the company's most recent quarterly earnings report, EPS was up 8%, although analysts are forecasting a 6% decline in the next report. Sales have been running generally flat the past several quarters.
But the company's return on equity is a healthy 29% and pretax margins are running at a 14% clip.
The company's Earnings Stability Factor is 3 on a 0 to 99 scale where low numbers correspond to steady growth.

Pepsi is in the packaged foods industry group, which stands at No. 82 out of 197 as of last week. Four stocks trading at least 12 a share score an RS Rating of 80 or higher, a good sign. Pepsi's RS is mediocre, at 64.

Pepsi pays a quarterly dividend of 65.5 cents a share, which works out to a 3% dividend yield. The dividend was declared May 6 and will be paid June 30 to shareholders of record June 6.PepsiCo (PEP) is going digital. Mild to moderate growth is expected for Keurig Green Mountain (GMCR) as the coffee and tea seller counts its earnings in between holiday gift-buying seasons.

The Waterbury, Vt.-based firm famed for its single-serve K-Cups is expected to earn 95 cents a share, a 2.2% gain from a year earlier, according to analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Revenue is forecast to grow 4.3% to $1.05 billion when it reports its fiscal Q2 earnings Wednesday.

With the Christmas shopping season behind Keurig and the spring gift-buying season for Mother's Day, Father's Day and graduations approaching in the current quarter ending June 30, analysts aren't looking for spectacular gains from the first three months of the calendar year.
"We're not expecting a huge bump up at the moment," said Marc Riddick, a senior analyst at Williams Capital Group. "It's not really what I'd call a gifting season."

Instead, the $1.25 billion equity investment that Coca-Cola (KO) made in Keurig is expected to give the coffee-product maker a firm foothold in the cold-beverage market — and on a global scale. Keurig is looking overseas to Australia, South Korea and Sweden to expand its brand.
Keurig shares closed down 1.9% to 90.61 Friday.

As for Keurig's competitors, potential or real, SodaStream (SODA) has been the subject of merger rumors, including a merger with Starbucks (SBUX). SodaStream shares are down 15% so far this year to 42.21.

Monster Beverage (MNST) reports earnings Thursday and is expected to earn 49 cents a share, up 32.4% from a year earlier. Revenue is expected to post a 12.3% gain to $543.6 million. Shares are down 1.3% so far this year and also are down 10.5% from a 52-week high on Feb. 21.Mild to moderate growth is expected for Keurig Green Mountain (GMCR) as the coffee and tea seller counts its earnings in between holiday gift-buying seasons.The Waterbury, Vt.-based firm famed for its single-serve K-Cups is expected to earn 95 cents a share, a 2.2% gain from a year earlier, according to analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Stocks wavered to a narrowly mixed finish in the stock market today.The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.1% and the S&P 500 ticked up a fraction. Both hit record highs. They were up as much as 0.2% and 0.3%, intraday. The Nasdaq slipped 0.3%, hurt by software and chip-equipment makers.Volume edged slightly lower on the NYSE and rose on the Nasdaq exchange, according to preliminary dataDespite the major indexes ending little change, some leading stocks had decisive moves.Keurig Green Mountain (GMCR) gapped up and surged 8% in heavy volume on news that Coca-Cola (KO) raised its stake in the company to 16% from 10%. The stock is getting closer to a potential buy point at 124.52 in a consolidation.McKesson (MCK) gapped up and climbed 3% in reaction to late Monday's better-than-expected fiscal Q4 results. The distributor of drugs and medical supplies reported earnings that jumped 72% to $2.55 a share. Sales rose 25% to $38.1 billion. Those were its biggest gains in years.The stock has retaken its 50-day moving average as it works on a flat base with a 188.12 buy point.WhiteWave Foods (WWAV) rallied nearly 3% to a record high. It cleared 30.56 buy point from a flat base in more than twice its average volume. Tuesday marked its fourth straight gain in above-average volume.Denver-based WhiteWave makes plant-based foods and drinks. It's the company behind the Silk brand of almond milk and soy milk. It has delivered accelerating growth in earnings and sales in the latest two quarters.On the downside, HollySys Automation Technologies (HOLI) lost 3% in heavy trading after reversing lower. The stock met resistance at its 50-day line. The Chinese provider of automation and control systems will report fiscal Q3 earnings Wednesday. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters see profit rising 24% to 26 cents a share.The NAHB housing market index will be out Wednesday. Kate Spade (KATE), Macy's (M), NetEase (NTES), and WuXi PharmaTech (WX) are some notable companies reporting earnings Wednesday.

Coca-Cola became the largest shareholder of Keurig Green Mountain (GMCR) by boosting its share in the coffee-brewer manufacturer to 16%, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.The move comes three months after Coca-Cola (KO) bought a 10% stake in the Waterbury, Vt.-based coffee company, whose shares were up nearly 10% to 121.43 on the stock market today.Atlantic Industries, a Coca-Cola subsidiary, currently controls approximately 26 million shares in Keurig. Coca-Cola owns about 19.5 million shares in Keurig and has the right to buy an additional 6.5 million shares if it so chooses.Coca-Cola's shares rose 0.8% to 41.15.Coke is Keurig's partner for cold beverages for a new cold brewing machine in production. The Keurig cold machine could threaten home carbonated drink maker SodaStream (SODA), whose shares fell nearly 3% to 40.56 intraday.Some reports have said Starbucks (SBUX) could take a stake in the Israeli-based SodaStream. There's also speculation of an alliance with PepsiCo (PEP).
Stocks notched a solid open Tuesday, with tech and transportation stocks leading and energy and mining issues bringing up the rear.
The Nasdaq climbed 0.5%. The S&P 500 added 0.4% and the Dow Jones industrial average tacked on a 0.3% gain.
Volume was briskly mixed in the stock market today, up 28% on the Nasdaq and down 20% on the NYSE, the inverse of early trading action on Monday.

Air transport issues, led by FedEx (FDX) and United Parcel Service (UPS), notched the best early gains among the 197 industry groups tracked by IBD. Gold, coal and oil groups posted the five worst losses on the list.
The Commerce Department reported construction spending surged 1.1% in October. That reversed a revised 0.1% decline for September and easily outpaced economist expectations for a 0.5% increase.

Early stock action showedBiogen (BIIB) skipping up 5% after the company reported positive results from a phase 1b study of its Alzheimer's Treatment, and plans to aggressively move into a phase 3 trial. The gain lifted shares back above their converged 10- and 40-week moving averages, but left the stock still within a three-month consolidation.

Cypress Semiconductor (CY) powered up 17% and punched to a 16-month high after agreeing to be acquired by Sunnyvale, Calif.-based Spansion (CODE) in an all-stock deal valued at $4 billion. Cypress shares have been wallowing in a consolidation since mid-2013. Spansion shares fired ahead 24%, well into new highs.
Among leaders, Ambarella (AMBA) and Celgene (CELG) jumped to the front of the IBD list.

Ambarella popped 3% at the start of trade, retaking a portion of its 8% tumble taken on Monday. The video chip maker is trading 9% below Friday's high, and extended after a strong October rebound from 10-week support.

While big brands have always advertised on mainstream platforms using athletes and movie actors, they're expanding onto new social platforms like Vine and featuring a new group of celebrities: Internet stars.
In an increasingly mobile- and Internet-driven entertainment era, media firms and retail brands are digging their heels deeper into cyberspace to woo customers and stay relevant.

"It's the wave of the future," FBR Capital Markets analyst Susan Anderson told IBD. "If you do not have a good e-commerce presence, then you're not going to win out over the longer term. (Brands) have to have an online presence."
Evidence of the new era appears daily. For example:
 Walt Disney (DIS) recently agreed to fork over $500 million for Maker Studios, a multichannel network that works with YouTube channels and content creators as a production company.
 Yahoo (YHOO) bid $250 million for Fullscreen, a multichannel network that boasts 3 billion monthly views and helps artists "build (their) brand" online.
 YouTube makeup guru Michelle Phan stars in traditional TV ads for Dr Pepper (DPS).
Most Video From YouTube

Advertisers poured an estimated $5.6 billion into YouTube in 2013, says research firm eMarketer, which predicts that figure will rise 28.5% this year to $7.2 billion. And a new survey from Adroit Digital says 68% of viewers say they "consume video content" from YouTube vs. only 51% for live TV broadcasts.
In a separate study, Adroit found TV and social clear winners in a poll of the most influential ad medium, where "traditional media outside of TV fell flat."

Brands attempting to conquer savvy customers via social media know that simply running a banner ad isn't enough. Twitter (TWTR), Facebook (FB), Instagram and other platforms engage in "native" ads made to look like user content. And more companies have started hiring online celebrities to star in their ads.

Engaging in social media "is a good way to get your brand out there," said FBR's Anderson. "The teen consumer now looks to social media to find what she likes or what she wants. It's something brands can't ignore."

Social-media ad agency startup Niche, which has raised $3 million in venture funding, has worked with brands such as CBS Films, Gap (GAP) and Oral-B. It connects content creators with companies looking to advertise across platforms.

But instead of hiring paid actors and writers, Niche's client companies let online personalities feature their products right within their Vine videos or Instagram photos in a way that feels organic. So the advertising, in fact, is part of the content.

Cody Johns, Niche's creative ambassador — that's his job title — is a social media celebrity who has 2.2 million followers on Twitter (TWTR)-owned Vine. He's built a name for himself creating six-second videos that the platform is known for. Since joining Niche, Johns says he's teamed up with at least 25 brands, conceiving and scripting short ads/videos that employ his signature sense of humor and style.

In a recent Vine ad/video for Coca-Cola (KO), he riffs on the company's existing "Share a Coke" campaign by skateboarding alongside a car to share his bottle with the attractive girl in the driver's seat. Since the video was posted on July 1, it's had more than 1.5 million "loops," or plays.

"(Brands) are thrilled with this kind of engagement because they're used to purchasing banner ads that no one clicks," said Niche co-founder Rob Fishman. "These perform incredibly well. We've never run a campaign where the results didn't over-deliver by a high margin."

When many viewers can't bear to even watch a 30-second YouTube ad, this kind of in-video product placement is a boon for advertisers. According to Adroit, 56% of surveyed viewers over 18 said they skip online video ads most of the time on sites that let viewers skip ads.

"Forever skipping all youtube ads." That's how Johns characterized his viewing habits in a recent tweet to his 116,000-plus Twitter followers. YouTube ads are "annoying and not creative," Johns told IBD.
But of his spots on Vine, he said subscribers ask questions like, "Was this a Coke ad?", because they can't tell the difference between ads and user content.
As Niche's Fishman put it, "Everything we do is linked. The advertisement is the content and the content is the advertisement."
Aeropostale, Bethany Mota

Struggling teen retailer Aeropostale (ARO) partnered with YouTube star Bethany Mota late last year, even giving the 18-year-old, who has her own YouTube channel, a branded in-store collection of shirts, leggings and accessories.

Mota is known for her "haul videos," in which she reviews the contents of her shopping trips with her 6.5 million YouTube subscribers. The company is betting that viewers' love for the wholesome California teen extends to Aeropostale apparel.

"With its Bethany Mota collection, ARO captured new customers to the brand," said a recent FBR Capital research report. "We expect ARO to continue to introduce sub brands in order to drive exclusivity and to supplement these products with social media efforts."

Though it's hard to quantify results this early, social-media marketing seems to be getting results. EMarketer says 88% of U.S. marketers will use social media in their marketing this year, up from 87% a year earlier.

"It's probably hard to measure in terms of how much of that has driven incremental sales," said FBR's Anderson, "but it makes logical sense that if consumers are following you on Facebook or your website or (are in) your loyalty database, then they should be purchasing more from you."While big brands have always advertised on mainstream platforms using athletes and movie actors, they're expanding onto new social platforms like Vine and featuring a new group of celebrities: Internet stars.In an increasingly mobile- and Internet-driven entertainment era, media firms and retail brands are digging their heels deeper into cyberspace to woo customers and stay relevant."It's the wave of the future," FBR Capital Markets analyst Susan Anderson told IBD. "If you do not have a good e-commerce presence, then you're not going to win out over the longer term. (Brands) have to have an online presence."Evidence of the new era appears daily. For example: Walt Disney (DIS) recently agreed to fork over $500 million for Maker Studios, a multichannel network that works with YouTube channels and content creators as a production company. Yahoo (YHOO) bid $250 million for Fullscreen, a multichannel network that boasts 3 billion monthly views and helps artists "build (their) brand" online. YouTube makeup guru Michelle Phan stars in traditional TV ads for Dr Pepper (DPS).Most Video From YouTubeAdvertisers poured an estimated $5.6 billion into YouTube in 2013, says research firm eMarketer, which predicts that figure will rise 28.5% this year to $7.2 billion. And a new survey from Adroit Digital says 68% of viewers say they "consume video content" from YouTube vs. only 51% for live TV broadcasts.In a separate study, Adroit found TV and social clear winners in a poll of the most influential ad medium, where "traditional media outside of TV fell flat."Brands attempting to conquer savvy customers via social media know that simply running a banner ad isn't enough. Twitter (TWTR), Facebook (FB), Instagram and other platforms engage in "native" ads made to look like user content. And more companies have started hiring online celebrities to star in their ads.Engaging in social media "is a good way to get your brand out there," said FBR's Anderson. "The teen consumer now looks to social media to find what she likes or what she wants. It's something brands can't ignore."Social-media ad agency startup Niche, which has raised $3 million in venture funding, has worked with brands such as CBS Films, Gap (GAP) and Oral-B. It connects content creators with companies looking to advertise across platforms.But instead of hiring paid actors and writers, Niche's client companies let online personalities feature their products right within their Vine videos or Instagram photos in a way that feels organic. So the advertising, in fact, is part of the content.Cody Johns, Niche's creative ambassador — that's his job title — is a social media celebrity who has 2.2 million followers on Twitter (TWTR)-owned Vine. He's built a name for himself creating six-second videos that the platform is known for. Since joining Niche, Johns says he's teamed up with at least 25 brands, conceiving and scripting short ads/videos that employ his signature sense of humor and style.In a recent Vine ad/video for Coca-Cola (KO), he riffs on the company's existing "Share a Coke" campaign by skateboarding alongside a car to share his bottle with the attractive girl in the driver's seat. Since the video was posted on July 1, it's had more than 1.5 million "loops," or plays."(Brands) are thrilled with this kind of engagement because they're used to purchasing banner ads that no one clicks," said Niche co-founder Rob Fishman. "These perform incredibly well. We've never run a campaign where the results didn't over-deliver by a high margin."When many viewers can't bear to even watch a 30-second YouTube ad, this kind of in-video product placement is a boon for advertisers. According to Adroit, 56% of surveyed viewers over 18 said they skip online video ads most of the time on sites that let viewers skip ads."Forever skipping all youtube ads." That's how Johns characterized his viewing habits in a recent tweet to his 116,000-plus Twitter followers. YouTube ads are "annoying and not creative," Johns told IBD.But of his spots on Vine, he said subscribers ask questions like, "Was this a Coke ad?", because they can't tell the difference between ads and user content.As Niche's Fishman put it, "Everything we do is linked. The advertisement is the content and the content is the advertisement."Aeropostale, Bethany MotaStruggling teen retailer Aeropostale (ARO) partnered with YouTube star Bethany Mota late last year, even giving the 18-year-old, who has her own YouTube channel, a branded in-store collection of shirts, leggings and accessories.Mota is known for her "haul videos," in which she reviews the contents of her shopping trips with her 6.5 million YouTube subscribers. The company is betting that viewers' love for the wholesome California teen extends to Aeropostale apparel."With its Bethany Mota collection, ARO captured new customers to the brand," said a recent FBR Capital research report. "We expect ARO to continue to introduce sub brands in order to drive exclusivity and to supplement these products with social media efforts."Though it's hard to quantify results this early, social-media marketing seems to be getting results. EMarketer says 88% of U.S. marketers will use social media in their marketing this year, up from 87% a year earlier."It's probably hard to measure in terms of how much of that has driven incremental sales," said FBR's Anderson, "but it makes logical sense that if consumers are following you on Facebook or your website or (are in) your loyalty database, then they should be purchasing more from you."

Amazon.com (AMZN) topped the list of companies with the highest U.S. public reputation in the 2014 Harris Poll Reputation Quotient study released Tuesday. The survey queries more than 18,000 people to measure the reputations of what Harris called the 60 most visible companies in the U.S.
Amazon came in with an overall score of 83.87, with scores above 80 considered "excellent" by the polling company.

Amazon dominated three of the six "reputation categories" in the study, with scores above 80 in: emotional appeal; products and services; and workplace environment. It also had high marks for trust, admiration and respect; high quality products and services; and being a good place to work. Harris said it was Amazon's sixth consecutive year with an excellent rating.
The other top companies were Coca-Cola (KO), Whole Foods Market (WFM) and Honda Motor (HMC).

Among tech companies, Samsung landed in 7th place and achieved its first ever excellent rating of over 80. Microsoft (MSFT) jumped to No. 9 from No. 15 last year, achieving its 11th excellent rating in the last 15 years.
RELATED:

Stocks rolled up early gains in weak trade, as soft economic news did little to coax investors off the sidelines.
The S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average scrambled ahead 0.4%. The Nasdaq fought to hold a fractional gain.
Volume opened on weak footing, with the Nasdaq trading 19% lower and the NYSE down 13% compared with early trade Monday.
The stock market today opened to comments from Federal Reserve Chairwoman Janet Yellen, speaking in a video recording played before an Atlanta Federal Reserve conference.

The Fed chief made a case for big banks to fortify themselves by setting aside more capital than recommended by recently upgraded Fed standards. Yellen also said the international banking standards, made more rigid following the 2008 financial crisis, "do not fully address the financial stability concerns associated with short-term wholesale funding," and that the Fed was "actively considering additional measures that could address these and other residual risks."
A bump up in inflation, driven primarily by an increase in housing costs, pushed the March Consumer Price Index up 0.2% — more than expected.

Despite the suggestion of stronger housing prices, the National Association of Homebuilders reported that its April Housing Market Index sat flat at 47. The group revised its March number lower, to 46 from 47, so the April result was a de facto gain. The index showed builder confidence relatively steady, but below 50 for a third straight month and still well below levels posted in July through January.

In stocks, Coca-Cola (KO) batted out a 3% gain after reporting its first-quarter earnings, leading the Dow. A handful of recently battered biotech stocks rebounded in early action. Gilead Sciences (GILD) and Biogen Idec (BIIB) bounced 3% in big trade to top the Nasdaq 100. But both stocks remain weakened.

Leading stocks again posted broad gains at the open. More than four in five IBD 50 stocks rose out of the starting gate. Among the early risers, touch-sensor technology developer Synaptics (SYNA) jumped 2% in mild trade. The stock drifted below the 10-week moving average in back-and-forth action begun March 24 and is seven weeks into a consolidation.Stocks rolled up early gains in weak trade, as soft economic news did little to coax investors off the sidelines.The S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average scrambled ahead 0.4%.
