Stock futures showed healthy gains early Tuesday as Europe's markets rebounded, oil prices recovered from lows, and economic news was fair to positive.

Dow futures traded 75.5 points above fair market value, down from 100.5 points an hour earlier. Nasdaq 100 futures added to early gains and were up 29.1 points. S&P 500 futures moved up 11.7 points, even with hour-earlier levels.

The stock market today has its eye on Wednesday afternoon as the Federal Open Market Committee members head into their two-day powwow. Expectations are high for a policy shift when the group announces its decision on Wednesday at 2 p.m. ET.

Consumer prices were flat in November, the Labor Department reported. That was down from a 0.2% gain in October and in line with economist expectations. Core prices, minus food and energy, rose 0.2% — equal to October's increase and meeting consensus projections.

Manufacturing activity in the New York region slowed at an improved rate in December, according to the New York Federal Reserve's Empire State Manufacturing Survey. It showed a -4.6 performance vs. a -10.7 showing in November. That was better than the -7 reading expected by economists.
At 10 a.m., the National Association of Home Builders releases its builder confidence index. The Treasury Department reports long-term Treasury international capital flow for October at 4 p.m.

Oil prices took a modest bounce in early trade, lifting West Texas Intermediate less than 1% and Brent crude more than 1%, although still trading below $37 and $39 a barrel, respectively. That, and the late-day recovery of U.S. markets on Monday, fed a rebound across European markets. The leading indexes bounced up from 10-week lows, sending the DAX in Frankfurt and the CAC-40 in Paris up more than 2% near midday.

In stocks, miners and steel markets were rebounding, with issues like Vale (VALE) up 5% and Arcelor-Mittal (MT) ahead more than 4%. On the Dow, diversified operator 3M (MMM) — the old Minnesota Mining & Manufacturing Co., tanked more than 4% after lowering its 2015 earnings guidance. Chevron (CVX) topped the index in premarket trade with a 0.8% gain.
3M also notched the worst loss among S&P 500 stocks. F5 Networks (FFIV) took the second hardest hit, down a bit more than 2%.
Chipmaker Nvidia (NVDA), Newell Rubbermaid (NWL) and Southwestern Energy (SWN) topped the list, all up better than 3%.

Flooring retailer Lumber Liquidators (LL) bolted 27% higher after news reports detailed a letter from Kase Capital Management Managing Partner Whitney Tilson, declaring that he had covered his short position against the stock.

Tilson had weighed in against the company following allegations that some of its flooring contained unsafe levels of formaldehyde. Tilson concluded that management probably did not know about the problem, according to Bloomberg, which means "the company was sloppy and naive, but not evil," Tilson wrote. The stock ended Monday down 80% since news of the investigation broke in February.

Leading stocks stuck to moderate moves in premarket action. Hawaiian (HA) topped the IBD 50 list, up slightly more than 1% in premarket trade. Coca-Cola's  (KO) fiscal first-quarter sales declined vs. the same quarter last year amid a global soft-drink sales slump. But Coke shares spiked early Tuesday as investors rewarded it for beating sales expectations and meeting Wall Street's profit target. The world's largest soft-drink maker reported a 4% drop in year-over-year revenue to $10.58 billion, edging views of $10.55 billion. It…

Even though soda consumption continues to fizzle, beverage bottler Coca-Cola Enterprises (CCE) is still showing some pockets of strength. Consumption of carbonated soft drinks fell 3% in 2013, according to Beverage Digest. That marks the ninth straight drop. Coca-Cola Enterprises, one of the world's biggest bottlers of Coca-Cola products, has seen strength in Coke Zero and energy drinks. Sales of…

The market bounced back Thursday, closing near session highs as it now sets its sights on Friday's employment report.The Nasdaq rose 0.2%, while the S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average closed flat after working their way back from significant losses. It was a positive reversal for the stock market today. Volume was lower across the board, although above average, preliminary data showed.Transportation stocks rolled along. Canadian Pacific (CP) jumped 5%, rising from support at the 50-day moving average, in heavy volume. At an investor conference late Wednesday, the railroad set aggressive targets, including more than doubling its earnings per share over the next four years and increasing annual revenue to $10 billion in 2018.On Friday, the government's employment report for September headlines the economic calendar. The consensus estimate is for an increase of 215,000 nonfarm jobs and the unemployment rate staying at 6.1%, according to Econoday.The report will be announced at 8:30 a.m. ET. The ISM services gauge will be out at 10 a.m. ET.

Shares soared for SodaStream (SODA) after a report surfaced that Starbucks (SBUX) is in advanced talks to buy 10% of the Israel-based home carbonation products business. SodaStream shares rose nearly 14% to 46.03 on the stock market today on the news. Starbucks reportedly is willing to pay $1.1 billion — a 30% premium, according to "Globes," an Israeli business publication.…
Senomyx's (SNMX) new flavor ingredient was approved by regulators Tuesday, giving fans of Pepsico (PEP) drinks more options for lower-calorie drinks.
The Food and Drug Administration said Sweetmyx is safe for consumption by humans, allowing beverages containing the ingredient to find their way to store shelves as soon as this year.
The flavor ingredient enhances sweet flavors like sucrose or fructose so fewer sweeteners are needed in drinks.
Pepsi has exclusive rights to Sweetmyx in nonalcoholic drinks, and the Swiss company Firmenich has the rights to commercialize the flavor for food and alcoholic beverages.
Senomyx shares soared 26% on the stock market today, its highest level since 2008. Pepsi rose 1%.
"The new Sweetmyx flavor ingredient will enable the creation of lower-calorie beverages and foods that have reduced sweeteners without sacrificing taste," Senomyx CEO John Poyhonen told Reuters.
Americans' taste for sweet beverages like soda has soured in recent years as people become more health conscious and favor flavored waters, teas and energy drinks.

But Coca-Cola (KO), Dr Pepper Snapple (DPS) and Pepsi have expanded their offerings beyond just sodas and diet sodas. Coke Zero, Dr Pepper Ten and Pepsi Max are all lower-calorie variations with less sugar but a more natural flavor than diet drinks flavored with pure aspartame.

Sweetmyx isn't the only soda ingredient making headlines. Stevia has been a popular sugar substitute in recent years, and Coke's new stevia- and sugar-sweetened Coca-Cola Life has performed well in test markets in Chile and Argentina. Last month, Coke said it would begin distributing the beverage in other, unspecified markets.

The stock market closed higher Thursday, although indexes pared gains.
The Nasdaq climbed 0.8% while the S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average added 0.5%.
Volume rose on the NYSE, but fell on the Nasdaq, according to early figures. Advancing stocks led decliners by 7-to-5 on the Nasdaq, but winners barely edged out losers on the NYSE.
Computer, trucking and financials ranked among the day's top performing sectors. Retail, metals and energy stocks lagged.
A weak forecast sent a chill through homebuilding stocks in the stock market today.

Meritage Homes (MTH) cut its forecast for 2015 earnings, citing rising labor costs, delays in closings and slower-than-expected business in the company's newer markets in the Southeast. The stock fell 9% in heavy trading, to the lowest level since early February.

"There are shortages of skilled labor in many markets as subcontractors struggle to catch up with the increased demand of a continued recovery in homebuilding," said Chairman and CEO Steven J. Hilton. Competition for labor is raising costs and lengthening construction times, his statement added. Bad weather in parts of Texas and Colorado further hurt the company.
The homebuilders' industry group, which has been a market leader, was one of the worst 20 groups Thursday out of 197 that IBD tracks.

One of the day's biggest losers was Lululemon Athletica (LULU), which plunged 16% after the yoga-styled apparel chain guided Q3 and full-year earnings below expectations. Shares fell to the lowest level since December.
Google (GOOGL) rose 1% and shares continued to rise from support at the 50-day moving average. But volume in Google was light.
After the close, shares of action sports retailer Zumiez (ZUMZ) slid after the company announced quarterly results. The stock closed regular trading near a 52-week low.

Stocks rallied for a fourth straight session Tuesday, extending recent rebound efforts amid a heavy batch of earnings reports.Apple (AAPL), which reported better-than-expected quarterly results late Monday, helped boost the Nasdaq to a 2.4% gain. The S&P 500 jumped 2%, regaining its 200-day moving average. Hurt by losses in IBM (IBM) and Coca-Cola (KO), the Dow Jones industrial average lagged with a 1.3% advance. The genetic-sequencing firm also lifted its full-year earnings outlook. Stocks advanced Friday, but the gains came in declining volume. The Nasdaq added 1%, while the S&P; 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average rose 1.3% and 1.6%, respectively. The IBD 50 checked in with a 1.4% pop. Volume fell across the board. The gains in the indexes were primarily the result of a strong start. The Nasdaq was up…

After news media reported incorrectly that Sweetmyx had received FDA approval Tuesday, Senomyx (SNMX) issued a new statement on Wednesday explaining that the safety designation was issued by a third party, the Expert Panel of the Flavor and Extract Manufacturers Association of the United States.

The GRAS, Generally Recognized As Safe, designation means the product can be consumed by humans. GRAS determinations can be made without notifying the FDA. IBD and other media incorrectly reported the FDA had issued its approval.
Shares popped 26% on Tuesday after the misleading news that Sweetmyx got regulatory approval, but shares moved down 5% in the stock market Thursday.
The Sweetmyx artificial ingredient enhances sweet flavors like sucrose or fructose so fewer sweeteners are needed in drinks, Senomyx said.
Pepsi has exclusive rights to Sweetmyx in nonalcoholic drinks, and the Swiss company Firmenich has the rights to commercialize the flavor for food and alcoholic beverages.

"The new Sweetmyx flavor ingredient will enable the creation of lower-calorie beverages and foods that have reduced sweeteners without sacrificing taste," Senomyx CEO John Poyhonen told Reuters Tuesday.

Sweetmyx isn't the only soda ingredient making headlines. Stevia has been a popular sugar substitute in recent years, and Coke's new stevia- and sugar-sweetened Coca-Cola Life has performed well in test markets in Chile and Argentina. Last month, Coke said it would begin distributing the beverage in other, unspecified markets.

Follow Gillian Rich on Twitter at @IBD_GRichAfter news media reported incorrectly that Sweetmyx had received FDA approval Tuesday, Senomyx (SNMX) issued a new statement on Wednesday explaining that the safety designation was issued by a third party, the Expert Panel of the Flavor and Extract Manufacturers Association of the United States.The GRAS, Generally Recognized As Safe, designation means the product can be consumed by humans. GRAS determinations can be made without notifying the FDA. IBD and other media incorrectly reported the FDA had issued its approval.Shares popped 26% on Tuesday after the misleading news that Sweetmyx got regulatory approval, but shares moved down 5% in the stock market Thursday.The Sweetmyx artificial ingredient enhances sweet flavors like sucrose or fructose so fewer sweeteners are needed in drinks, Senomyx said.Pepsi has exclusive rights to Sweetmyx in nonalcoholic drinks, and the Swiss company Firmenich has the rights to commercialize the flavor for food and alcoholic beverages."The new Sweetmyx flavor ingredient will enable the creation of lower-calorie beverages and foods that have reduced sweeteners without sacrificing taste," Senomyx CEO John Poyhonen told Reuters Tuesday.Americans' taste for sweet beverages including soda has soured in recent years as people become more health conscious and favor flavored waters, teas and energy drinks.But Coca-Cola (KO), Dr Pepper Snapple (DPS) and Pepsi have expanded their offerings beyond just sodas and diet sodas. Coke Zero, Dr Pepper Ten and Pepsi Max are all lower-calorie variations with less sugar, but with a more natural flavor than diet drinks flavored with pure aspartame.Sweetmyx isn't the only soda ingredient making headlines. Stevia has been a popular sugar substitute in recent years, and Coke's new stevia- and sugar-sweetened Coca-Cola Life has performed well in test markets in Chile and Argentina. Last month, Coke said it would begin distributing the beverage in other, unspecified markets.Follow Gillian Rich on Twitter at @IBD_GRich

Hurt by slowing sales, soda makers are rushing to find sugar substitutes as consumers increasingly shun highly sweetened beverages. But flat revenue hasn't affected one drink maker's stock. Shares of Dr Pepper Snapple Group (DPS) have been trading at or near new-high ground since mid-February, when they cleared a long base in heavy trade. The Plano, Texas-based company on Feb.…

SodaStream (SODA) shares lost their fizz after Barclay's questioned the in-home beverage maker's ability to handle competition Monday, despite a new deal with Sunny Delight.Barclay's downgraded SodaStream to equal weight from overweight on new competition and distribution concerns and cut SodaStream's price target to $40 from $55.Shares fell 1.22% on the stock market today.SodaStream has been under pressure recently to ink more partnership pacts after Green Mountain Coffee Roasters (GMCR) announced a deal with Coca-Cola (KO) on Feb. 5 to produce a cold beverage maker.Some analysts have speculated that SodaStream could reach a deal with PepsiCo (PEP). SodaStream already dominates the home cold-beverage machine market and has an existing network for selling and refilling the carbon dioxide canisters, according to an earlier report by Citron Research.On Monday, the company announced a deal with Sunny Delight to make the SunnyD Tangy Original Orange, Orange-Strawberry and other flavors exclusively for the SodaStream's system. Financial terms were not disclosed, but drinks will be available in the second half of 2014 in the U.S.SunnyD joins Kraft's Country Time Lemonade as partners with SodaStream. In February, SodaStream announced a deal with TV personality Bethenny Frankel's Skinny Girl line of low-calorie beverages.Meantime, the company is getting over a rough promotional holiday shopping season that shrank its margins. Last week, SodaStream reported a 91.7% drop in Q4 earnings, but still beat analysts expectations. Revenue climbed 26.4% and also beat.Follow Gillian Rich on Twitter at @IBD_GRich.

SodaStream (SODA) reported a sharp drop in earnings Wednesday but still topped analyst estimates. The in-home soda maker's shares are bubbling up, after flattening for days in the wake of a deal between Coca-Cola (KO) and Green Mountain Coffee Roasters (GMCR).The Israeli company reported a 91.7% drop in fourth-quarter earnings to 3 cents per share. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters were expecting EPS of 1 cent. Revenue climbed 26.4% to $168.1 million, above estimates for $167.3 million.The company had warned on earnings in January.Revenue rose in all geographic regions during the quarter. Sales in the Americas unit rose 16% and 38% in Western Europe. Asia-Pacific sales were up 28% and Middle East and Africa sales were up 36%.Gross margin narrowed to 42.4% vs. 53.0% in the year-ago quarter on lower than average prices due largely to year-end discounting and promotions.SodaStream said in its earnings release that the fourth-quarter was "more challenging" than expected. The company is expecting a 15% increase in 2014 revenue with implied sales of $647.11 million. Analysts are expecting $657.16 million.Shares rose 6.25% to 41.52 in early afternoon trading in the stock market today. SodaStream shares tumbled on Feb. 5 after Green Mountain, the maker of Keurig single-serve coffee makers, and Coke announced a deal to produce a cold beverage maker.But analysts turned positive on the deal after the initial downturn on speculation that PepsiCo (PEP) could form its own deal with SodaStream, bringing back the soda wars. SodaStream already dominates in the home cold-beverage market and has an existing network for selling and refilling the carbon dioxide canisters, according to Citron Research.Citigroup analyst Wendy Nicholson said Coke's partnership with Green Mountain brings validity to the in-home beverage-making sector. She adds that the visibility of Coke and Green Mountain's new cold brewing machine could boost SodaStream sales as consumers look for other options.Follow Gillian Rich on Twitter at @IBD_GRich.
After an uncertain open, the stock market rallied Tuesday, up modestly by midday.
The Nasdaq rose 0.4%, the S&P 500 was up 0.2% and the Dow Jones gained 0.1%. Volume was up on the Nasdaq, but down on the NYSE.

Among IBD 50 stocks, Myriad Genetics (MYGN) gapped down in heavy volume and was off nearly 10%. The company said a Utah court denied its application for a preliminary injunction against Ambry Genetics. Myriad accused it of patent infringement over breast cancer tests.

Green Mountain Coffee Roasters changed its name to Keurig Green Mountain (GMCR), effective immediately. The company's Keurig single-serve cups have been a big hit as they have rolled out across the country. The stock was up nearly 4% in heavy volume. The stock has pulled back from an all-time high. It gapped up out of a cup-with-handle base Feb. 6 after announcing a global partnership with Coca-Cola (KO).
In the stock market today, Urban Outfitters (URBN) dropped nearly 5% in huge volume after reporting results. Same-store sales dropped.

Shares of Dick's Sporting Goods (DKS) were up 3% in heavy volume after the company reported results. EPS and sales were both up 8%. It may be forming a base, but the stock has become a laggard.After an uncertain open, the stock market rallied Tuesday, up modestly by midday.The Nasdaq rose 0.4%, the S&P 500 was up 0.2% and the Dow Jones gained 0.1%. Coca-Cola (KO) shares fell Tuesday after the beverage giant reported declining fourth-quarter sales in North America. The maker of Sprite, Powerade and Dasani water said Q4 earnings rose 2.2% to 46 cents a share, matching estimates of analysts polled by Thompson Reuters. Revenue dipped 3.7% to $11.04 billion, under estimates for $11.31 billion. Shares fell 3.7% to 37.47 in the…
PepsiCo (PEP) gave out a solid Q3 report before the open Thursday, beating estimates on both the top and bottom lines and raising full-year guidance.
The stock gapped up early, rising to a new all-time high, although a weak market submarined the stock later in the day.
Pepsi earned $1.36 a share, a 10% increase from the year-ago quarter. Analysts' forecast was for $1.29. Revenue climbed 2% to $17.2 billion vs. estimates of $17 billion.

The company credited margin improvement for the good numbers, even though American beverage sales were flat and Europe dipped 1%. Sales of Frito-Lay North America rose 3% while South American food sales rose 6%.
Gross margins were 53.6%, an increase of 45 basis points vs. a year ago. The company says productivity savings and cost cutting has helped along with smarter pricing.
Pepsi now expects 9% full-year EPS growth compared with an earlier estimate of 8%. Analysts expect 5% this year and 7% in 2015.
Earlier this month, Pepsi announced the launch of Pepsi True, a Stevia-sweetened drink that will initially be available only on Amazon.com (AMZN). It will later be available in grocery stores.
Soft-drink makers have been a good place to be for income investors seeking slow but steady growth for some time.
Coca-Cola (KO) and Dr Pepper Snapple (DPS) have also been rallying smartly.
Dr Pepper has been the top performer, outperforming 95% of the stocks in the market over the last year.
Pepsi pays a 65.5-cent quarterly dividend. That works out to a 2.8% annualized yield. The last dividend was paid Sept. 30.

Pepsi's five-year annualized EPS growth rate is 4% and the Earnings Stability Factor is 3 on a 0 to 99 scale where low numbers correspond to stable earnings growth.PepsiCo (PEP) gave out a solid Q3 report before the open Thursday, beating estimates on both the top and bottom lines and raising full-year guidance.The stock gapped up early, rising to a new all-time high, although a weak market submarined the stock later in the day.Pepsi earned $1.36 a share, a 10% increase from the year-ago quarter. McDonald's didn't try to supersize its disappointing third-quarter results Tuesday, with its CEO saying the fast food giant must "fundamentally change." But winning over new diners without alienating its existing base won't be easy.

The world's No. 1 restaurant operator earned $1.35 excluding a 26-cent tax-related charge for an unfavorable foreign court ruling. That's down 11% vs. a year earlier. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected $1.37.
Revenue fell 4.6% to $6.99 billion, below views of $7.18 billion.

U.S. and global same-store sales fell 3.3% vs. a year earlier, reflecting a decline in guest traffic, meat supplier issues in Asia and blowback from tensions between Russia and the West over Ukraine. Slowing economies in China and Europe didn't help.
McDonald's (MCD) stock fell 0.6% to 91.01 after hitting 89.70 intraday.

President and CEO Don Thompson didn't attempt to spin the results, saying they "reflect a significant decline from a year ago" and promising "decisive action to fundamentally change the way we approach our business."
More Local Tastes Planned
Thompson stressed plans for more menu choices, more local autonomy in the U.S. to cater to customers' tastes, and modernizing decor and technology.
McDonald's has introduced Apple (AAPL) Pay mobile payment technology at 14,000 U.S. locations and added self-order kiosks in France, Australia and elsewhere, he said.

The burger giant also launched an advertising campaign letting people make fun of and ask what's in McDonald's food, which many young adults see as unhealthy compared to fast-casual fare from Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) and Panera Bread (PNRA). (Chipotle shares fell 7% Tuesday despite reporting blowout earnings late Monday, mostly on concerns that growth must slow.)
But raising the quality of McDonald's food would hit customers in their wallets.
"It is very hard to do that without raising the prices," said Lynne Collier, an analyst at Sterne, Agee & Leach. "It's not going to be an easy fix."
McDonald's prices already rose 3% in the 12 months to June 30.
Low-income consumers, a mainstay of fast-food eateries, were hit hard by the Great Recession and continue to struggle amid a sluggish recovery.
Yum, Coke Also Struggle

Yum Brands (YUM), parent of KFC, Pizza Hut and Taco Bell, earlier this month issued disappointing quarterly earnings and full-year guidance. Much of that reflects continued fallout from China's meat scandal on KFC there. But the fast-food operator also has struggled to win over U.S. customers with higher-quality fare.

Coca-Cola (KO) shares suffered their biggest intraday loss since 2008, falling 6% to 40.68 after reporting soft Q3 earnings Tuesday. The soda king, like Yum and McDonald's, is coping with an economic slowdown overseas and health concerns at home.
McDonald's remains a well-liked dividend stock with a long-track record as one of the great U.S. business success stories.
"They are a powerful cash flow generator," said Efraim Levy, an equity analyst at S&P Capital IQ. "That's not going away."
Levy said that the key to McDonald's growth is "creating a different experience ... from what it is today (that) doesn't stray too much from its core."
Tweaks are needed, not major surgery, Levy added.

"Not all their consumers are that cost-conscious. They want the flavor and the convenience."McDonald's didn't try to supersize its disappointing third-quarter results Tuesday, with its CEO saying the fast food giant must "fundamentally change." They want the flavor and the convenience."
Owning well-established blue chips that generate slow but steady gains and dividends is one way to play the stock market.

But investors looking for a little more sizzle should be on the lookout for newer names with the potential for fast growth. Think of the N in CAN SLIM, which stands for new products, new management, new companies — and even new highs.

Big caps such as Coca-Cola (KO), General Electric (GE) and Procter & Gamble (PG), all components of the Dow Jones industrial average, have a long history and tend to provide fairly stable profits as well as an income stream. They also have market caps near $200 billion or higher, and have more than 2 billion shares outstanding.

What they don't usually offer, however, is a big run-up in stock price over a relatively short period. And most are cyclical — more subject to what's going on in the economy. The price performance this year for the three Dow stocks mentioned above ranges from -4% to a 9% gain. The overall Dow is up 7%.
By comparison, the Nasdaq composite, which tends to house newer, younger companies, has risen 13%. The S&P 500 is up 11%. So adding some newer stocks to your portfolio could help boost performance.
What's considered young?

IBD research has found that companies tend to make their biggest advance during the first several years after coming public. As a rule of thumb, a newer company is one that has been publicly traded for less than 15 years.

That's not to say an older company won't make a second big run. Most don't — but one exception is Apple (AAPL), 37 years old as a public company. The iPhone and iPad maker has had its share of ups and downs over the years, but has had a yet another revitalization: It's rallied over 40% this year.

New companies can create new markets, and those leaders can post enormous gains. Look at action camera maker GoPro (GPRO), up 200% from its June 26 debut. Ambarella (AMBA), which makes chips for GoPro cameras, has surged more than 730% since its October 2012 IPO.

More recently, a flurry of Chinese Internet stocks have surged amid the growth of the middle class in the Middle Kingdom. Alibaba (BABA), Baidu (BIDU) and BitAuto (BITA), which range from two months to nine years in age, have generated big gains for shareholders.

That's not to say you can pick any young stock and expect a big gain. Due diligence is necessary, as are the usual factors — the overall stock market, the economy, company fundamentals, and price and volume action. Also key: buying at the right time.

Mobileye (MBLY) formed an IPO base soon after its Aug. 1 debut. Investors who got in at the 41.60 buy point would have enjoyed a 41% gain in two weeks (1) — triggering the eight-week hold rule for fast movers.

The stock has now pulled back into a new base. Those who bought at the entry still hold a high single-digit percentage gain, but anyone chasing the stock on its way up would now have a smaller gain, if not a loss.

Mobileye's technology goes into camera-based advanced driver assistance systems. Its technology is used in cars by most major automakers, and is thought to be in some new Tesla Motors ' (TSLA) vehicles.Owning well-established blue chips that generate slow but steady gains and dividends is one way to play the stock market.But investors looking for a little more sizzle should be on the lookout for newer names with the potential for fast growth. Stocks remained firmly in the red in late-morning trading Wednesday.
The Nasdaq fell 0.7%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.3% and the Dow Jones industrial average shaved 0.1%. Volume continued to track heavier across the board in the stock market today.
Losses in the Dow were cushioned by strong gains in Boeing (BA), Home Depot (HD) and Coca-Cola (KO), each of which climbed more than 1%.
Leaders up in heavy volume were few heading into the lunch hour Wednesday.

JetBlue Airways (JBLU) climbed 3% in heavy trading. The stock retook a 12.93 buy point from a cup base and is working on a potential sixth straight weekly gain. The company announced it will begin charging fees for checked bags on its cheapest level of tickets.

Restaurant operator Buffalo Wild Wings (BWLD) added 1% in above average volume and is approaching a 167.74 buy point from a cup base. The company has posted six straight quarters of 20% or better earnings growth. Early Wednesday a Wunderlich Securities analyst reiterated a buy rating on the stock and raised the price target to 185. CEO Sally Smith is featured on today's Leaders & Success page.
On the downside, Synchronoss Technologies (SNCR) plunged 12% in huge trade, slicing through its 50-day moving average. The stock was downgraded to underperform by Robert W. Baird.

The stock market is having trouble, so it might be a good time to propose a toast to three dividend-paying soft-drink makers trading near highs. Raise your glass to Coca-Cola (KO), PepsiCo (PEP) and Dr Pepper Snapple (DPS). The strongest performer of the three is Dr Pepper. Its stock is performing better than about 90% of stocks over the past…

Microsoft on Tuesday unveiled its third-generation Surface tablet, a device it hopes will sell as a replacement for notebook computers.While tablets have been billed for a few years as laptop PC replacements, the truth is that most tablet owners still use notebooks as well, Panos Panay, corporate vice president of Microsoft (MSFT) Surface, said at a press event in New York City.Usability trade-offs have kept tablets from replacing notebooks, he said. Panay noted how 96% of Apple (AAPL) iPad owners also own notebook computers.The new Surface Pro 3 tablet features a bigger screen, an improved attachable keyboard and a digital pen for making handwritten notes and drawings on screen.The new tablet will be available for pre-order on Wednesday starting at $799. The optional Surface Pro Type cover costs $129.99. The Surface Pro 3 will be in stores on June 20 in the U.S. and Canada, the company said.Microsoft needed to try something different to compete against tablet leaders Apple and Samsung, FBR Capital Markets analyst Daniel Ives said.Positioning the Surface Pro 3 as a laptop replacement "gives Microsoft a more unique selling feature than being another 'me too' tablet product," Ives said. "Strategically they are definitely taking a different direction."Because the third-generation Surface Pro, with keyboard cover, costs $830 at a minimum, Microsoft has to position the device against high-end laptops like Apple's MacBook Air, Gartner analyst Mike Silver said.He points out that Microsoft's two earlier Pro tablets also were pitched as laptop replacements. But the tech giant is now "being bolder about how they communicate that," Silver said.Microsoft appears to be targeting enterprise and business users with the Surface Pro 3. At the press event, the company showed usage scenarios for architects and creative professionals.Buyers Include BMW, CokeCompanies such as BMW Group and Coca-Cola (KO) have already committed to purchasing and deploying the device inside their organizations, Microsoft said.Microsoft also is selling a desktop docking station and keyboard that costs $199.99 and targets office workers.The Surface Pro 3 runs on fourth-generation Intel (INTC) Core processors. The tablet is 0.36-inch thin and weighs 1.76 pounds. It boasts up to nine hours of Web-browsing battery life.The basic model comes with 4 gigabytes of RAM, 64 GB of flash storage and Intel's Core i3 processor. Microsoft is selling five configurations of the Surface Pro 3. The top-of-the-line model costs $1,949 and comes with 8 GB of RAM, 512 GB of storage and Intel's i7 chip.Like its predecessors, the Surface Pro 3 can double as a tablet and notebook. It features a more rigid dockable keyboard and adjustable screen kickstand that will allow for laptop typing, something that was difficult with earlier models.The keyboard's trackpad was enlarged and improved as well.Plus, the device features a special pen for writing digital ink on documents, editing photos and other tasks where pen input is preferable.The Surface Pro 3 has a 12-inch screen; the previous model had a 10.6-inch display. The new screen is 38% bigger than Surface Pro 2, with 50% more pixels."Ladies and gentlemen, this is the tablet that can replace your laptop — the Surface Pro 3," Panay said as he held up the ultrathin, lightweight device.A key application of the new tablet is to replace an analog pen and notepad. Clicking the top of the special pen commands the Surface tablet to turn on with a OneNote writing surface displayed.Click the Surface Pen again, and the note is synced to the Internet cloud via Microsoft's OneDrive.The software leader's executives also demonstrated using the pen to do a New York Times crossword puzzle app and to edit images in Adobe Systems' (ADBE) Photoshop.Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella spoke at the press event about how Surface hardware is part of the company's "mobile first, cloud first" strategy.Microsoft released its first-generation Surface tablets in October 2012. The first Pro configuration came out in February 2013.Microsoft came out with its second generation Surface tablets in October 2013."They're hoping the third time will be the charm," Ives said.The first two waves of Surface tablets barely put a dent in the tablet market, which is dominated by Apple's iPad and Google (GOOGL) Android-based devices.Not discussed at Tuesday's press event were any new consumer Surface RT tablets or a rumored mini tablet.

Green Mountain Coffee Roasters (GMCR) shares fell Wednesday after the company was downgraded over limited details on its forthcoming Keurig Cold beverage maker and a lawsuit over its K-cup business practices. The maker of Keurig coffee makers was downgraded to neutral from buy by Longbow, which cited the stock's valuation, increased investment spending and limited details on the Keurig Cold…
Stocks notched uneven early gains Tuesday as investors weighed solid new home sales and mixed durable goods data against the potential for a deal between Greece and its eurozone creditors.
The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 0.3%. The Nasdaq added less than 0.1%. The S&P 500 split the difference, up 0.2%.
Volume was mixed on the stock market today, up 5% on the Nasdaq and 8% lower on the NYSE, compared to trade at the same time Monday.

The top-line number in the Commerce Department's May durable goods report showed a 1.8% decline and a downward revision to April's number to minus 1.5%. Economists had forecast a more mild 0.6% slip. The bulk of the miss was apparently due to a sharp decline in aircraft orders during the month. Minus transportation, durable goods orders rose 0.5% — in line with expectations. So far this year, durable goods orders are running 2.2% below last year's January to May period.

Housing prices improved steadily in May, lifting the Federal Housing Finance Agency's House Price Index 0.3%. That increase was equal to March's increase but just below consensus forecasts for a 0.4% gain. Year over year, the index is up 5.3%.

New home sales popped in May to an annualized rate of 546,000, according to the Commerce Department. That was up from April's (upwardly revised) 534,000 pace, well above consensus expectations of 525,000 and the strongest number since Feb. 2008.

A bit less rosy was the preliminary June manufacturing estimate from researcher Markit. Its Purchasing Managers Manufacturing Index was at 53.4, down from May's 53.8 number and below forecasts for an increase to 54.2. The number points to a third month of slowing activity and is the gauge's weakest gain in 18 months.
In stocks, it was a good morning for Florida-based companies.

Darden Restaurants (DRI) rose 3% to lead the S&P 500 by a wide margin. The Orlando-based owner of the Olive Garden, Red Lobster and other chains reported healthy fiscal fourth-quarter results and announced plans to slice off a portion of its real estate assets into a separate real estate investment trust. The stock popped to a new high, paring some gains but holding just above a cup-base buy point of 70.48.

Citrix Systems (CTXS) pecked out a 2% gain, the best increase among Nasdaq 100 stocks. The Fort Lauderdale-headquartered software developer is still in buying range, 4% above a 69.33 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.
Among leaders, most of the IBD 50 list posted modest gains and losses — with a couple of dramatic exceptions.

Ambarella (AMBA) led the list with a 9% rebound. The stock tumbled 21% Monday, following a short-seller's report on Friday that questioned the stock's valuation. The stock remains extended after a mid-May rebound from 10-week support and is well above its 10-week moving average.

At the bottom of the group, burger joint Sonic (SONC) dived 11% in massive trade. Fiscal third quarter sales and profits met consensus expectations, but full-year earnings guidance didn't. The sell-off stopped at a test of the stock's 10-week moving average, seriously damaging efforts to shape a three-month cup base.Stocks notched uneven early gains Tuesday as investors weighed solid new home sales and mixed durable goods data against the potential for a deal between Greece and its eurozone creditors.The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 0.3%. Stocks traded in a tight range Tuesday, ending narrowly mixed.The S&P 500 topped the 1900 level for the first time before backing off. It still rose fractionally to a new all-time closing high.The Dow Jones industrial average added 0.1%. The Nasdaq lagged, falling 0.3%. Preliminary data showed NYSE and Nasdaq volume coming in a tad higher than Monday's levels.In economic news, retail sales edged 0.1% higher in April, below forecasts for a 0.4% gain. Excluding autos, sales were flat, also below expectations for a 0.6% increase.In the stock market today, oil-services provider Emerge Energy Services (EMES) added nearly 2%. There was no news, but it was mentioned in a profile of group peer Matrix Service (MTRX) in Tuesday's Stock Spotlight. Both small caps are fast growers in the group.Meanwhile, Keurig Green Mountain (GMCR) jumped 8% in heavy volume on news that Coca-Cola (KO) raised its stake to 16% from 10% ahead of the launch of Keurig's new cold-beverage system. After a 28% pullback, Keurig has rallied about 30% in less than two weeks. It's only 4% off its all-time high.TransDigm Group (TDG) outperformed, rising 2%, as it continued work on a late-stage flat base. Last week, the maker of aerospace components for commercial and military aircraft reported its third straight quarter of accelerating sales growth. TransDigm has been a big winner since the start of the bull market in March 2009. Shares are up about 750%.IBD 50 member Akorn (AKRX) outperformed again as it neared the top of a 12-week-old base. Shares rose 4%. Late last week, the specialty drugmaker announced plans to buy privately held VersaPharm for $440 million.On the downside, oil and gas producer Antero Resources (AR) eased 1%. Late Monday, the company announced a secondary offering of 10 million shares.

The S&P 500 made a new high Tuesday, but it wasn't enough to relieve the market from its lethargic pace. The benchmark index climbed less than 0.1% after trimming most of a 0.3% advance earlier in the day. The Nasdaq lagged, losing 0.3%. Volume inched up on the Nasdaq and fell on the NYSE. In the strictest technical terms, the…

And Green Mountain Coffee Roasters'  (GMCR) partnership with Coca-Cola (KO) could brew good things for Dunkin', which is a partner with both. Dunkin' Brands reported a 26.5% jump in fourth-quarter earnings to 43 cents per share. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters were expecting only 40 cents.…

Stocks weakened and were narrowly mixed late Tuesday. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 were each up 0.2%, but Nasdaq lost 0.2%. Turnover was running lower on both major exchanges in the stock market today compared with the same time Monday.
The major averages have seesawed amid mixed economic data.

Some medical stocks were in comeback mode after being slammed Monday. Biogen (BIIB), Celgene (CELG) and Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN) had gains ranging from a fraction to 3%. But AMN Healthcare Services (AHS), Universal Health Services (UHS) and Impax Laboratories (IPXL) lost between 3% and 9%.

Elsewhere, Chuy's (CHUY) eased but was still up about 3%. Shares of the restaurant operator were up nearly 4% after being started at outperform and given a price target of 32 from research firm Telsey Advisory Group.
Post Holdings (POST) dropped 7% to its lowest level since Aug. 7. On Monday, the stock had already tumbled 9% and triggered the 8% sell rule from a 67.50 entry in a three-weeks-tight pattern.

Few leaders advanced Wednesday as growth stocks took a beating in the broad market sell-off. Many stocks that closed at or reached new highs intraday were low priced, thinly traded or fundamentally flawed. Duke Energy (DUK) added 0.53 to 75.30 in twice its normal trade for its sixth straight up session. The stock crossed just above a 75.23 buy point…
Stocks opened lower but quickly turned mixed in quiet trade early Friday, with chip stocks under particularly heavy pressure.

The Dow Jones industrial average managed a 0.1% gain, as Procter & Gamble (PG), Wal-Mart (WMT) and Coca-Cola (KO) all gained more than 1%. The S&P 500 dipped 0.2%. The Nasdaq spun lower, losing 0.8%. Volume was very weak, down 90% on the Nasdaq and 89% lower on the NYSE, compared to action at the same time Thursday.

A volatile premarket session might have hinted at what kind of trade investors can expect from the stock market today . Futures dug deep into losses in early trade, shadowing heavy sell-offs across Europe and Asia. Futures then abruptly trimmed losses and turned mixed, with Dow and S&P 500 futures rising just before the start of regular trade.
Chipmakers got slammed at the open, however, with Intel's (INTC) 4% loss holding back the Dow. The worst loss among Nasdaq 100 stocks was an 11% dive by Netherlands-based NXP Semiconductors (NXPI).
Leading stocks staged a surprisingly positive open, with three in five IBD 50 stocks rising in early trade.

But Avago Technologies (AVGO), the hardest hit among IBD 50 stocks, toppled 10% in heavy trade. The slide put the Singapore-based chip developer well below its 10-week line of support and left it just even with a 72.60 buy point in a three-weeks-tight pattern.

Chipmaker Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) skittered 7% lower. The stock had been fighting to regain its 50-day moving average in a shallow consolidation, but Friday's gap-down loss sent shares 18% below their Sept. 25 high.
Tesla Motors (TSLA) slumped 6% in very heavy trade. The Palo Alto, Calif.-based automaker on Thursday evening introduced the "D," an all-wheel drive version of its Model S sedan.

On the upside, generic-drug maker Lannett (LCI) climbed 2%, edging closer to the buy point in a cup-with-handle base.Stocks opened lower but quickly turned mixed in quiet trade early Friday, with chip stocks under particularly heavy pressure.The Dow Jones industrial average managed a 0.1% gain, as Procter & Gamble (PG), Wal-Mart (WMT) and Coca-Cola (KO) all gained more than 1%. Monster Beverage (MNST) and Moody's (MCO) cleared buy points Wednesday, leading another short new-highs list. Monster rose 4.04, or 4%, to 96.47 and clearing a 92.87 cup-with-handle buy point. However, volume was just 7% above average, well below the 40% spike that would signal a healthy breakout. Monster soared 30% on Aug. 15 after Coca-Cola (KO) said it would take…
Electronics pioneer Sony (SNE) has wrestled through a multi-year effort to turn and hold profits.

Falling sales led to earnings declines of 33% in fiscal 2012 and 72% in 2013. Prior to Thursday's earnings, EPS were expected to drop 22% for the fiscal year ending in March, followed by a jarring 472% rebound forecast in the next fiscal year.

The company, based in the Minato section of Tokyo, reported Thursday the company gained $255 million in the quarter (vs. a year-ago loss). It also warned that its Vaio PC and television businesses would not be profitable, as pledged, for the fiscal year ending in March.

As a result, a company statement said Sony had agreed to sell its Vaio PC business to Japan Industrial Partners. Terms have not been worked out, but Sony is expected to conclude the deal by the end of March.
JIP will continue to support existing Vaio customers, but will concentrate on sales in the Japanese market. Sony will exit PC manufacturing after the spring launch of the company's new products.

The company also outlined plans to spin off its Bravia TV operations as a wholly owned subsidiary by July. The sale will free the company to further concentrate on digital imaging, gaming and mobile markets, set as the company's core business by Kazuo Hirai when he took the helm as president and chief executive in 2012.

Sony also said Thursday it will lay off an additional 5,000 workers by March 2015, raising to 15,000 its job cuts announced in the past year. The stock climbed 143% in the six months through May, then drifted down 34%.

Israel-based beverage device maker SodaStream (SODA) fell 10% in after-hours trading Wednesday on news that Coca-Cola (KO) and Green Mountain Coffee Roasters (GMCR) will team up to present a cold-drink-making system of their own.

When Thursday's session opened, SodaStream shares surged 9% in very heavy trade after a pair of analyst notes speculated the company could team in a similar deal with PepsiCo, Dr Pepper Snapple Group or Nestle.
Analysts also pointed out that the two companies are concentrated in different markets. SodaStream takes two-thirds of its revenue from Europe, while 85% of Green Mountain's revenue is U.S.-based.

The stock market erased losses in afternoon trading and registered modest gains. The Nasdaq was up 0.2%. Apple (AAPL), its largest component, erased losses and was flat, trading just below a 133.70 buy point.The S&P 500 climbed 0.3%, and the Dow Jones industrial average 0.4%. Volume was tracking higher on the NYSE and lower on the Nasdaq.Medical stocks remain in the spotlight, and one broke out in the stock market today.Aetna (AET) rose past the 110 buy point of a flat base.The health insurer boosted full-year per-share earnings guidance as medical membership grew and the company topped earnings expectations for the first quarter. Aetna now expects $7.20 to $7.40 in earnings per share, up from $7. Analysts project $7.19 per share.Centene (CNC) earnings grew 79% to 52 cents a share, 4 cents above estimates. Revenue at the HMO rose 48% to $5.13 billion, just edging past expectations for $5.12 billion. The stock slid 3% and is testing its 10-week moving average.However, a couple of other high-rated medical stocks cratered.Idexx Laboratories (IDXX) plunged 13% in heavy trading, thrashing a cup-shaped base that it was forming. The animal diagnostic and health care company's earnings and sales for the first quarter missed expectations.Icon (ICLR), a clinical research outsourcing company, beat profit estimates; its sales were in line with expectations. The company raised its full-year profit forecast to $3.60-$3.70 a share but decreased revenue guidance to $1.6 billion-$1.65 billion. Prior guidance was $1.61 billion-$1.675 billion. Shares fell 5%, dipping below the 50-day line.

That tact also gets the most out of relationships with employees, suppliers and industry partners. • Motivate. Stock futures showed healthy gains early Tuesday as Europe's markets rebounded, oil prices recovered from lows, and economic news was fair to positive.

Dow futures traded 75.5 points above fair market value, down from 100.5 points an hour earlier. Nasdaq 100 futures added to early gains and were up 29.1 points. S&P 500 futures moved up 11.7 points, even with hour-earlier levels.

The stock market today has its eye on Wednesday afternoon as the Federal Open Market Committee members head into their two-day powwow. Expectations are high for a policy shift when the group announces its decision on Wednesday at 2 p.m. ET.

Consumer prices were flat in November, the Labor Department reported. That was down from a 0.2% gain in October and in line with economist expectations. Core prices, minus food and energy, rose 0.2% — equal to October's increase and meeting consensus projections.

Manufacturing activity in the New York region slowed at an improved rate in December, according to the New York Federal Reserve's Empire State Manufacturing Survey. It showed a -4.6 performance vs. a -10.7 showing in November. That was better than the -7 reading expected by economists.
At 10 a.m., the National Association of Home Builders releases its builder confidence index. The Treasury Department reports long-term Treasury international capital flow for October at 4 p.m.

Oil prices took a modest bounce in early trade, lifting West Texas Intermediate less than 1% and Brent crude more than 1%, although still trading below $37 and $39 a barrel, respectively. That, and the late-day recovery of U.S. markets on Monday, fed a rebound across European markets. The leading indexes bounced up from 10-week lows, sending the DAX in Frankfurt and the CAC-40 in Paris up more than 2% near midday.

In stocks, miners and steel markets were rebounding, with issues like Vale (VALE) up 5% and Arcelor-Mittal (MT) ahead more than 4%. On the Dow, diversified operator 3M (MMM) — the old Minnesota Mining & Manufacturing Co., tanked more than 4% after lowering its 2015 earnings guidance. Chevron (CVX) topped the index in premarket trade with a 0.8% gain.
3M also notched the worst loss among S&P 500 stocks. F5 Networks (FFIV) took the second hardest hit, down a bit more than 2%.
Chipmaker Nvidia (NVDA), Newell Rubbermaid (NWL) and Southwestern Energy (SWN) topped the list, all up better than 3%.

Flooring retailer Lumber Liquidators (LL) bolted 27% higher after news reports detailed a letter from Kase Capital Management Managing Partner Whitney Tilson, declaring that he had covered his short position against the stock.

Tilson had weighed in against the company following allegations that some of its flooring contained unsafe levels of formaldehyde. Tilson concluded that management probably did not know about the problem, according to Bloomberg, which means "the company was sloppy and naive, but not evil," Tilson wrote. The stock ended Monday down 80% since news of the investigation broke in February.

Leading stocks stuck to moderate moves in premarket action. Hawaiian (HA) topped the IBD 50 list, up slightly more than 1% in premarket trade. The broad market indexes were higher near Tuesday's halftime after recovering from earlier volatility brought on by worse-than-expected housing data.

Lifted by gains in Priceline.com (PCLN), Google (GOOG) and Apple (AAPL), the Nasdaq climbed 0.6% to its best levels since July 2000. The S&P 500 rose 0.2%. Meanwhile, the Dow Jones industrial average was mostly unchanged, even as Coca-Cola (KO) fell more than 3% on soft quarterly sales.

Sungy Mobile (GOMO) bolted 6% to a new high. The stock cleared a 25.77 buy point from an IPO base. IPO bases can be shorter than typical patterns. The Chinese provider of mobile Internet products and services lost money in 2011 and 2012, but is expected to have turned a profit of 39 cents a share for 2013. Earnings are expected at 74 cents a share for this year.

In the stock market today, IBD 50 stock Ubiquiti Networks (UBNT) rallied 5% and cleared a 48.10 buy point from a rare ascending base in fast trade. Earlier this month, the networking gear maker delivered fiscal Q2 earnings that grew 140%, the second straight period of triple-digit growth. Another triple-digit gain is expected in the current period.

HollySys Automation Technologies (HOLI) pared a near 11% gain to 5%. The Chinese maker of automated factory equipment surged early in response to Monday's blowout fourth-quarter earnings. The gain briefly poked above a 19.53 buy point in a seven-week, V-shaped cup base. The stock market put in a quiet session with the major indexes up modestly in muted trade Friday, but it capped an encouraging week.For the day, the Nasdaq was up 0.1%, the S&P 500 rose 0.5% and the Dow Jones industrial average was 0.8% higher. Volume was down on both exchanges, according to preliminary data.For the week, the Nasdaq rose 2.9%, the S&P 500 was 2.3% and the Dow Jones industrial average rose 2.3%. It put the S&P and the Nasdaq back near their highs. The Nasdaq has risen for seven straight sessions.In the stock market today, 22 IBD 50 stocks were up and 27 were down with one unchanged. The best performer was Packaging Corp. of America (PKG), which rose 1.8% to a new high. It reported earnings Tuesday evening that were 70% above the year-old quarter. The stock gapped up and closed 9.9% higher the next day.The worst performer was Green Mountain Coffee Roasters (GMCR), down 3.9%. But it's had a powerful two weeks. Last week, it was up 33% after announcing a long-term partnership with Coca-Cola (KO). It was up another 7.7% this week.And although Friday was lackluster for the elite list of 50 growth stocks, they have resumed outperforming the S&P 500 after months of matching its performance.In economic news, the preliminary reading from the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for February came in at 81.2, unchanged from January, but better than the consensus estimate of 80.Comcast (CMCSA) and Time Warner Cable (TWC) were still being heavily traded, one day after they announced a merger. Comcast and Time Warner shares added more than 1%.The markets are closed Monday for Presidents Day.On Tuesday, the New York Fed's Empire State Manufacturing Survey is released along with the NAHB Housing Market Index.
Stocks rose Friday after the European Central Bank hinted at new stimulus measures to boost inflation. But the major averages ended off intraday highs.

The Nasdaq rose 0.6%, the Dow Jones industrial average gained 0.5%, and the S&P 500 was up 0.4%. Volume was mixed in the stock market today, rising 16% on the NYSE and falling 4% on the Nasdaq compared to Thursday, according to preliminary figures.
European Central Bank head Mario Draghi suggested that the ECB will introduce new stimulus measures at its Dec. 3 meeting.
Retailers, medical and apparel stocks led the upside, while data storage, energy and steel stocks underperformed.

Nike (NKE) led the Dow and the IBD 50, jumping 5% in heavy volume after announcing a 2-for-1 stock split, share buyback and a dividend increase late Thursday. The stock is well extended past a 117.82 buy point but has found support at the 50-day moving average.

Alaska Air (ALK) was also among the best-performing IBD 50 stocks. The regional airline climbed nearly 3%, in line with oil's plunge below $40 a barrel, as it nears an 82.88 buy point of a flat base. Hawaiian Holdings (HA) also rose nearly 3%. The carrier is just 1% off an all-time high and well out of buying range.

It was a tale of two markets Friday, as a sell-off in chip stocks fueled a precipitous decline in the Nasdaq. Blue chips, however, outperformed.With a little over one hour remaining in the session, the Nasdaq fell 1.1%. It was earlier down by as much as 1.8%. The S&P 500 eased 0.1% while the Dow Jones industrial average picked up 0.1%. NYSE and Nasdaq volume was tracking higher than Thursday's levels.Top-performing Dow components included Coca-Cola (KO) and Procter & Gamble (PG).The biggest decliners in the Nasdaq 100 all hailed from the chip sector. NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) shed 12% while Avago (AVGO) and Xilinx (XLNX) fell 9% and 7%, respectively.The chip sell-off was partly ignited by Microchip Technology (MCHP). Shares slumped 10.5% after the company pre-announced weaker-than-expected revenue for the current quarter.In the stock market today, IPO Dave & Busters (PLAY) debuted strongly in a shaky market. It priced last night at 16, at the low end of proposed range of 16-18. Shares of the arcade and restaurant chain were recently trading around 17.18.Elsewhere, Infosys (INFY) reclaimed a 62.26 cup-with-handle buy point after the IT services names reported solid earnings. Shares gapped up and rose 6%. It's still in a buy range but new buys are risky when the market's in a correction.Tesla Motors (TSLA) lost 7% after the company unveiled spruced up features at the rate the company requested.
SodaStream (SODA) is fizzing again with rumors of a sale. The in-home carbonated beverage maker is reportedly in talks with a British hedge fund, according to an Israeli paper.
SodaStream could be sold for $40 per share, according to sources cited by TheMarker.
Shares jumped 1.7% to 32.02 in the stock market today.

This isn't the first time SodaStream was reportedly in talks with a buyer. In July Bloomberg reported that SodaStream was in talks with an investment firm in a deal that would value the company at $828 million, or $40 per share. The report also said "several private-equity funds" have been eyeing the company for a leveraged buyout
Earlier in the year Starbucks (SBUX) reportedly was considering buying a stake in SodaStream.
The company continues to attract interest amid growing demand for healthier, custom-made drinks. Cash-strapped consumers still open their wallets for small splurges like beverages.
SodaStream may need a partner as it faces increased competition from Coca-Cola (KO) and Keurig Green Mountain (GMCR), which have teamed up to design an in-home soda maker.
PepsiCo (PEP) also joined the in-home soda wars, investing in European-based Bevyz with Keurig. The company launched an at-home beverage maker in the U.S. in March.
SodaStream went public in November 2010 for $20 per share and peaked at $78 in 2011 before competition increased.

Jim Diedrich and his colleagues at Nuveen Mid Cap Growth Opportunities should send a thank-you note to the Federal Reserve.
Amid Fed tapering of its bond-buying program and the prospect of higher interest rates, the market has tilted toward stocks that the $1.3 billion fund favors.
"Since June 2013, higher growth, higher quality names got traction," said lead manager Diedrich.
That market rotation has translated into better absolute and relative performance for the fund.

It gained 36.86% in 2013 vs. 32.39% for the S&P 500, up from 15.12% and 16%, respectively, in 2012. The fund was up 37.82% over the 12 months going into Tuesday. "In recent months, investors have become more comfortable with the prospect of sustainability of (economic growth)," Diedrich said.
The fund began its current stake in Jazz Pharmaceuticals (JAZZ) in July. Its position in the specialty drugmaker has been steady in recent months.
Shares soared 207% in the past 52 weeks.

"What we like about them is that they are Irish-domiciled and have an Irish tax rate," Diedrich said. Ireland's corporate rate is 12.5% vs. 35% in the U.S. "That's an advantage in its own right and in acquiring other companies."
That should make its takeover of Gentium even more accretive, Diedrich says.
In addition, Jazz should benefit from ongoing consolidation in its biopharma space.
Easier Analytics
The Nuveen mutual fund began its current stake in Tableau Software (DATA) in October. It added to that in the next three months.

"Tableau is a business analytics provider," Diedrich said. "Before, you needed someone in your IT department to write a program to extract and analyze corporate data. With Tableau's software, it's much easier for people to get data on their own."
Shares are up 218% since going public in May at 31.

The fund cut back its stake in Michael Kors (KORS) in December and January after big additions in October and November. The trims were made to meet redemptions, not because the fund had soured on Kors, Diedrich says.

"Their earnings have been fantastic," he added. "There's not a lot in retail and apparel that's been producing good earnings. Kors is a standout. It has continued to beat consensus views on earnings."
Shares are up 70% the past 52 weeks.

The fund added to Green Mountain Coffee Roasters (GMCR) in November and December. "We can't find much that we like in consumer staples," Diedrich said. "But Green Mountain is a very efficient maker of K-Cup brewers. Earnings were decent."
The 10% stake taken in Green Mountain by Coca-Cola (KO) is a great confidence booster, Diedrich adds. Coke is supporting Green Mountain's effort to make a single-cup cold-drink maker.
"Will Coke like the economics of that machine? If they get a machine that works right, earnings could be meaningfully higher. But it's a wild card," Diedrich said.

Diedrich says LPL Financial (LPLA) stands to benefit from financial advisers leaving big financial firms to become independent registered investment advisers. The company also should benefit as rising interest rates generate more earnings on the float from customers' accounts.Jim Diedrich and his colleagues at Nuveen Mid Cap Growth Opportunities should send a thank-you note to the Federal Reserve.Amid Fed tapering of its bond-buying program and the prospect of higher interest rates, the market has tilted toward stocks that the $1.3 billion fund favors."Since June 2013, higher growth, higher quality names got traction," said lead manager Diedrich.That market rotation has translated into better absolute and relative performance for the fund.It gained 36.86% in 2013 vs. 32.39% for the S&P 500, up from 15.12% and 16%, respectively, in 2012. Stock futures added to early gains ahead of Thursday's starting bell after a positive reading on weekly unemployment claims.Dow futures jumped 88.6 points above fair market value. Nasdaq 100 futures powered up 16 points, while S&P 500 futures were 8.9 points higher.
Stock Market Today

A positive premarket session means little to the stock market today , however, making them a key factor to watch through the end of the week. The Nasdaq ended Wednesday down 1.6% and the S&P 500 down 1.5% so far for the week.
Economic News

Jobless claims fell 19% to 289,000 in the week ended March 7, the Labor Department reported. That sharply undercut expectations for a mild decline to 309,000 claims. The prior week's estimate was revised upward to 325,000. The four-week moving average shifted lower, its first decline in three weeks.

The Commerce Department reported that retail sales slipped 0.6% in February, better than January's 0.8% drop but well below forecasts for a 0.3% gain. Minus auto sales, sales were down 0.1% vs. a 0.9% drop in January. Economists projected a 0.5% gain.

Later this morning, the Commerce Department reports January business inventories at 10 a.m. ET. The Energy Information Administration gives weekly natural gas storage estimates at 10:30. The Treasury Department delivers its February budget figures at 2 p.m.
Stocks
Zoe's Kitchen (ZOES) zoomed up 6% in premarket trade, while Shake Shack (SHAK) shed 6%. Both eateries announced fourth-quarter results after Wednesday's close.
Zoe's closed Wednesday 9% below a 35.75 buy point in a cup-with-handle base. Shake Shack is in the seventh week of an IPO base, ending Wednesday 123% above its January initial offering price.

Krispy Kreme Doughnuts (KKD) crumbled 9% before the open. The home of the doughnut-bacon-hot dog late Wednesday reported Q4 earnings that narrowly beat forecasts, but revenue missed. Shares have been climbing since August, building the right side of a 16-month correction.

Morgan Stanley (MS) and Citigroup (C) jumped 3% each. Both banks hoisted their dividends and announced massive share buyback initiatives after passing the Federal Reserve's annual stress test requirements. Deutsche Bank (DB) and Banco Santander (SAN) rose 0.6% and 1.6%, respectively, despite the Fed halting their dividend and buyback plans after both received non-passing grades.
Overseas
Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index crept up 0.3%, while the Shanghai Composite vaulted 1.8%. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 also jumped, up 1.4%. Europe's markets were mildly mixed near midday.
Currencies/Commodities

The dollar eased a tad vs. the euro and slipped against the yen. Oil prices bounced about 1%, with benchmarks holding near recent lows. Gold bumped up nearly 1% to above $1,158 an ounce. Seeking to cater to more health-conscious consumers, beverage giant Coca-Cola (KO) recently unveiled a new concoction dubbed Coca-Cola Life. The healthier alternative, which comes in green and white packaging, has few calories and is sweetened with a combination of sugar and stevia leaf extract. Diet Coke and Coke Zero are both sweetened with aspartame, an artificial sweetener. A 330-milliliter (11.16…

PepsiCo (PEP) got a stock price target boost to 100 from 97 on UBS' expectations that the beverage and snack maker will continue to report earnings that beat expectations, in addition to Trian Partners' interest in the company.
By early afternoon, shares of the company had risen 1.6% to 91.75 in the stock market today, Monday.

"Simply put, coming out of the first half of 2014, we now have increasing conviction that PEP is operating with a newfound and welcome sense of urgency, and we have further confidence that better-than-expected results can continue," said UBS analyst Stephen Powers in a research note, adding that the Frito-Lay North America business is performing well and the global beverage segment is "holding its own" against competitors such as Coca-Cola (KO).

"More importantly, overall PEP results seem to imply that PEP is pushing harder to realize margin improvements and productivity in North American Beverages (NAB) and International Snacks, where it is critically needed to improve PEP's overall earnings algorithm," he said.

PepsiCo reported fizzy, estimate-topping Q2 earnings, in which the company boosted its full-year earnings guidance to an 8% hike, up from 7%, following a 0.8% Q2 earnings rise to $1.32 a share and a 0.5% revenue increase to $16.89 billion.
Trian Partners' Nelson Peltz has said he might push for a proxy fight as he encourages a reorganization of the company's businesses.
Powers said Trian has met with about 100 investors this year.

"From our discussions with many of these investors, support for Trian's position and plans seems relatively high," said Powers, adding that pre-Trian PepsiCo trailed Coca-Cola and its rivals, but PepsiCo has outperformed them since Trian got involved in early 2013.
RELATED:

Stock futures on Tuesday advanced toward the open for a second straight day, but showed a bit more strength than in Monday's premarket session.

Dow futures were ahead 91.1 points, well above Monday's premarket levels, and rising. Nasdaq 100 futures climbed 23.6 points above fair market value. S&P 500 futures showed a healthy 10.2-point gain. Small caps also looked in good shape, with Russell 2000 futures up 4.8 points.

The stock market today rolls into December with automakers releasing November sales numbers throughout the session. Fiat Chrysler (FCAU) reported a 3% gain in sales to its best level for November in 15 years. Jeep sales drove the results, rising 20%, vs. a 12% decline for Chrysler products, an 8% slip for Dodge and a 3% fall for Fiat autos.
Auto researcher Edmunds forecasts a total of 1.33 million light vehicles sold during the month, up 2.5% from a year ago. If accurate, it would make this the best November for automakers since 2001.
At 10 a.m., the Institute for Supply Management releases its November ISM Index and the Commerce Department reports October construction spending.

Retailers with a strong online presence may get a bump from data released by Adobe Systems (ADBE) showing shoppers spent a total of $2.98 billion during "Cyber Monday" — the Monday following the Black Friday launch of the holiday shopping season, which is designated as a day of technology and online shopping specials. The amount was a record and up 14% from last year's Cyber Monday sales, Adobe said. Adobe also estimated that Thanksgiving through Cyber Monday receipts would top $11 billion, up 15% year-over-year and also a record.
About a third of the Dow's issues were positive in premarket action, the rest were flat. The best gain came from Home Depot (HD), which added 1%.
Adobe Systems rose 2% to lead the Nasdaq 100. Baidu (BIDU) posted the Nasdaq 100's largest decline, down nearly 2%.

Automated network control specialist Infoblox (BLOX) rocketed 17% higher before the open. The Santa Clara, Calif.-based company reported late Monday fiscal first-quarter earnings, revenue and Q2 guidance above expectations, and management announced a $100 million share buyback initiative.

Mattress Firm Holding (MFRM) bounced 5% higher after announcing late Monday it would buy HMK Mattress Holding, owner of the Sleepy's retail chain, in a $780 million deal. The company said it expects about $40 million a year in cost savings. Mattress Firm also announced its fiscal Q3 sales rose 51%, and said it expected a 10% EPS gain — in line with consensus views.

China-based Qihoo 360 Technologies (QIHU) added 3% after the Wall Street Journal reported an investor group was prepared to offer $9 billion to take the Internet security and content provider off the U.S. market. The $77-per-American Depositary Receipt deal could be completed in the coming weeks, the report said. Plans then call for relisting the company on one of China's domestic exchanges.

Qihoo is the most recent in a wave of privatizations among China-based companies trading in the U.S. Another China-based issue, Ikang Healthcare (KANG), announced Monday it was being taken private by a group of investors at $22 per ADR.

Among leaders, stocks on the IBD 50 list were quiet ahead of the open. Most of the group remained flat. Among the few gains and losses, all held to less than 1%. The same was true for stocks on IBD's Your Weekly Review list.
Overseas, markets across Asia gained as PMI gauges tracking China's manufacturing and services sectors showed further divergence during the month. European markets were narrowly mixed near midday.

The amount was a record and up 14% from last year's Cyber Monday sales, Adobe said. Adobe also estimated that Thanksgiving through Cyber Monday receipts would top $11 billion, up 15% year-over-year and also a record.About a third of the Dow's issues were positive in premarket action, the rest were flat. The best gain came from Home Depot (HD), which added 1%.Adobe Systems rose 2% to lead the Nasdaq 100. Baidu (BIDU) posted the Nasdaq 100's largest decline, down nearly 2%.Automated network control specialist Infoblox (BLOX) rocketed 17% higher before the open. The Santa Clara, Calif.-based company reported late Monday fiscal first-quarter earnings, revenue and Q2 guidance above expectations, and management announced a $100 million share buyback initiative.Mattress Firm Holding (MFRM) bounced 5% higher after announcing late Monday it would buy HMK Mattress Holding, owner of the Sleepy's retail chain, in a $780 million deal. The company said it expects about $40 million a year in cost savings. Mattress Firm also announced its fiscal Q3 sales rose 51%, and said it expected a 10% EPS gain — in line with consensus views.China-based Qihoo 360 Technologies (QIHU) added 3% after the Wall Street Journal reported an investor group was prepared to offer $9 billion to take the Internet security and content provider off the U.S. market. The $77-per-American Depositary Receipt deal could be completed in the coming weeks, the report said. Plans then call for relisting the company on one of China's domestic exchanges.Qihoo is the most recent in a wave of privatizations among China-based companies trading in the U.S. Another China-based issue, Ikang Healthcare (KANG), announced Monday it was being taken private by a group of investors at $22 per ADR.Among leaders, stocks on the IBD 50 list were quiet ahead of the open. Most of the group remained flat. Among the few gains and losses, all held to less than 1%. The same was true for stocks on IBD's Your Weekly Review list.Overseas, markets across Asia gained as PMI gauges tracking China's manufacturing and services sectors showed further divergence during the month. European markets were narrowly mixed near midday.Follow Alan Elliott on Twitter @IBD_AElliott.

Keurig Green Mountain (GMCR) is getting honest with its customers. The company on Wednesday deepened its deal with Coca-Cola, adding two varieties of Coke's Honest Tea K-Cups for its hot brewing machines.
Coca-Cola's (KO) Just Green and Just Black Honest Tea branded organic iced tea will be available for purchase on the Keurig site in North America starting Thursday.

"As we began to collaborate with The Coca-Cola Company on the development of their brands for our Keurig Cold system, the opportunity to incorporate certain Coca-Cola brands, like Honest Tea, into our Brew Over Ice selections for our Keurig hot brewing system became an exciting possibility," said Mark Wood, Senior VP, Global Hot Systems at Keurig.
The K-Cups will be the first Coke product for use in Keurig's hot brewing system. The teas are designed to be brewed hot and then poured over ice.
Keurig also has tea options from Unilever's (UL) Lipton and Dr Pepper Snapple (DPS).
Keurig shares edged up 0.2% to 133.51 on the stock market today. Coke shares were up 5 cents to 41.69.
In February, Coke inked a 10-year agreement with Keurig to help it market a Keurig cold-beverage maker and bought a 10% stake in the company. Coke then upped its holdings to 16% in May.
The deal led analysts to speculate that PepsiCo (PEP) would make a similar deal with in-home carbonated beverage maker SodaStream (SODA), heating up the cola wars.
Soda consumption in America has fallen in the past decade as consumers become more health conscious and want healthier, customizable beverages.
The Beverage-Non-Alcoholic group is ranked No. 95 out of the 197 industry groups IBD tracks.

Keurig Green Mountain shares rose after the maker of coffee brewers announced Friday that it will partner with Kraft Foods to make Maxwell House and McDonald's McCafe pods for its upcoming Keurig 2.0 brewer.
Shares of Keurig (GMCR) rose 13% to 133.36, hitting a record 135.99 intraday. The stock is up nearly 77% so far this year. Kraft (KRFT) shares fell four cents to 57.22.

Keurig in 2014 has announced partnerships with Nestle's Coffee-mate, Harris Teeter Supermarkets (HTSI) and Peet's Coffee & Tea. It already has K-Cup license deals with Starbucks (SBUX), Dunkin' Brands (DNKN) and others.
Kraft had been a notable brand holdout.
"Having exposure to the faster-growing portions of beverages across the board is something many companies are striving for," Williams Capital Group analyst Marc Riddick told IBD.
He expects more Keurig deals. "Future opportunities include the development of private-label and retailer-owned brands," he said in a Thursday note.
He noted Costco's (COST) Kirkland Signature K-Cup and the addition of Target (TGT) as an Archer Farms brand partner.
Since its K-Cup patent expired in 2012, Keurig has had to compete with unlicensed portion-pack makers.
The Keurig 2.0 brewer is designed to work only with licensed K-Cups, but it is unclear if it will be effective in shutting out imitators.
Williams Capital upped its price target on Keurig on Thursday to $131 from $125.

"Keurig Green Mountain remains a vital participant in the long-term growth of single-serve beverage consumption ," Riddick said in his note, adding that Keurig is an "important contributor" as a growth generator for its partners.
Earlier this year, Coca-Cola (KO) initiated and expanded a stake in Keurig, with plans to develop a Keurig Cold machine for release in the next several months.

Last week, Keurig said it would hike prices by up to 9% on its portion packs and bagged coffee, starting Nov. 3. Other coffee sellers have raised prices in recent months following a drought in Brazil's coffee-growing region.
Kraft has been working its coffee game, too. Earlier in the week, Kraft announced that it would bring McDonald's (MCD) McCafe java to grocery stores.

In addition to McCafe, Kraft brands such as Maxwell House, Gevalia and Yuban will be available in single-serve K-Cups, four-cup K-Carafes that fit the new Keurig 2.0, and Keurig Bolt packs that brew half-gallon pots, the companies said.

"This agreement offers the opportunity for expanded distribution across multiple channels and is another example of our focus on long-term growth in action," said Kraft Executive Vice President Dino Bianco in a release.

A nascent market uptrend, confirmed by the Nasdaq and S&P 500 on May 27, is looking pretty good. Distribution days, or higher-volume declines, have been nonexistent so far and growth stocks overall are holding up well. The IBD 50 is essentially flat year-to-date, compared with a 3.3% gain for the Nasdaq and 5.4% gain for the S&P 500. On Friday,…
Stocks were trading near their highest levels in early afternoon trading despite a weaker-than-expected jobs report before the open.

The Nasdaq reclaimed its 50-day moving average with a 1.2% gain, while the S&P 500 was up 0.8% and the Dow industrials 0.6%. Volume was tracking higher on the Nasdaq and slightly lower on the NYSE in the stock market today.

Green Mountain Coffee Roasters (GMCR) rose 6% in huge trade, hitting its highest level in more than two years. The stock continued its surge from Thursday, when it exploded 26% on news that Coca-Cola (KO) is taking a 10% stake in the Keurig maker and entering into a 10-year partnership. That overshadowed its fiscal Q1 results, where it beat on earnings but missed on sales.

Netflix (NFLX) was up 4% at a record high in busy trade. Stifel upgraded the streaming movie service to buy from hold. The stock was on track for their third straight up week since a 16% gap-up Jan. 23, after Netflix topped analysts' Q4 forecasts.

Jazz Pharmaceuticals (JAZZ) was up 8% in twice normal turnover to 2% off its high. The maker of narcolepsy and oncology drugs, a leader in IBD's Medical-Ethical Drugs group, was one of the stocks featured in Friday's Industry Themes column.

Alliance Data Systems (ADS) rose 4% to a new high in heavy trade, extending its 10% jump from the prior session. JMP Securities raised its price target on the private-label credit card issuer, which announced Q4 earnings and sales before Thursday's open that trounced analyst forecasts. It also guided its Q1 EPS outlook above consensus estimates.Stocks were trading near their highest levels in early afternoon trading despite a weaker-than-expected jobs report before the open.The Nasdaq reclaimed its 50-day moving average with a 1.2% gain, while the S&P 500 was up 0.8% and the Dow industrials 0.6%.
