It also guided its Q1 EPS outlook above consensus estimates.
Major averages opened with strong gains Thursday and were still holding them about two hours into the session.
The Nasdaq led the way, rising 1.1%. The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 gained 0.9% each. Volume in the early going was tracking well below Wednesday's levels.

In economic news, weekly jobless claims fell 20,000 to 331,000. Economists expected a smaller drop to 337,000. The data come ahead of Friday's jobs report. Nonfarm payrolls are expected to come in at 181,000 after dismal job growth of 74,000 in December.

Meanwhile, the European Central Bank left its main lending rate unchanged. Mario Draghi took a page out of the Fed's playbook, pledging to keep interest rates "at present or lower levels for an extended period of time."

In the stock market today, LinkedIn (LNKD) rallied 2% ahead of its earnings report after the close. The stock has turned into a bit of a laggard. It's been consolidating gains since September, trying to hold above its 200-day moving average. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect earnings to rise 9% to 38 cents a share, with sales up 44% to $437.8 million.

Among the day's movers, Green Mountain Coffee Roasters (GMCR) soared 30%. Late Wednesday, the company reported sluggish sales growth, but investors focused on news that Coca-Cola (KO) is buying a 10% stake in the company for $1.25 billion. Green Mountain is known for its Keurig single-serve coffee makers and is developing a machine for cold drinks.

Yelp (YELP) also soared on strong earnings. Shares jumped 21% after the company matched estimates for a loss of 3 cents a share. Sales growth was strong again, rising 72% to $70.7 million. In fiscal 2014, Yelp is expected to earn 17 cents a share. Annual profit is seen soaring 229% in fiscal 2015.

Akamai Technologies (AKAM) gapped out of a 16-week consolidation, rising 19%, on strong earnings. A Relative Strength Rating of 62 points toward sluggish price performance in recent months, but buyers were in the stock in spades Thursday.Major averages opened with strong gains Thursday and were still holding them about two hours into the session.The Nasdaq led the way, rising 1.1%. Stocks were tightly mixed at Tuesday's open, with earnings reports driving much of the early action.
The Nasdaq, hamstrung by Baidu's (BIDU) 14% decline, fought with a fractional loss. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 each added 0.2%.
Volume was soft, down 12% on the Nasdaq and 17% lower on the NYSE, compared to action at the same time Monday.

The stock market today has an eye on the Federal Open Market Committee, which is meeting in Washington but not expected to generate any news until the policy announcement scheduled for 2 p.m. on Wednesday.

Other economic news began with home prices, which were effectively flat in May, according to a 4.9 reading for the Case Shiller 20-City Home Price Index. Economists had expected a reading of 5.6. April's number was revised a notch higher, to 5.

The Conference Board's Consumer Confidence Index also fell, dropping to 90.9 in July, down from June's 101.4 tally, which was revised lower to 99.8. Economist consensus projected a very slight dip, to 99.6, for July.

A more positive note from researcher Markit reported the services sector of the economy improved in July. The preliminary estimate for its PMI index rose to 55.2, up from a 54.8 reading in June. Consensus had looked for a no-change number of 54.8.
In stocks, reactions were generally positive as quarterly reports rolled out from a broad range of companies.

Ford (F) and heavy truck maker Paccar (PCAR) climbed nearly 2% each. GrubHub (GRUB) jumped 3% after its Q2 report. Norway's state-owned oil producer Statoil (STO) jumped more than 2% on its second-quarter results.

Baidu (BIDU) posted the news-leading decline, with shares diving 14% after the company reported a Q2 earnings miss late Monday. The drop put shares down 17% so far for the week, and far below critical levels of support.

Cummins (CMI) powered up almost 4% after the diesel engine maker easily beat analysts' second-quarter sales and earnings projections. Management held to its prior revenue guidance for the year, which is consistent with consensus views. The stock has been in a deepening consolidation since June last year.

United Parcel Service (UPS) swept up nearly 4% as its earnings beat consensus estimates. Revenue stopped short of expectations, but management backed its prior EPS range of $5.05 to $5.30 for the year, and said it would come in near the top of that range. The stock has been crawling along the bottom of a flat consolidation and fighting to retake 10-week support since January.
The IBD 50 list opened the session evenly split — half up, half down at the start of trade.
Horizon Pharma (HZNP) and Blackhawk Network (HAWK) led the group, up more than 2% each. United Therapeutics (UTHR) grabbed the low post, dropping almost 4% after a mixed second-quarter report.

JetBlue Airways (JBLU) slipped nearly 4% after 132% EPS growth met Q2 expectations, but an 8% revenue gain stopped short of consensus estimates. The bulls failed to mount a counter-attack to Tuesday's sell-off, and stocks finished mildly lower Wednesday in light trading. The Nasdaq fell less than 0.1%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.2% and the Dow Jones industrial average declined 0.3% in the stock market today. Volume on both exchanges was lighter than Monday, according to preliminary data.
Volkswagen (VLKAY) jumped nearly 7% as its board accepted the resignation of CEO Martin Winterkorn in the wake of a scandal over cheating on emissions tests. The stock is still down 25% this week.

Among IBD 50 stocks, 36 were higher and 14 were lower. The top performer was AMN Healthcare Services (AHS), up more than 3% to a new high. The company, which supplies health care facilities with doctors and nurses, announced the acquisition of First String Healthcare.
Egg Producer Cal-Maine Foods (CALM), another IBD 50 name, rose nearly 3%. It's building the right side of a base.
Another provider of nurses and doctors, Cross Country Healthcare (CCRN), rose nearly 4% in above-average volume to a new high.

Synchronoss Technologies (SNCR) fell 11% in monster volume. An analyst reportedly said the company might lose Verizon (VZ) as a cloud customer. It had been down as much as 25%.The bulls failed to mount a counter-attack to Tuesday's sell-off, and stocks finished mildly lower Wednesday in light trading. Dr Pepper Snapple Group has been a sweet deal to investors who have bought shares of the drink maker this year. Dr Pepper Snapple (DPS) stock is up 25% so far, outpacing the S&P 500's 7% gain. Also, the firm pays a 2.7% dividend at the current share price, well above the S&P average 1.9%. Dr Pepper Snapple, which traces…
Stocks pounded out healthy gains in early trade Friday.
The Nasdaq jumped 0.6%. The S&P 500 grabbed a 0.4% gain and the Dow Jones industrial average popped 0.3%.
Volume on the stock market today got a boost from options expiration. Trade surged 52% on the Nasdaq and soared 166% on the NYSE compared with action at the same time Thursday.

Economic news continued to roll out, with the Treasury Department reporting foreign investors sold a net $18.7 billion in U.S. stocks and other vehicles in June. The long-term Treasury International Capital flow report downwardly revised its May number to $18.6 billion. June's adjusted number, which estimates unrecorded principal payments to foreigners on U.S. asset-backed securities and other factors, showed sales of $30.2 billion.

Factory output ratcheted up 0.4% in July, the Federal Reserve said, even with June's upwardly revised reading and slightly above the 0.3% gain expected by economists. Capacity utilization eked up to 79.2% vs. June's 79.1 level and in line with expectations.

Consumer confidence ebbed in August, with the University of Michigan's preliminary reading on its Consumer Sentiment Survey slipping to 79.2, down from 81.8 in July. Analysts consensus pointed to a reading of 82.3.

In stocks, Monster Beverage (MNST) staked out the morning's high road, rocketing 29% higher on a partnership deal with Coca-Cola (KO) late Thursday. The pact includes Coke making a $2.1 billion payment and handing over its energy drink portfolio, including tasty names like Full Throttle and Burn. Monster had been consolidating since February. Friday's move sent shares above their April 2012 high. Coke rose 2%.

Applied Materials (AMAT) jumped 5% after reporting fiscal third-quarter results late Thursday. Earnings narrowly topped expectations. Revenue growth stopped short of estimates. But new orders and gross margins surged, and management gave in-line guidance for the rest of the year.
The chip designer is in the fourth week of a shallow consolidation.
The open was almost unanimously positive among IBD 50 stocks, with all but a few rising at the starting bell.

Vipshop Holdings (VIPS) stroked out a 3% gain, moving to just below its high mark notched on Wednesday. Stock futures ladled out moderate losses ahead of Friday's open, as an uptick in May producer prices added to the inflation pressure on the Federal Reserve.
Dow futures slipped 39.4 points below fair market value. Nasdaq 100 futures dropped 15.3 points and S&P 500 futures were down 5.4 points.

The stock market today heads into Friday with the Nasdaq up 0.3% this week and the S&P 500 ahead 0.8%. The Nasdaq continued to find support at its 50-day moving average. The S&P 500 slipped below that level late last week, but retook support on Wednesday. A significant change in the eurozone's debt standoff with Greece, or clarity regarding a possible rate increase by the Federal Reserve, could help urge indexes out of their months-long limits. But until the market challenges the high or lows of its recent range, investors must stay prepared for a shift in either direction.

In economic news, prices paid to producers rose 0.5% in May, the Labor Department reported, the largest increase since at least December. The gain reversed April's 0.4% decline, and it topped analyst expectations for a 0.4% increase. The core Producer Price Index, minus energy and food, edged up 0.1% vs. a 0.2% slip in April and in line with expectations.
The University of Michigan is slated to release its initial June consumer sentiment estimate at 10 a.m. ET.

Stock action showedTwitter (TWTR) perking up 3% after announcing Chief Executive Dick Costolo will step down July 1. Twitter co-founder and Chairman Jack Dorsey will serve as interim CEO during a search for a new CEO. Dorsey said he would take no compensation for the position until later in the year. The stock has been unable to exit a consolidation begun shortly after its November 2013 IPO. It ended Thursday 52% below its Dec. 27 high.

Connecticut-based biotech Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN) dropped more than 2% in premarket action. The stock has been in a deepening consolidation since December and has been struggling to regain its 10-week moving average since early May.

Among IBD 50 stocks, Synaptics (SYNA) rose 2% before the open. The company announced Thursday it had reached a milestone, with shipments of fingerprint sensors now topping 200 million units. The sensors are used in smartphones, tablets and notebook computers. The stock has been hovering just below a June 3 high, ending Thursday almost 7% above a 91.33 buy point.

Overseas, markets across Asia ended higher, led by a 1.4% jump by Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index. The Shanghai Composite rose 0.9% to end the week up 2.8%. The Hang Seng ended up a fraction for the week. In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 rose 0.1% Friday to end the week effectively flat.
Europe's top indexes were also tracking toward flat finishes for the week, with the FTSE 100 in London, Frankfurt's DAX and the CAC-40 in Paris all showing moderate losses near midday.

The dollar continued to gain ground, keeping downward pressure on stocks and commodity prices. Oil and gold traded lower, with West Texas Intermediate futures holding just above $60 per barrel and the August gold contract trading at $1,179.20 an ounce. For the week, oil was up not quite 2%. Keurig Green Mountain will hike coffee prices to cope with rising costs for green coffee and other expenses, as new machines are set to debut soon. Keurig Green Mountain (GMCR), which makes single-cup coffee brewers, says that prices for all portion packs sold for use in its machines and all of its bagged coffee products sold at retail will rise…

Shares of PepsiCo (PEP) are up like a Mentos in a bottle of diet soda, as the maker of Mountain Dew and Cheetos raised its full-year guidance after reporting strong second-quarter earnings. PepsiCo now anticipates an 8% earnings rise this year, a boost from the company's previous expectation of a 7% increase. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters see full-year earnings…
Broader stock averages continued to sport gains Tuesday afternoon, despite disappointing regional manufacturing and housing data earlier.

The Nasdaq climbed 0.7%, while the S&P 500 rose 0.2%. Meanwhile, a 4% loss in Coca-Cola (KO) had the Dow Jones industrial average struggling for direction. Volume was running mixed in the stock market today. Trade was tracking sharply higher on the NYSE, while Nasdaq trade was running lower.

Medical stocks were strong on this morning's news of Actavis (ACT) buying Forest Laboratories (FRX) for $25 billion in cash and stock. Shares of Forest Labs rocketed 29%, while Actavis rallied 7%. Shares of Actavis, a Leaderboard stock, are up more than 20% past a 166.42 buy point from a three-weeks-tight pattern.
Other top-rated drugmakers Salix Pharmaceuticals (SLXP), Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) and Jazz Pharmaceuticals (JAZZ) were up 5% to 7%.

Elsewhere, IBD 50 stock Ubiquiti Networks (UBNT) stretched its gain to 9% and hit an all-time high. Earlier Tuesday, the stock blew past a 48.10 buy point from a rare ascending base. Earlier this month, the networking gear maker delivered fiscal Q2 earnings that grew 140%, the second straight period of triple-digit growth. Adding sugar to the mix, he came up with a recipe for a classic American soft drink — Hires Root Beer. Although Hires (1851-1937) didn't invent root beer, he was the…
Stocks were trading near the high of the day going into the final hour of trading Thursday, but volume was disappointing.
The Nasdaq, the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average were all up 1.2% with volume trailing Wednesday's pace on both exchanges.

In the stock market today, network security firm Palo Alto Networks (PANW) surged 10% and cleared a base after the company received a favorable ruling in a patent infringement dispute with Juniper Networks (JNPR). A trial date is scheduled for Feb. 24, the same day Palo Alto reports earnings.

Among IBD 50 stocks, 38 were up and 12 were down. The big mover was Green Mountain Coffee Roasters (GMCR), which announced earnings Wednesday evening and a long-term strategic partnership with Coca-Cola (KO). Green Moutnain soared 28% in furious volume.
The market got off to a good start when the Labor Department announced before the open that initial claims for unemployment last week fell more than expected to 331,000.

Disney (DIS) gapped up 5% in huge volume after profit for the latest quarter jumped 32% from a year ago, accelerating for the second quarter in a row. Revenue rose 9%, also picking up for the second straight period.
The stock retook its 50-day moving average and was just 1% off an all-time high.

Auto parts retailer O'Reilly Automotive (ORLY) also got a boost from a strong earnings report. It gapped up 9% to a new high in volume that was running about five times higher than normal. Stocks enjoyed solid gains Thursday, finishing near their highs, while earnings reports sparked sharp moves for several stocks after the close.The Nasdaq was up 1.1%, while the S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average rose 1.2%. Volume was lower on both exchanges, according to preliminary figures.The big mover of the day was Green Mountain Coffee Roasters (GMCR), which was up 26%. On Wednesday evening, it reported earnings and announced a 10-year global pact with Coca-Cola (KO).In after-hours trading Thursday, LinkedIn (LNKD) was down after it offered lowered guidance. The stock has been trying to build the right side of a base.Travel-booking website Expedia (EXPE) was up sharply after it reported EPS of 92 cents a share vs. 63 cents in the year-ago quarter. Before the report, shares were trading below the 50-day line.Web.com (WWWW) was down after reporting earnings. It reported 59 cents a share, 2 cents above estimates. Web.com has been trying to break out of a base past a 32.58 buy point.Athenahealth (ATHN) was up sharply. It missed on earnings, but beat on revenue. Earnings were 34 cents a share vs. estimates of 45 cents. Sales were up 48% from a year ago.The closely watched employment report is due out before the market opens Friday. For January, economists are forecasting 175,000 new jobs. A large deviation from the number could rattle or excite traders.

The major averages were little changed Friday in weak post-holiday trading. The Nasdaq was up 0.3%, the S&P 500 edged up 0.1% and the Dow Jones industrial was flat. Volume in Friday's half-day session was running sharply lower than at the same time Wednesday, the last trading session before Thanksgiving.Universal Display (OLED), a maker of light-emitting diodes for flat panel displays, jumped 3% in heavy volume on new reports that its products will be used in Apple's (AAPL) iPhone model due out in 2018. The stock is approaching a 55.93 buy point of a deep cup base.Falling oil prices hurt energy stocks but helped airlines in the stock market today.Coal producer Consol Energy (CNX) and oil stock Southwestern Energy (SWN), both longtime laggards, dropped 5%, weighing on the S&P 500. On the other hand, American Airlines (AAL) and United Continental (UAL) each rose about 2%, in line with a decline in oil prices. IBD 50 stock Hawaiian (HA) rose 2%.Meanwhile, Walt Disney (DIS) dropped 4% in heavy volume, dragging down media stocks, after announcing late Wednesday that its ESPN sports network has lost 7 million subscribers over the past two years. The stock dropped below a 117.68 cup-with-handle buy point that it cleared Nov. 18.Viacom (VIAB) fell 3% while Time Warner (TWX) was down 1%.
Stocks remained mostly higher Tuesday afternoon, despite disappointing regional manufacturing and housing data.

The Nasdaq climbed 0.7% and the S&P 500 edged up 0.1%. However, the Dow Jones industrial average slipped 0.1%, led by a 4% loss in Coca-Cola (KO) following a disappointing earnings report. Volume was running mixed, with turnover tracking sharply higher on the NYSE and slightly lower on the Nasdaq.

In the stock market today, IBD 50 stock Qihoo 360 Technology (QIHU), a China-based search engine, game and security software provider, jumped 7% to a new high in heavy volume. The stock recently climbed back above a 96.35 buy point. Its Relative Strength line also hit a new high, a bullish sign.

Ubiquiti Networks (UBNT), another IBD 50 stock, rose 9% to an all-time high, blowing past a 48.10 buy point from a rare ascending base. Earlier this month, the networking gear maker delivered fiscal Q2 earnings that grew 140%, the second straight period of triple-digit growth. Another triple-digit gain is expected in the current period.

Elsewhere, medical stocks rose after Actavis (ACT) announced it was buying Forest Laboratories (FRX) for $25 billion in cash and stock. Shares of Forest Labs rocketed 29%, while Actavis rallied 7%. Shares of Actavis, a Leaderboard stock, are up more than 20% past a 166.42 buy point from a three-weeks-tight pattern.
Other top-rated drugmakers Salix Pharmaceuticals (SLXP), Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) and Jazz Pharmaceuticals (JAZZ) were up 3% to 7%.

On the downside, oil and gas producer Sanchez Energy (SN) plunged 8% in huge volume, paring an earlier 17% loss. Tuesday was shaping up to be another ugly day for the stock market, but major averages recovered impressively and closed near highs on a busy day of headline flow. The S&P 500 led the way, rising 0.7%. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 0.6%, helped by strong earnings from Coca-Cola (KO) and Johnson & Johnson (JNJ). The Nasdaq, meanwhile, came…
Stocks held near their session highs Monday afternoon, thanks to easing geopolitical tension, merger news and better-than-expected housing data.

The Dow Jones industrial average led with a 1% gain. Meanwhile, the Nasdaq climbed 0.9% and the S&P 500 rose 0.8%. Turnover was again running lower on both major exchanges in the stock market today. Friday was an options expiration day, which makes for a tough volume comparison.

Lannett (LCI) gapped up and rallied 9% after giving an upbeat outlook. The generic-drug maker said it expects fiscal Q4 sales to come in at $81 million and pegged earnings at 60 cents to 64 cents a share. Both are above current views calling for earnings of 41 cents a share and revenue of $71.16 million. Lannett is close to potential resistance at its 50-day line.

58.com (WUBA) climbed 6% in fast trade, clearing short-term resistance at the 50 level. The stock, which recently found support at its 10-week line, has formed a cup base within a larger pattern. Its buy point is at 57.60. The company will report Q2 earnings Thursday before the market open. Profit is expected at 8 cents a share, up 33% from a year ago.

AerCap Holdings (AER) cruised up nearly 4% to an all-time high. It cleared a 48.91 buy point from a flat base in volume that was tracking more than double its average pace. The Dutch aircraft leasing company was profiled in Stock Spotlight last week.

Leaders down in volume were few, but Monster Energy (MNST) fell 4% in fast trade. The bears ran wild Wednesday as the indexes fell hard in fast trade.
The Nasdaq chopped off 1.6%, while the Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 severed 1.4% and 1.3%, respectively.
Volume increased on both major exchanges, according to preliminary data.

While losses in Monday and Tuesday's sessions inspired talk of selective window dressing near the end of the quarter, the action on the first day of the fourth quarter was more like indiscriminate window breaking.

Every stock in the blue chip Dow except one fell. (The exception was Coca-Cola (KO), which inched up 0.2%.) On the Nasdaq, losers led winners by a 10-to-3 ratio. On the NYSE, losers led by a 3-to-1 ratio. The only up index was the Dow Jones utility average, which added 0.6%.
The day's worst performer among indexes was the Philadelphia Semiconductor Index, which dived 2.4%.
Top-rated stocks were hit hard. Five stocks in the IBD 50 dropped 5% or more:

Chip-sector play Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) fell 8%. Transportation-sector stock Trinity Industries (TRN) slid more than 7%. Auto-sector stock Gentherm (THRM) skidded 6%. Internet-sector play BitAuto (BITA) lost 6%. Finance-sector stock United Rentals (URI) dropped 6%.

The put-call ratio closed at 1.16, above the 1.0 level for the fifth straight session. Stifel upgraded the streaming movie service to buy from hold. The stock was on track for its third straight up week since a 16% gap-up Jan.…

Walk into a Buffalo Wild Wings (BWLD) location and it's easy to see why the stock is up more than 1,000% since its debut in November 2003. Flat-screen TVs are everywhere as patrons watch their favorite sporting events. Drinks flow while a steady stream of waiters exits the kitchen with plates full of wings. But the restaurant business is tough…

In the wake of Russia's food-safety probe of McDonald's (MCD) that some suggest is a response to European and U.S. sanctions over Ukraine, the financial focus is shifting to other businesses that could be affected by geopolitical tensions. Four McDonald's restaurants in Moscow were shuttered on alleged sanitary violations Wednesday, and dozens more across the nation are now under investigation,…

Shares of home drink-carbonation maker SodaStream (SODA) are popping on view-topping quarterly results. Revenue floated 6.6% to $141.2 million, passing views for $140.6 million. Earnings sank 28.3% to 43 cents a share — the fourth straight year-over-year decline — but still beat analyst estimates for 31 cents a share. International sales bubbled, but drippy Americas figures prompted the company to lower U.S. sales expectations.The company, most famously endorsed by actor Scarlett Johansson, rose 12% to 33.34 in afternoon trading on the stock market today. That's still well below the 52-week high of 69.78 last September. SodaStream hit a 2-year low of 28.65 on July 21.Sales picked up in Western Europe, Asia Pacific, and the region that covers Africa, the Middle East and Central and Eastern Europe. But SodaStream revenue in the Americas dipped 13.7% to $40.9 million from $47.4 million."In the U.S., soda maker volumes remained under pressure as we struggled to drive consumer demand and retailers worked through excess inventory carried over from the holiday season," said CEO Daniel Birnbaum in a release. "We are lowering our U.S. soda maker sales projections for the back half of the year while we reposition our brand behind health & wellness and refine our product line and marketing message to better promote this important consumer benefit."SodaStream now sees full-year revenue rising 5% from $562.7 million last year, down from a 15% rise projected last quarter.Analysts had expected an 11.2% rise in revenue for the year to $626 million.Keurig Green Mountain (GMCR) and Coca-Cola (KO) plan to roll out a cold Keurig device by next year that could further pressure SodaStream sales.The Israel-based company has reportedly been in talks to go private.

The major averages ended mixed Wednesday, as stocks pared earlier losses following the Federal Open Market Committee's policy statement.The Nasdaq led with a 0.5% gain, while the S&P 500 closed fractionally higher. The Dow, dragged down by Coca-Cola (KO) and UnitedHealth Group (UNH), fell 0.2%. Volume was mixed in the stock market today, according to preliminary data. Nasdaq volume fell from Tuesday.Transportation logistics providers, steel producers and enterprise software makers were among the day's top gainers. The biggest decliners included truck parts makers, meat processors and utilities.Icon (ICLR) gapped up and soared 8%, clearing a 48.91 cup-with-handle buy point in huge volume. The clinical research services provider reported Q2 profit of 64 cents a share, up 48% and 6 cents above views. Revenue rose 13% to $376 million, in line with forecasts. The Irish company also lifted its full-year EPS outlook.Among IBD 50 stocks, Trinity Industries gained 2% in above-average trade to mark a new closing high. It surged as much as 6% intraday after reporting late Tuesday Q3 sales and profit that beat views.Stocks opened higher amid mixed economic data, then sharply pared gains ahead of the Fed announcement. Payroll processor ADP reported 218,000 new jobs added in July, well below June's 281,000 and economists' forecast for 235,000. But the Commerce Department said the economy grew 4% in Q2, above views for 3.1% GDP growth.As expected, the Fed said it will continue tapering its bond purchases and that short-term rates will stay low for "a considerable time" after its bond-buying program ends. But it didn't specify when it plans to start raising short-term interest rates.Economic data due out tomorrow morning include jobless claims for the week ended July 26 and the Chicago purchasing manager index for July.Follow Nancy Gondo on Twitter at @IBD_NGondo.
Keurig Green Mountain late Wednesday reported that earnings growth perked up in its fiscal Q3, but the K-Cup maker's revenue and its EPS guidance failed to meet Wall Street's standards.

Earnings rose 21% to 99 cents a share excluding items, topping views for 88 cents. That ended a three-quarter string of slowing growth. But sales rose just 6% to $1.02 billion, slightly missing analyst estimates for $1.05 billion.

For fiscal Q4, Keurig Green Mountain (GMCR) anticipates high-single to low-double-digit sales growth. It raised its adjusted EPS target to 68-75. But that's still below Wall Street views for 86 cents and suggest a 20% year-over-year drop at the midpoint.
Keurig shares fell 2% after the close. During the regular session, the stock rose 39 cents to 118.13. It hit a record 128.50 on July 3.
In Q3, portion pack sales rose 10% to $826.3 million, including a 15% unit gain. But that shift to packs spurred other product sales to fall 17%. Brewer and accessory sales dipped 4% to $128 million.
Hot And Cold

Earlier in the year, Coca-Cola (KO) bought 16% of Keurig, which is developing a cold beverage brewer that is expected to be released next fiscal year. SodaStream (SODA), the carbonated at-home soda maker company, has recently seen earnings declines.
Keurig plans to introduce to the market this fall a new Keurig machine that brews carafes of coffee in addition to single-serve cups.

"Our solid year-over-year brewer shipment growth of 13% and our 15% unit growth in portion packs is indicative of the continued expansion of the Keurig system across the U.S. and Canada," said CEO Brian Kelley in a press release. "We also are excited about the imminent launch of our new Keurig 2.0 hot platform; the addition of formerly unlicensed and new brands to the Keurig hot beverage system during the quarter; and our progress on the new Keurig Cold beverage system."
The company said that it will give fiscal 2015 guidance some time this quarter.

Analyst views on Keurig have been mixed. Argus Research recently upgraded it to buy from hold on anticipated K-Cup and brewer sales, but Buckingham Research downgraded the company to neutral from buy on Keurig's investments in its cold beverage brewer.
Keurig said in June that it would partner with Subway to install single-serve Keurig K150 brewers in thousands of the ubiquitous sandwich chain's North American locations.
Since its patent on K-Cup expired two years ago, Keurig has seen increased competition from companies making similarly styled portion packs for its coffee makers at lower costs.
But the Keurig 2.0 won't accept unlicensed K-Cups, though it's not clear if the technology will keep out all copycats.

Keurig, which has had a partnership with Starbucks (SBUX) for several years, has announced deals in the past month with Harris Teeter Supermarkets (HTSI) and Cafe Bustelo to make K-Cup packs. It also forged an alliance with Nestle USA to create Coffee-mate branded K-Cups that include coffee with creamer.Keurig Green Mountain late Wednesday reported that earnings growth perked up in its fiscal Q3, but the K-Cup maker's revenue and its EPS guidance failed to meet Wall Street's standards.Earnings rose 21% to 99 cents a share excluding items, topping views for 88 cents. That ended a three-quarter string of slowing growth. But sales rose just 6% to $1.02 billion, slightly missing analyst estimates for $1.05 billion.For fiscal Q4, Keurig Green Mountain (GMCR) anticipates high-single to low-double-digit sales growth. It raised its adjusted EPS target to 68-75. But that's still below Wall Street views for 86 cents and suggest a 20% year-over-year drop at the midpoint.Keurig shares fell 2% after the close. During the regular session, the stock rose 39 cents to 118.13. It hit a record 128.50 on July 3.In Q3, portion pack sales rose 10% to $826.3 million, including a 15% unit gain. But that shift to packs spurred other product sales to fall 17%. Brewer and accessory sales dipped 4% to $128 million.Hot And ColdEarlier in the year, Coca-Cola (KO) bought 16% of Keurig, which is developing a cold beverage brewer that is expected to be released next fiscal year. SodaStream (SODA), the carbonated at-home soda maker company, has recently seen earnings declines.Keurig plans to introduce to the market this fall a new Keurig machine that brews carafes of coffee in addition to single-serve cups."Our solid year-over-year brewer shipment growth of 13% and our 15% unit growth in portion packs is indicative of the continued expansion of the Keurig system across the U.S. and Canada," said CEO Brian Kelley in a press release. "We also are excited about the imminent launch of our new Keurig 2.0 hot platform; the addition of formerly unlicensed and new brands to the Keurig hot beverage system during the quarter; and our progress on the new Keurig Cold beverage system."The company said that it will give fiscal 2015 guidance some time this quarter.Analyst views on Keurig have been mixed. It also forged an alliance with Nestle USA to create Coffee-mate branded K-Cups that include coffee with creamer.

Stocks opened the week with losses and were near session lows about two hours into Monday's session. Another round of disappointing housing data and dampened hopes for more stimulus in China fueled the selling.

The Nasdaq took another hit, falling 1.1%, as it drew closer to its 50-day moving average. The S&P 500 lost 0.7% and the Dow Jones industrial average gave up 0.3$. NYSE and Nasdaq volume was tracking much lower than Friday, but Friday's volume was unusually high due to options expiration.

In the stock market today, Apple (AAPL) added 0.3% on news the company sold more than 10 million iPhone 6 and iPhone 6 Plus units on Friday, Saturday and Sunday. Apple's muted response to the news isn't a big surprise. Good news is often priced into a stock before the news hits, and that appears to be the case with Apple. Shares are up more than 20% after a breakout earlier this year over 82.26.
Monster Beverage (MNST) added 1% in heavy volume. Coca-Cola (KO) recently bought a 16.7% equity stake in the energy drink maker.
Ambarella (AMBA) was among a handful of IBD 50 names that traded higher Monday. Shares rose 0.8%. The stock is extended, but continues to hold near highs after a recent breakout over 33.91.
Meanwhile, in M&A news, German drug firm Merck announced plans to buy chemical maker Sigma-Aldrich (SIAL) for $17 billion. Sigma-Aldrich got a big premium, soaring 34% on the news.

On the downside,Carbo Ceramics (CRR) got hit hard, falling 19%, after the company said sales of its synthetic fracking material fell as customers used more sand. Fracking, or hydraulic fracturing, is the process of extracting natural gas from hard to reach shale rock layers.

In economic news, August existing-home sales fell 1.8% to 5.05 million units. Economists expected a slight increase to 5.18 million units. The new data come on the heels of disappointing housing-start data last week. IBD's Building-Residential/Commercial group lost 1.4% on the news.Stocks opened the week with losses and were near session lows about two hours into Monday's session. Stocks notched uneven early gains Tuesday as investors weighed solid new home sales and mixed durable goods data against the potential for a deal between Greece and its eurozone creditors.
The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 0.3%. The Nasdaq added less than 0.1%. The S&P 500 split the difference, up 0.2%.
Volume was mixed on the stock market today, up 5% on the Nasdaq and 8% lower on the NYSE, compared to trade at the same time Monday.

The top-line number in the Commerce Department's May durable goods report showed a 1.8% decline and a downward revision to April's number to minus 1.5%. Economists had forecast a more mild 0.6% slip. The bulk of the miss was apparently due to a sharp decline in aircraft orders during the month. Minus transportation, durable goods orders rose 0.5% — in line with expectations. So far this year, durable goods orders are running 2.2% below last year's January to May period.

Housing prices improved steadily in May, lifting the Federal Housing Finance Agency's House Price Index 0.3%. That increase was equal to March's increase but just below consensus forecasts for a 0.4% gain. Year over year, the index is up 5.3%.

New home sales popped in May to an annualized rate of 546,000, according to the Commerce Department. That was up from April's (upwardly revised) 534,000 pace, well above consensus expectations of 525,000 and the strongest number since Feb. 2008.

A bit less rosy was the preliminary June manufacturing estimate from researcher Markit. Its Purchasing Managers Manufacturing Index was at 53.4, down from May's 53.8 number and below forecasts for an increase to 54.2. The number points to a third month of slowing activity and is the gauge's weakest gain in 18 months.
In stocks, it was a good morning for Florida-based companies.

Darden Restaurants (DRI) rose 3% to lead the S&P 500 by a wide margin. The Orlando-based owner of the Olive Garden, Red Lobster and other chains reported healthy fiscal fourth-quarter results and announced plans to slice off a portion of its real estate assets into a separate real estate investment trust. The stock popped to a new high, paring some gains but holding just above a cup-base buy point of 70.48.

Citrix Systems (CTXS) pecked out a 2% gain, the best increase among Nasdaq 100 stocks. The Fort Lauderdale-headquartered software developer is still in buying range, 4% above a 69.33 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.
Among leaders, most of the IBD 50 list posted modest gains and losses — with a couple of dramatic exceptions.

Ambarella (AMBA) led the list with a 9% rebound. The stock tumbled 21% Monday, following a short-seller's report on Friday that questioned the stock's valuation. The stock remains extended after a mid-May rebound from 10-week support and is well above its 10-week moving average.

At the bottom of the group, burger joint Sonic (SONC) dived 11% in massive trade. Fiscal third quarter sales and profits met consensus expectations, but full-year earnings guidance didn't. The sell-off stopped at a test of the stock's 10-week moving average, seriously damaging efforts to shape a three-month cup base.Stocks notched uneven early gains Tuesday as investors weighed solid new home sales and mixed durable goods data against the potential for a deal between Greece and its eurozone creditors.The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 0.3%. Revenue in the U.S., which accounted for about 56% of overall sales, increased 3.4% from Q2 2013. The advertising, marketing and media group earned 25 cents a share, in line with views and up…

Leading stocks show strength in several different ways.They break out of well-formed bases in heavy volume. They show tight weekly closes after a breakout. They get consistent support at their 10-week moving average during long advances.Another way a stock shows strength is by forming a base-on-base structure. If you want to find great market winners, keep an eye out for this special chart pattern.The pattern forms after a stock breaks out of base. But instead of going on a lengthy uptrend, it rallies for a bit — typically less than 20% from the base's recent entry point — then settles into another base. You'll often see a flat base form atop a first base, but a cup could emerge on top of a prior cup. A base-on-base pattern counts as one base.Examples abound throughout market history. Coca-Cola (KO) did it coming out of the Depression in 1934, and Boeing (BA) did it in 1978.Base-on-base patterns don't form any old time. They tend to form when selling pressure starts to build in the broad market. When the market takes a turn for the better, historical precedent shows that base-on-base patterns can deliver the strongest upside moves.That was the case with Ascend Communications soon after it went public in May 1994. It cleared a second-stage base-on-base pattern in December 1994. Its first base didn't look all that great due to wide-and-loose price action. Still, the stock managed to break out and rally 26% in three weeks. Because the bullish move triggered IBD's eight-week hold rule, those who bought at the initial breakout could sit tight as the second base formed.The second base looked much better than the first, mostly because of tighter, more orderly trade from week to week. The second base formed above the first, just what you want to see, and the base showed some tight weekly closes at the bottom of the base, near the 10-week moving average. Even better, weekly volume in the second breakout (1) was much stronger than the first.Ascend Communications was also showing strength in a relative way. It started building the right side of its base-on-base pattern when the Nasdaq was still in the throes of a pullback. Ascend was going up while the market was going down.The Nasdaq eventually bottomed and followed through in December, right at the time Ascend was breaking out past a 35.60 entry. The Nasdaq continued to gain traction and followed suit with a breakout of its own to new highs in February 2005. By that time, Ascend Communications had already rallied 67% past the buy point.
You try to think outside the box. But some boxes are unavoidable. Consider deadlines, budgets and disagreements. Short staffing. The economy. Ethics. Exhaustion. Crisis. Customer concerns.

Smart innovators learn how to use these boxes to make sure new business thinking blooms. Start celebrating the things that limit you, and go from there. "Constraints fuel creativity," Seth Lederman, a physician and CEO of prescription development firm Tonix Pharmaceuticals (TNXP), told IBD. "Think about Michelangelo and marble. The marble had a flaw in it, and he worked around it."

"Limitations are a good thing," agreed freelance creative director Ernie Schenck, author of "The Houdini Solution: Put Creativity and Innovation to Work by Thinking Inside the Box." "They point us toward something instead of toward nothing."
Hitting a wall? Try these:
• Think molecular. Big ideas tend to get all the emphasis, but Schenck challenges that knee-jerk thinking. "It's the constant implementation of small ideas that ultimately wins the day," he said.
Giant breakthroughs are often countered by the competition before they can hit the marketplace, he says. Then there are the customers, prone to balk at big swings.

Think New Coke in 1985. Executives thought the product update was sweet. Wrong, shouted loyal swiggers. "Coca-Cola (KO) managed to get back on its feet quickly," Schenck said. But the company learned a lesson: Unbridled, wild ideas can be dangerous. You must have a big enough operation to swallow them if they go sour.
• Man up. At the same time, you don't want to avoid big what-ifs. "There is a difference between being skeptical and being terrified," Schenck said.

• Check the clock. You don't need weeks or years to crack an innovation and fry it for the marketplace. "Few things can constipate a company or a person like the assumption that innovation is a time-eating process," Schenck said.
• Smash. "While there might not be any genuinely new ideas, there is an infinite supply of combinations of ideas," Schenck said.
The airplane took flight because someone thought about uniting a bird's wing with an engine.

• Stoke the beautiful mind. "It's not just the Jonas Salks and the Walt Disneys of the world who have this wonderful capability," Schenck said. "You are a fundamentally creative person with a power to innovate, and once you know how to tap into that power, it can change your life forever."You try to think outside the box. But some boxes are unavoidable. Consider deadlines, budgets and disagreements. Short staffing. The economy. Ethics. Exhaustion. Crisis. Robert Ludlum was one of the hottest authors of all time.Upon his death at age 73, his novels had sold 200 million to 300 million copies globally and been translated into dozens of languages.Yet Ludlum (1927-2001) didn't write his first novel until he was 42.His life is an inspiration to those who ponder the prudence of a late second career. Yes, it can be done, and Ludlum proved it."People called me all kinds of a nut," he told the press in 1973. "But my wife said, 'If you really feel this way, do it.'"Ludlum ended up writing 25 novels, earning advances from publishers as high as $4 million.Some of these novels were converted into Hollywood blockbusters, from "The Holcroft Covenant" in 1985 to "The Bourne Identity" in 2002. The latter was such a smash, it spawned three more films based on the Jason Bourne saga.More To ComeTwo additional movies based on Ludlum's work are planned for 2013 and 2014: "The Matarese Circle," starring Denzel Washington, and "The Chancellor Manuscript," with Leonardo DiCaprio headed for the top of the marquee.Ludlum's second career as a novelist built on his first as an actor and producer.Born in New York City, he found himself drawn to theater. As a teenager, he started acting in plays.Little did Ludlum know it, but he was learning through acting the art of storytelling that would make him a premier crafter of thrillers.Acting enriched his sense of how to set a scene, devise compelling dialogue and keep audiences on edge. Above all, it taught him the power of plot twists, which became his hallmark as a novelist."He was a master of plotting," Jeremy Lott, editor of Real Clear Books, told IBD. "He made you want to turn to the next page."That early exposure to the dramatic arts helped Ludlum lap other budding novelists."I equate suspense and good theater in a very similar way. I think it's all suspense and what-happens-next," he once mused.Ludlum also learned from his early acting how to sell a product. For a time, he made money working in commercials. Long before he generated a stream of marketable books, he was appearing in ads and doing voice-overs for such products as Tuna Helper.He enjoyed telling his friends that he financed part of his son's college education on "Plunge works fast," a line he spoke in a widely seen toilet cleaner ad.His work in plays and commercials was even more valuable in teaching him how to engage and persuade audiences. He performed at the North Jersey Playhouse and in some early TV shows, hobnobbing with such actors as Jack Lemmon.Ludlum ultimately found acting too stifling. He didn't want to speak lines handed to him; he wanted to write his own. "Usually I got cast as a lawyer or a homicidal killer," he told the Chicago Tribune. "But I got bored with the total lack of control an actor has."He tried to remedy his boredom by moving from acting to producing — and started the Playhouse on the Mall in Paramus, N.J.But producing brought its own share of frustrations. Crowds remained small in spite of the quality of his plays or his eye for talent; he enlisted a young Alan Alda for one of his plays.Ludlum joked that when "you did something exciting and good, you could shoot a moose in the lobby for all the people who ever came."He also found himself entangled in noncreative matters, such as contract negotiations and union disputes, which left him exhausted. "I couldn't stand it anymore," he said.From Stage To PageAfter two decades in the theater, Ludlum performed a second act as a novelist that many wouldn't have thought possible.It wasn't easy. He struggled to find a publisher for his first novel, "The Scarlatti Inheritance," a story set in Washington during World War II that revolves around the potential defection of a Nazi in possession of an explosive secret file.Ten publishers passed on it, before World Publishing finally rolled the presses with it in 1971.That novel and all the succeeding 24 were New York Times best-sellers.Ludlum's success derived in part from his penchant for tapping into a growing discontent with oversized institutions and into the public's wariness of powerful elites."What I don't like in this country and the world is largeness — large corporations, large governments," he told the Los Angeles Times.Another nut in his writing approach: innovation.Reviewers observed that he eschewed older, staler genres (such as crime fiction) and in effect established his own field of fiction — the conspiratorial thriller in which an individual, who is at once flawed and heroic, defeats large and nefarious global forces.This sphere fit with the mood of modern readers, who hungered for an answer to the baffling events of a war-saturated 20th century and longed for the triumph of good over evil if only in escapist fare. "He was in tune with the times," said Charles Coletta, an instructor in the Department of Popular Culture at Bowling Green State University in Ohio. "He knew how to tell a good story" and how to give people a sense that he was pulling back the curtain on dark times and showing them "what was really going on."The FizzAdded Coletta: "He has become a brand name like Coca-Cola (KO). People know what to expect."The power of his brand, added Coletta, can be measured in its influence on other books and movies: "His hero Jason Bourne is a more realistic version of James Bond, and that has influenced the last few Bond movies."Most people assume familiarity breeds contempt; Ludlum grasped its power to breed attachment. This is why the template of his titles — "The" followed by a proper noun and noun — never varied.So familiar and powerful is Ludlum's brand that it has continued after his death. He has been "Bourne again," noted Publisher's Weekly in 2009, reporting that the "Ludlum brand is nearly as strong today as when he was alive."Ludlum worked hard on his books, rising at 4:30 in the morning and churning out at least 2,000 words a day by hand.His research was meticulous. He understood that he needed to display factual expertise in order to engross readers, so he would spend months studying up on military and intelligence details and traveling abroad.To garner a global audience, he cultivated global themes.Long before 9/11, he explored the potent subject of international terrorism in "The Holcroft Covenant" and "The Matarese Circle."Rumored international conspiracies that fascinated the public also figured in his novels. In the Bourne books, he fed readers' endless appetite for CIA-related intrigue.Some critics panned his books as airport novels — books that gave jet passengers cheap thrills as they soared over the world he was describing. The brickbats of the critics didn't bother him. He wrote for the common man."I don't believe that my first name is Leo, or that my last name is Tolstoy. I'm a storyteller," he said.

Salesforce.com's (CRM) northward growth trajectory is expected to continue as the company replaces aging customer relationship management systems with its cloud-based software and attracts more customers to its burgeoning marketing services business.

Salesforce.com is the No. 1 provider of customer relationship management software, delivering its software as a service via the Internet "cloud." It's set to report its earnings for its fiscal Q3 ended Oct. 31 after the close Monday, with its stock trading near all-time highs.
Salesforce.com's cloud-based service is an alternative to often more expensive on-premise systems sold by Oracle (ORCL), SAP (SAP) and other rivals.

The company earlier targeted its cloud service to small and midsize corporate customers, but it's been signing up larger customers, such as Coca-Cola (KO). The transition to larger customers could gain steam in the second half of this year, says Brad Sills, an analyst for Maxim Group.
"That is when large enterprises typically sign agreements ... so the expectation is that those large enterprise replacement deals start to close in Q3, Q4," Sills told IBD.

In July, Salesforce closed its $2.5 billion acquisition of ExactTarget, a marketing services company that Salesforce has combined with earlier acquisitions of Buddy Media, a social media marketing services company, and Radian6, a social media monitoring firm. Its goal is to create a one-stop shop for marketing and social media business applications.
ExactTarget will likely provide significant upside to Q3 revenue, Sills says.
"You only had three weeks of ExactTarget's revenue in last quarter's numbers and now you have a full quarter, which in my model is $55 million in total revenue," he said.
Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect Salesforce to report total revenue of $1.05 billion, up 34% from the year-earlier period. They expect earnings per share minus items of 9 cents, up a penny.

For the current quarter, analysts expect revenue of $1.12 billion, up 34%, with EPS ex-items of 7 cents, down from 13 cents. The decline stems from restructuring charges associated with integrating ExactTarget.

Salesforce.com stock was flat in midday trading in the stock marketFriday, near 57. Earlier in the session, the stock touched an all-time high of 57.89, the third time in the past four days the stock has touched a new high. The transition to larger customers could gain steam in the second half of this year, says Brad Sills, an analyst for Maxim Group."That is when large enterprises typically sign agreements ... so the expectation is that those large enterprise replacement deals start to close in Q3, Q4," Sills told IBD.In July, Salesforce closed its $2.5 billion acquisition of ExactTarget, a marketing services company that Salesforce has combined with earlier acquisitions of Buddy Media, a social media marketing services company, and Radian6, a social media monitoring firm. Its goal is to create a one-stop shop for marketing and social media business applications.ExactTarget will likely provide significant upside to Q3 revenue, Sills says."You only had three weeks of ExactTarget's revenue in last quarter's numbers and now you have a full quarter, which in my model is $55 million in total revenue," he said.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect Salesforce to report total revenue of $1.05 billion, up 34% from the year-earlier period. They expect earnings per share minus items of 9 cents, up a penny.For the current quarter, analysts expect revenue of $1.12 billion, up 34%, with EPS ex-items of 7 cents, down from 13 cents. The decline stems from restructuring charges associated with integrating ExactTarget.Salesforce.com stock was flat in midday trading in the stock marketFriday, near 57. Earlier in the session, the stock touched an all-time high of 57.89, the third time in the past four days the stock has touched a new high. Salesforce.com stock is up more than 35% this year.

An inheritance from relatives can be a boon, but choosing the right financial adviser to make that money grow is crucial. When clients opt to invest inherited money with a financial adviser, it can expand options and prepare them financially for the future. Inheritance also carries traps that need to be avoided to ensure that the money is not wasted.…
Stocks began modestly lower Monday, then reversed to small gains.
The Nasdaq was barely above the break-even line while the S&P 500 rose 0.2%. The Dow Jones industrial average was flat. Volume was running higher in the stock market today vs. Friday's sluggish pace.
Blue chips were about evenly split between winners and losers. Dow components Chevron (CVX) and Home Depot (HD) showed the biggest gains, with each up 0.8%. IBM (IBM) took the hardest hit, down 1.5%.
In the IBD 50, a proxy for leading stocks, chip stocks were in retreat while transportation-related stocks were advancing.
The schedule for economic data is thin, but the Dallas Federal Reserve manufacturing survey was expected to be released this morning.

West Texas intermediate crude oil and Brent crude were each up 1%, crossing the $55 and $60 marks, respectively. Concerns swirled around supply disruption in Libya, which is struggling with port blockades and protests.Stocks began modestly lower Monday, then reversed to small gains.The Nasdaq was barely above the break-even line while the S&P 500 rose 0.2%. What can Morningstar tell investors and their financial advisers? Plenty, judging by the registration of nearly 2,000 of them for the research firm's 26th annual investment conference, which gets into full swing Thursday.

This year's subjects range from active management strategies to "strategic beta" — an index investing strategy that seeks to boost returns by using certain features of active management — to unconstrained bond funds, dividend-paying stocks and international opportunities.

This year's gathering, which began Wednesday afternoon in Chicago, is scheduled to feature high-profile fund investors, including Pimco founder and chief investment officer Bill Gross (Thursday lunch keynote), Fidelity's Will Danoff, Ariel Investments' John Rogers and Oakmark's David Herro.

Morningstar expects the conference to draw 1,914 attendees, including 1,066 advisers. Last year, 1,963 people attended, including 1,028 advisers. Information gleaned from the conference will help advisers serve their clients, including those preparing for or in retirement.

Danoff, manager of $107.5 billion Fidelity Contrafund , was on a Wednesday panel that discussed how to find leaders ahead of the crowd. He said he looks for firms whose durable multiyear earnings growth is not reflected in its current price. And he looks for best-of-breed stocks — whose high returns on capital and solid free cash flow contribute to strong competitive positions.
Thursday Panels
Herro's Thursday morning panel was to be aimed at finding opportunities in a market that looks fairly valued to many investors.

Herro, a manager of three Oakmark funds, including $32.8 billion International , told IBD beforehand that he planned to discuss where he sees value in Europe, why his weighting is low in emerging markets and his outlook on Japan.
Emerging Markets

Another morning panel will focus on emerging markets. Justin Leverenz, manager of $42.6 billion Oppenheimer Developing Markets , told IBD he planned to describe what the next wave of emerging markets growth will look like.
Yet another early Thursday panel will consider whether strategic beta funds are useful or Frankensteinian monsters, combining tactics that don't belong together.

On an afternoon panel about protective moats, Stephen Yacktman of Yacktman Asset Management said he would discuss stable operating margins and returns on investment for names like Procter & Gamble (PG) and Coca-Cola (KO). In a downward-trending stock market they should hold their value better than many rivals, he said.
A session later on Thursday will ask panelists where their preferred global opportunities are.

Panelist Dennis Stattman, cofounder of $60 billion BlackRock Global Allocation Fund , told IBD that he likes valuations in Japan and Western Europe. Japan's easy money policy dwarfs that of the U.S. And he likes prospects for corporate earnings and stock buybacks.

Bernie Horn, manager of $269 million Polaris Global Value , currently likes small and midcap stocks, especially in Japan, China, Taiwan and Hong Kong. Many valuations in those parts of Asia remain attractive vs. stocks in developed markets, particularly the U.S., that have enjoyed large run-ups, he told IBD.
Many stocks in Japan now benefit from low valuations after years of economic doldrums, combined with a new government stimulus program and a post-tsunami rebound.

In Thailand, Horn likes Thai Oil, a stock whose price has been hurt by concerns over domestic political turmoil. The energy and transportation conglomerate's refinery lets them convert petroleum to complex, higher value products.

He recently added a smaller Norwegian bank, SpareBank. "The Norwegian economy is slowing a little, but it's one of the healthiest in Europe because of oil," Horn said. "So if you're going to invest in a bank that's a good value, it's better to buy in an economy that's doing well vs. one that's falling off a cliff."

Horn also likes longtime Hong Kong-listed holding Guangdong Investment. "It's a water utility that supplies all the water from Guangdong province to Hong Kong," he said. "It is a lower risk, steady cash flow business."
Friday Highlights
On Friday morning, T. Rowe Price's Thomas Huber and Wellington's Don Kilbride will discuss where to find attractive dividends with downside protection.

Also Friday morning, a panel will discuss opportunities and potential land mines in floating-rate bank loans. Eaton Vance's Scott Page, whose funds include the $14.1 billion Floating Rate Fund , told IBD that he prefers a moderate strategy that lets him harvest coupon yield — EVBLX currently averages 4.5% — with little risk to his principal. More aggressive strategies gain 25 to 50 basis points in yield annually, but they put capital at risk when the credit cycle ends, he says.What can Morningstar tell investors and their financial advisers? Patent expiration often heralds slower growth for innovative firms.Such has been the case with Keurig Green Mountain (GMCR), which sells single-cup coffee brewers along with single portion K-Cups of their own and licensed brands of coffee.The expiration of key patents in September 2012 let unlicensed rivals win share in the lucrative K-Cup market.Keurig, which boosted sales at a compound annual clip of roughly 55% from 2009 to 2013, was forced to make do with more pedestrian low double-digit growth levels. Some bearish observers wondered if the market for single cup-coffee was as robust as Keurig claimed.But Keurig, on the verge of introducing two major products, thinks it has the solution to slowing growth. And Wall Street seems convinced. Keurig stock, which ended 2013 priced just under $75, recently fetched over $120.Keurig's Composite Rating — 98 of a possible 99 —puts it first among the eight firms in IBD's Wholesale-Food industry group. With a market value of just over $20 billion, it ranks second in size only to Sysco (SYY) among those eight.Still, the company has had to weather declining revenue growth in the past two years. Sales growth, which as recently as the quarter ended Sept. 30, 2012, stood at 33%, was just 10% in the quarter ended March 31. Even with slower revenue growth, Keurig has been able to expand earnings per share nicely: EPS rose 16% last quarter.Later this year, Keurig will unveil a new system that brews whole carafes of coffee as well as its familiar one-cup servings. Perhaps more important, the Keurig 2.0 brewers threaten to lock out unlicensed purveyors of K-Cup compatibles.Coca-Cola StakeNext year Keurig will carve out new product territory with its Keurig Cold system for at-home carbonation of soft drinks.Coca-Cola Co. (KO) has invested in the at-home carbonation concept by purchasing 16% of Keurig shares. Coke's share purchases seem to validate Keurig's carbonation product plan. They've also fueled speculation of a buyout.Akshay Jagdale, analyst with KeyBanc Capital Markets, makes the bullish case. "We think the company can triple to quadruple its earnings in a three to five year period. It has the potential to do that," he said in a phone interview.He believes Keurig's core brewing business is far from saturation and that Keurig Cold will offer new capabilities beyond those of existing home-carbonation platforms."Five years from now, they have the potential to earn $8.20 from the hot platform and $3.50 from the cold," he said. Jagdale has a price target of $150. If Keurig's hot and cold businesses flourish as he anticipates, the stock would be "a steal" at his price target of $150.Others have their doubts. Theo Brito, an analyst with BTIG, a New York-based trader for hedge funds, mutual funds and other institutional clients, begins by throwing cold carbonated water on the notion of a Coke buyout, which he terms "very unlikely." His fundamental skepticism is centered on Keurig's core brewing business.Pods And ProfitKeurig brewers are in roughly 18 million U.S. households. Suzanne DuLong, Keurig vice president of investor relations, notes that there are 90 million coffee-drinking households in America. "We think there's still ample opportunity with our Hot systems," she said.Brito questions whether all those 90 million households have the income or inclination to purchase a Keurig brewer, which can run from $80 to $189.Brito claims that as Keurig has expanded sales, the average number of cups brewed on its machines — the attachment rate, in industry lingo — has declined."Over the last five years, there's been an annual decline of around 10%," Brito told IBD. "I expect the decline to continue."That's important because Keurig derives the bulk of its profit from K-Cups, not brewers. Declining K-Cup sales would definitely pinch margins, he contends.Still, Wall Street bulls have been winning the argument on Keurig this year. And KeyBanc's Jagdale tackles the bearish doubts head-on. He contends that Keurig has the potential to vastly increase the household presence of its brewers.In Europe, he notes, single-serve brewers are in 30%-35% of households. Keurig currently has just 20% penetration.And Jagdale foresees huge gains in single portion coffee as the new Keurig 2.0 locks out unlicensed packet providers. In just the last year and a half, unlicensed sellers have gone from zero to roughly 14% of the K-Cup market, he notes."The Keurig 2.0 brewer will not allow any unlicensed cups to work with it," he said.Jagdale sees signs that the strategy is already working. He notes that several retailers — including Target (TGT) — that had been unlicensed have recently entered into licensing arrangements with Keurig. He suggests that retailers prefer sharing coffee packet revenue with Keurig to being locked out of the business entirely.Jagdale does not venture to predict the likelihood of Coca-Cola expanding its equity ownership in Keurig Green Mountain. "It's hard to predict what will happen with buyouts," he said.He does think the likelihood of buyout "will increase with the success of Keurig Cold."The Cool FactorKeurig Cold systems will hit the market in 2015. Keurig spokeswoman DuLong says that at $80 to $189, Keurig Cold units will carry similar pricing to Keurig brewers.Consumers have other choices for at home carbonation, including products from market leader SodaStream International (SODA).Still, the market is in its infancy and Jagdale is impressed with one expected Keurig Cold feature: "It will be the only product that can produce a cold beverage."The Keurig carbonators could begin to contribute as much as $3.50 in EPS just three years after their 2015 introduction , Jagdale estimates. That's one reason he expects Keurig to get back on the fast growth track."You're going to see an acceleration in top-line growth for Keurig," he said.

Stocks danced higher Tuesday morning and were holding most of their gains in early afternoon trade.
The Nasdaq stepped up 0.8%, the S&P 500 0.6% and the Dow Jones industrial average 0.4%. Volume in the stock market today was running moderately higher than Monday's pace.
On the Dow, winners led losers by a 2-to-1 ratio.
Goldman Sachs (GS) popped about 2% higher in strong volume. The stock had been hesitating around a 171.18 buy point, but cleared it decisively at today's open.

Goldman's entry, however, is not ideal. The 171.18 buy point is derived from a low handle, and low handles are more prone to failure than a proper handle. The base, though, is a double-bottom structure, so another entry is possible at 175.69, if the stock can clear that area in strong volume.

IBD's earnings rating for Goldman Sachs is 78, putting it in the top 22 percentile for profitability. Aggressive growth investors expect better than that, but income investors might give Goldman's first-stage base some consideration. The stock's annualized dividend yield is 1.3%.

In recent days, the rumor mill surrounding Goldman Sachs has been busy. On Monday, Reuters reported that Goldman Sachs signed a preliminary agreement to buy a 30% stake in Turkey's largest integrated port. On Tuesday, Reuters reported that Goldman and a private equity firm were forging a deal to buy a 20% stake in bad-debt manager China Huarong Asset Management.
Among IBD's Big Cap 20 stocks, Halliburton (HAL) thrust 3% in heavy volume as it scored a new high. On Monday, when it reported earnings, the stock posted a new high early, then reversed lower.
Another Big Cap 20 stock also pegged a new high. Canadian National Railway (CNI) gapped up 2% in roughly double volume. It too reversed off a new high Monday.
Big caps have been leading small caps over the past 12 months. The small-cap Russell 2000 is up 9% in the past 12 months vs. a 25% gain in IBD's Big Cap 20 and a 17% advance in the large-cap S&P 500.

Many companies reported mixed quarterly results today — missing on either earnings or revenue but not both. Insurance company Travelers (TRV) missed on earnings and gapped down 4% in heavy volume. Coca-Cola (KO) missed on revenue and gapped down 3% in heavy volume. McDonald's (MCD) missed on both earnings and revenue. The stock gapped down about 2% in fast turnover.

On a positive note, managed health care provider Centene (CNC) topped the Street's estimates on the top and bottom lines. Worldwide oil demand will grow by 1.4 million barrels per day in 2015, up from growth of 1.2 million this year, the International Energy Agency said Friday. Demand will be driven by 4.2% growth from China, up from 3.3% in 2014. Non-OPEC countries will boost supply by 1.2 million bpd, meeting most of the demand growth, with the U.S. and Canada accounting for two-thirds of that.
Here is a summary of top world and U.S. economic news for Friday, July 11, 2014.
Obama to business: Pay suppliers faster

The White House touted a new initiative to get major companies to speed up payments to small firms that serve as contractors. Among 26 companies involved are Apple (AAPL), Honda (HMC), Coca-Cola (KO), Walgreen (WAG), FedEx (FDX) and IBM (IBM). The program mirrors a federal government effort to pay contractors within 15 days, aiding cash flow and making it easier to grow.

 Canada's economy lost 9,400 jobs in June and the unemployment rate ticked up to 7.1%, Statistics Canada reported. The details were a bit better, with 33,500 full-time jobs added. Part-time jobs fell back after rising by 26,000 the prior month. Over the past year, job growth has averaged a tepid 6,000 per month.
Socialist to get key European economy post

Jean-Claude Juncker, who is widely expected to be confirmed as the new head of the European Commission next week, pledged to name a socialist as economic affairs commissioner to reward the center-left members of the coalition supporting him. The post has been held by a fiscal hawk.
 France's current-account deficit widened to $4.2 billion in May from $3.1 billion in April, as the goods deficit increased and the service surplus narrowed.

 Germany's inflation rate rose 0.4% in June from May, the Destasis national statistics office said. The annual inflation rate picked up to 1% from 0.6% in May. Inflation in the broader euro zone was just 0.5% in June. European Central Bank officials have said that low inflation in Germany makes it harder for other euro members to adjust wages and become more competitive economically.

 Hungary's consumer prices fell 0.3% in June from a year ago, amid lower food and energy prices. Hungary's central bank has been cutting its main interest rate for two years, from 7% to 2.2%, and further cuts are expected.
